â€‰ A "KIND and highly talented" Liverpool-based drag superstar died after suffering a cardio-respiratory arrest after taking ketamine at their home in Cheshire, an inquest has concluded. Friends told of the harrowing moment they found James Lee Williams - known to many as The Vivienne - in the bath at their home in Chorlton-by-Backford in Cheshire on Sunday January 5. It is suspected they had died two days earlier. During the inquest into James' death at Cheshire Coroner's Court in Warrington, family and close friends paid tribute to the drag star, who shot to fame after winning the first season of RuPaul's Drag Race UK as The Vivienne, and was widely known and loved in their adopted city of Liverpool. James used the pronouns them/ they in life, which the ECHO will use when referring to them in this article - other than in direct quotes from evidence given to the inquest where "he or him" was at times used. Friends and family told the inquest they became concerned for James on Sunday January 5 having not heard from them for some time. Friend and neighbour Janine Godbold told the hearing that having spoken to James' friends, she decided to drive to their house, for which she had a key. She and her son Ryan became increasingly concerned as they approached the house and saw James' dog Panda desperately trying to get out. They ventured into the house and upstairs where Janine found James in the bath. In an emotional account, she said: "He just looked like he was sleeping. I ran over to him and put my hand under his head to stop his face going into the water. "I screamed for Ryan, telling him he needed to call for an ambulance and to get some help. I kept hold of them because I didn't want their face in the water. Then I just sat with James and made sure his head didn't go under the water." The court also heard from James' best friend Bobby Musker, who described James as "the kindest person I knew, who would help everyone." He said he was aware of James' struggles with ketamine, saying he would go long stints without taking it, before returning to take the drug. Mr Musker had spoken to James on the evening of Friday January 3 and told the court he believed he could recognise that James had been using the drug at the time - adding that he had taken an Uber into Liverpool, which made him think James had been to purchase the drug. Mr Musker told the court: "I could kind of tell when he was on it, so I could tell he had taken some." Concluding his emotional evidence, Mr Musker added: "Him taking drugs didn't define him as a person. He did so much good. I don't want the public to see him just as what has happened, with drug use, that wasn't the person that defined him. There was a lot more to him." The court was read a written statement by Dr David Butterworth, a forensic pathologist who carried out the post-mortem on James. Dr Butterworth said he was clear in his statement that James died from the effects of cardiorespiratory arrest due to the use of ketamine and said there were no signs of drowning in the bath. While the amount of ketamine in James' system was not as high as amounts usually associated with toxicity or death, Dr Butterworth said the amount may have been higher initially as he wasn't found for two days. He said: "In my opinion, the cause of death was cardio-respiratory arrest due to ketamine use." Earlier in the inquest, James' father Lee Eliott Williams had spoken movingly, stating that James was "full of life", "outgoing" and was always there to help others achieve their goals as they achieved theirs. Mr Williams added: "He never turned his back on anyone, he wanted to help his community, to help other drag queens achieve their goals." Before recording her verdict, Senior Coroner Jacqueline Devonish, asked the family of James Lee Williams for their thoughts. James' sister Chanel told the court: "We acknowledge that James' death is as a result of drug use but we wholeheartedly know that was not his intention. "He loved life, he loved his family and friends and he loved his career. We feel that the conclusion should be one of misadventure." Recording her verdict, Ms Devonish described James as "hard-working, highly talented, charismatic and well liked and loved." She added: "He did a lot for his community and he made a name for himself as a performing artist and as a drag artist as The Vivienne. His family say he was very bold in pursuit of his dreams and that he made a difference. "It is very important to the family that James is not remembered for his use of ketamine, because drugs don't define the person he was." The coroner said that on the balance of probabilities, it is likely that James died on the evening of Friday January 3. She said the toxicology results show that there was still a fairly high amount of ketamine in James' system when he was found two days later, adding that the toxicology results suggest an "acute overdose". She said the medical cause of death will be recorded as cardio-respiratory arrest due to ketamine use. Concluding, the coroner added: "On the balance of probabilities, I am satisfied that James Lee Williams' death was a misadventure. He took ketamine but he did not intend to end his own life."

â€‰ The pregnant singer made the revelation while walking the blue carpet at the world premiere of the 'Smurfs' movie in Brussels on June 28 Kirsty Hatcher Link copied Antoine Flament/Getty Rihanna at the world premiere of the 'Smurfs' in Brussels on June 28, 2025 NEED TO KNOW Rihanna revealed her go-to karaoke song at the world premiere of the Smurfs movie in Brussels on June 28 The singer's unexpected choice is seemingly inspired by her latest role as Smurfette in the film "Maybe 'Burning Blue' by Mariah the Scientist," the pregnant star said with a laugh Rihanna is all about the blue! While walking the blue carpet in a sheer baby blue Chanel look at the Smurfs world premiere in Brussels on June 28, the singer, 37, revealed that her go-to karaoke song is seemingly inspired by her latest role. Speaking to U.K. radio station Capital FM at the premiere, the pregnant star, who voices Smurfette in the movie, shared her top pick when it comes to taking to the mic. â€œOhhhh!â€ she said as she thought about her answer and placed her hand on the side of her head. â€œOh my gosh, it's, it's, it's â€¦ maybe 'Burning Blue' by Mariah the Scientist," she continued with a laugh. The track, which was released in May and premiered its music video on May 8, is the lead single from the R&B singer's upcoming fourth studio album, according to Billboard. It peaked at No. 25 on the Billboard Hot 100. Prince Williams/FilmMagic Mariah the Scientist Thanks to the Smurfs movie, fans of the Barbadian musician got to hear new music from the star in the form of â€œFriend of Mine.â€ The catchy, synth-heavy song features lyrics about friendship and a music video filled with psychedelic graphics, bright colors and dancing Smurfs, including Rihanna as Smurfette. At the film's world premiere, Rihanna, who also produces the movie, was joined by her partner A$AP Rocky. The Fenty Beauty founder dressed her baby bump in a flowy Chanel chiffon top and skirt, with the top featuring a sheer center section that revealed her belly. The look took 840 hours to make, according to the fashion brand. Never miss a story â€” sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offerâ€‹â€‹, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. Arnold Jerocki/Getty Rihanna and A$AP Rocky at the 'Smurfs' world premiere in Brussels on June 28, 2025 Meanwhile, rapper Rocky, 36, who complemented Rihanna in a striped blue tie, appeared to reveal the sex of the couple's third child together on the blue carpet. Entertainment Tonight co-host Kevin Frazier asked the musician, â€œIs that the girl you've been waiting for?â€ as he gestured towards Rihanna. Rocky responded with a smile and said, â€œIt is, man, it is.â€ The PEOPLE App is now available in the Apple App Store! Download it now for the most binge-worthy celeb content, exclusive video clips, astrology updates and more! Paramount Animation James Corden and Rihanna's characters in the 'Smurfs' movie He then held up a Smurfette toy to the camera and added, â€œâ€” Right here, right here,â€ seemingly redirecting his answer. â€œYou know what I'm asking!â€ Frazier replied as Rocky continued laughing. The pair are already parents to sons RZA, 3, and Riot, 1. Smurfs hits theaters on Friday, July 18. Read the original article on People

â€‰ Kris Jenner said she was "called out in the family group chat" after wearing the same dress as her daughter, Kim Kardashian , while attending Jeff Bezos' wedding in Venice last week. The matriarch of the Kardashian family shared a carousel of photos and videos on Instagram on Monday, showing off the stunning purple Dolce & Gabbana dress she put on during on of the parties during the Amazon founder's nuptials in Italy . In the caption of the post, Kris, 69, said Kim, 44, inspired her to wear the gown, which she accessorized with the same diamond statement necklace the Skims founder wore at the 2023 Dolce & Gabbana Alta Moda show in Puglia. Kris posed with the long, flowy dress barefoot - and she also shared some snippets of Kim donning the same gown two years ago. She captioned the post, "'DOLCE DOLCE DOLCE' in my best Carrie Bradshaw voiceâ€¦ We'll always have Venice!" READ MORE: I read every single day â€” these 10 books are the best I've read this year so far READ MORE: Everything we know about Netflix's Squid Game USA spin-off after bombshell celebrity cameo She added, "Thank you Jeff and Lauren for the unforgettable memories, we love you!!" Kris then went on to clarify that Kim had previously worn the dress, saying it was "too beautiful not to bring back" for the wedding. She then admitted she was "called out on the family group chat" for wearing it. She wrote, "Kim wore this amazing dress at the Dolce & Gabbana Alta Moda show in Puglia a couple years ago, and I was so in love with it, it was just too beautiful not to bring back for this special weekend!! I may have gotten called out on the family group chatâ€¦ Kim, you're my inspiration!!" Many fans commented the post, praising Kris for her style. One said, "Like mother like daughter." Another wrote, "This is YOUR moment. Divine!" A third said, "Wow just wow." Another wrote, "We love a sustainable fashion moment." Khloe Kardashian commented on the post, describing her mom as "my gorgeous queen." Paris Hilton commented with a heart eyes emoji. Kris attended Jeff's wedding to Lauren SÃ¡nchez with her daughters Kim and Khloe, as well as Kylie and Kendall Jenner, and her partner Corey Gamble. During the three-day wedding celebrations, Kris rocked a number of distinctive looks including a Valentino black dress - and she looked younger than ever while on a lavish boat ride with her daughters Kylie and Kendall. Despite being 69 years old, the entrepreneur showed off her youthful appearance as she posed for photos during the event. Kris was seen smiling alongside her younger daughters as they left the Gritti Palace Hotel for a party and boarded a water taxi to reach the venue of the third day of the wedding celebrations. She donned a black and white dress paired with sunglasses and earrings - and according to body language expert Judi James, she seemed to be "very proud" of her daughters. Earlier in the day, Kris put on a black dress while heading to the Harry's Bar in Venice. Her partner Corey also wore an all-black outfit paired with a necklace, sunglasses and a brown hat. Kris was seen arriving in Venice with Kim and Khloe on Thursday last week - and before the wedding whirlwind , she stepped out for a day of shopping with Khloe ahead of her 41st birthday on Friday. The pair were seen walking around the historic streets of Venice with Khloe wearing a simple black sleeveless midi dress with Chanel thong sandals and oversized sunglasses and Kris in a leopard print Dolce & Gabbana ensemble with black flats and dark sunglasses. â€‰ The global personal luxury goods market, valued at USD 410 billion in 2024, is projected to reach USD 526 billion by 2030, growing at a CAGR of 4.24%. The U.S.-China trade war poses challenges, impacting costs and availability. Key trends include circular economy initiatives, online retail strategies, and urban demand in emerging markets. Segment growth varies, with watches and jewelry leading, while beauty and fragrances witness fastest growth. APAC remains the dominant region, driven by urbanization and digital retail transformation. Major players like LVMH and Rolex leverage strategic partnerships and innovation to maintain market positioning. Personal Luxury Goods Market Dublin, July 01, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The "Personal Luxury Goods Market Research Report 2025-2030" report has been added to ResearchAndMarkets.com's offering. The Personal Luxury Goods Market was valued at USD 410 billion in 2024, and is projected to reach USD 526 billion by 2030, rising at a CAGR of 4.24%. The global personal luxury goods market is fragmented and characterized by numerous manufacturers that hold modest market share. Key players, including LVH, Prada Group, Rolex, Kering, and Richemont, among others, have established dominance in the market by continuously innovating and expanding their product offerings. Major vendors are strategically implementing innovative technologies to maintain their market positions. For instance, in 2023, Burberry introduced its virtual store by partnering with Blankos Block Party, a gaming platform, and offering interactive product discovery. The companies in the personal luxury goods industry are also focusing on several strategic partnerships with other providers to ensure continuous supply chains and manufacturing capabilities. For instance, in 2023, Kering completed a 30% acquisition of the Italian luxury fashion house Valentino. The partnership is between Valentino's parent company, Mayhoola, and it has also provided an option for Kering to acquire the remaining 70% by 2028. The leaders in the personal luxury goods market are making significant R&D investments to enhance the availability and differentiation of their products. For instance, in 2024, Richemont acquired Vhernier, which is an Italian jewelry brand, to enhance its Jewelry Maisons division. Furthermore, companies are increasingly expanding their product range and strengthening their market positions through acquisitions and partnerships. For instance, in 2024, Lavie Luxe launched its new 18% fragrance concentration perfume line, featuring four Eau de Parfum fragrances named LUSH, LILY, LAGOON, and LOVE. Consumers are increasingly interested in luxury goods that are designed with circular economic principles, such as those that can be easily upcycled. Gucci was the first luxury brand to use ECONYL recycled nylon in ready-wear pieces, which is a 100% recycled nylon derived from fishing nets, textile waste, and a thick pile fabric used for carpets and upholstery. Luxury brands have increasingly adopted online approaches to meet evolving consumer expectations. For instance, in 2023, Dior was the most popular luxury brand online because of its strategic investments in digital marketing, e-commerce, and social media engagement. This approach helped the brand to engage a wider audience, which has boosted its online sales, especially in markets like China and the US. Brands strategically position themselves to capture renewed demand from urban areas. For instance, Dior expanded its Dioriviera pop-up shops in places like Bali and Phuket. It has created immersive experiences that resonate with travelers seeking exclusivity. Hence, such factors are supporting the demand for the personal luxury goods market across emerging nations. As the global economies continue to grow, disposable income levels rise, leading to increased spending on luxury items like footwear. Consumers are increasingly inclined towards luxury footwear because of changing lifestyles and fashion trends. Luxury footwear companies are focusing on the growing consumer base in developing countries such as India and other Southeast Asian countries, where wealth and demand for luxury goods are rising. In 2022, Louis Vuitton introduced its exclusive footwear collection for the Indian market, which features new colors like Rani Pink and glittering designs for celebrating India's cultural heritage. Urbanization in emerging markets such as China, India, and Southeast Asia continues to drive demand for the personal luxury goods market. In India, platforms like Luxepolis have significantly supported the development of the market by offering new and pre-owned luxury items to a growing audience in smaller cities, as the growing urban population increases the demand for high-end items. Brands are strategically positioning themselves to capture renewed demand from urban areas. For instance, Dior expanded its Dioriviera pop-up shops to places like Bali and Phuket. Additionally, collaborations between fashion houses and hospitality venues such as Fendi's beach club in Marbella have created immersive experiences that resonate with travelers seeking exclusivity. INDUSTRY RESTRAINTS The disruption in the supply chain has led to increased costs for raw materials, logistics, and transportation, which have raised operational costs and are often passed on to end consumers which leading to higher luxury goods prices. The focus on limited production to maintain exclusivity significantly raises the production costs for luxury brands. Brands often face higher unit costs for manufacturing, sourcing premium materials, and utilizing skilled labor for producing limited edition items. This limits scalability and hampers the personal luxury goods market demand. Furthermore, major brands occasionally face backlash for products or marketing campaigns, such as Louis Vuitton for selling a scarf inspired by the Palestinian keffiyeh and a jacket that seems to present Jamaican culture by using the country's flags but incorrectly represented. These factors hamper the brand value and show the need for careful consideration in global marketing efforts. PERSONAL LUXURY GOODS MARKET GEOGRAPHICAL ANALYSIS The APAC region dominated the global personal luxury goods market, accounting for a share of over 38% in 2024. APAC is experiencing a surge in urbanization and rising disposable income, particularly in countries like China, India, and Southeast Asian countries. A growing middle and upper-middle class is driving demand for luxury goods as markers of status, success, and aspiration. As consumers become more brand-conscious, luxury ownership is increasingly viewed as a symbol of achievement....

â€‰ MIAMI â€” Indianapolis-based mall giant Simon Property Group has acquired the remaining interest of the retail and parking component at Brickell City Centre, a 5.4 million-square-foot mixed-use development in downtown Miami. Swire Properties Inc. sold the majority 75 percent stake in the property's 500,000-square-foot retail portion for $512 million, according to several media outlets. Simon had previously owned a 25 percent, non-managing interest in The Shops at Brickell City Centre. Following the transaction, Simon is now the sole owner and manager of the property's retail and entertainment component. Completed in 2016, The Shops at Brickell City Centre comprises four four-story buildings across three city blocks. Anchored by SAKS Fifth Avenue, additional retail tenants at the center include Apple, Chanel Fragrance & Beauty Boutique, Coach, lululemon, Sephora, Zara and Nike. The property also features a multi-level food hall and entertainment venues including CMX and PuttShack.

â€‰ I reread "The Cloud Sculptors of Coral-D" by J.G. Ballard because my short story reading group is reading The Best Fantasy from The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction. Inclusion in this volume suggests its fantasy. However, it was also included in The Great Science Fiction Series edited by Martin H. Greenberg, Joseph Olander, and Frederik Pohl. The story contains no magic, no dragons or elves, and it's set in our present day, but in a fictional resort called Vermillion Sands. Vermillion Sands feels like a decadent playground for the rich, which also features the many kinds of parasites that live off the wealthy. It's also an artist and expat colony. We don't know its location, but it feels like Palm Springs, California. Many worldly travelers come and go there. "The Cloud Sculptors of Coral-D" was my first introduction to J. G. Ballard back in the 1960s. Other stories from that setting make up the series, collected into Vermillion Sands. "Prima Belladonna" (Science Fantasy, December 1956)     "Venus Smiles" (Science Fantasy, June 1957)    "Studio 5, the Stars" (Science Fantasy, February 1961)    "The Thousand Dreams of Stellavista" (Amazing Stories, March 1962)    "The Singing Statues" (Fantastic Stories, July 1962) (not in original collection)    "The Screen Game" (Fantastic Stories, October 1963)    "Cry Hope, Cry Fury!" (F&SF, October 1967)    "The Cloud-Sculptors of Coral D" (F&SF, December 1967)    "Say Goodbye to the Wind" (Fantastic, August 1970)      When I first read "The Cloud Sculptors of Coral-D" as a teen, it felt very grown-up to me. The characters were the kinds of people I met growing up in Miami, not the typical heroes of science fiction stories I spent so much time reading. It never occurred to me to think of the story as fantasy, but it didn't seem like science fiction either. At the time, I was just discovering British science fiction writers like Brian Aldiss and John Brunner and the New Wave SF. The stories were set in the present or near future and took place on Earth. No rockets or robots. Was this actual science fiction? "The Cloud Sculptors of Coral-D" is about a band of glider pilots who shape clouds with silver iodide. At first, their audience and patrons are people who park their cars along the lagoon road to watch. Eventually, the Garbo-like Leonora Chanel hires them to perform for her party. Sculpting clouds is a neat idea, but far from realistic. Does that make the story science fiction? Ballard does throw in a creature called sand rays, which I suppose are like manta rays that live under the sand instead of the sea. Do they make the story a fantasy? Science fiction has often been the dumping ground for any kind of weird story that can't be classified. The Vermillion Sands stories would have been rejected by mainstream and literary magazines. They fit nicely in The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction. They were also published in the British magazine Science Fantasy and the American Fantastic. Only one was published in a straight-ahead science fiction magazine, Amazing Stories. I doubt John W. Campbell would have accepted them in Astounding or Analog. Nor would he have published them in Unknown. I wonder if Rod Serling would have used "The Cloud Sculptors of Coral-D" for The Twilight Zone? I'm not fond of traditional fantasy, and many of the stories in The Best Fantasy from The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction aren't enjoyable for me to read. But I did enjoy "The Cloud Sculptors of Coral-D." The story has a pleasant, surreal feel. The setting is very close to this world, but just a smidge off. I love the artist colony atmosphere, the hint of decadence, the ever-so-slight sense of unreality. The story combines barnstorming, carny folks, and the ugly rich. I visualize it as a cross between early Faulkner and Fellini. The shortest description would be to say the story has atmosphere. James Wallace Harris, 7/1/25

â€‰ Rihanna made a striking appearance at the Smurfs world premiere in Brussels on June 28, where she revealed her go-to karaoke song by one of R&B's talented newcomers. Dressed in a sheer baby blue Chanel ensemble, a very pregnant Rih shared with Capital FM her current go-to karaoke song â€” naming Mariah The Scientist's â€œBurning Blueâ€ ballad. The 37-year-old singer and business mogul paused for a moment, then smiled as she revealed her pick. â€œOh my gosh, it's, it's, it's â€¦ maybe 'Burning Blue' by Mariah the Scientist,â€ she shared with a laugh. The emotional ballad released in May as the lead single from Mariah's upcoming fourth studio album, and the track has already made waves at No. 38 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. The premiere not only drew attention to Rihanna and her baby bump, but A$AP Rocky as well, who seemingly spilled the beans on their growing family. During an interview with Entertainment Tonight, Rocky hinted at the sex of their unborn child. When asked if the â€œgirlâ€ he had been waiting for had arrived, the Harlemite smiled and gestured to a Smurfette toy, saying, â€œIt is, man, it is.â€ When Rihanna was asked the same question later, she played it coy, teasing, â€œLet's see if it's a Smurfette! I don't know! Could be a Papa Smurf! Who knows!â€ Both are already parents to two sons RZA, 3, and Riot, 1. Rihanna also spoke on whether the baby's name would follow the family tradition and start with an R like her sons RZA and Riot, the â€œLift Me Upâ€ singer confirmed: â€œIt's always going to be an R name â€” that's the one thing me and Rocky don't fight over.â€ Take a look at Rihanna shouting out Mariah The Scientist's â€œBurning Blueâ€ song and speaking on her and A$AP Rocky's third child. Smurfs opens in theaters on July 18.

Selecting the Perfect Fit for Prescription Glasses Prescription glasses are a crucial part of many people's lives. They enhance vision and maximize confidence. However, finding the perfect fit is important to ensuring your glasses operate effectively and comfortably. A proper fit eliminates headaches, fatigue, and slipping. Firstly, consider your facial structure. Different frame shapes flatter different features. An vision specialist can guide you in selecting a design that's appropriate for your unique needs. Next, focus on the bridge. The nose pads should lie comfortably on your nose without creating excessive pressure. The bridge should fit the shape of your nose, while the frame width shouldn't be too wide or too narrow for your face. Finally, ensure that the temples fit well behind your ears without being too tight. You should be able to place your glasses easily for extended periods. â€‰ Lorde dropped her fourth studio album Virgin last Friday (June 27) and headed to Instagram on Monday (June 30) to check in with fans after its release. After asking fans what track(s) were their favorites, the singer shared some facts about the project, including what songs she started and finished first and last, her favorite sound on the album, being forced to cut a song she loves, suffering from insomnia while making it, and the song that "kicked [her] a**." "Hardest song was FD ["Favourite Daughter"], to write, to produce, to sing," Lorde admitted. "Kicked my a**." Now that the album's out in the world, the 28-year-old is focusing on putting together the live show for her "Ultrasound World Tour" that kicks off in September. See her insightful Instagram post and a full list of tour dates below. â€‰ Love, Like That All Mine One night, she crashed into my world and left a stain on my memory that couldn't wipe away. I never saw her again after that night, but after all these years have passed, I still think about her, dream about her. I even remember her scent. Imagine my surprise when she reappeared in my life as if she had never left. Well, that's because subconsciously she hadn't. She doesn't know who I really am. Her being here at this moment could only mean one thing, even with all my secrets, and that was that she was mine. Devin Haven thought that once he'd achieved the highest level of success, he'd feel fulfilled. But success wasn't keeping him warm at night. The one woman who could possibly fill that void was the woman from his past he'd sworn would never be his type. Chanel Declan wasn't the woman everyone thought she was. She'd run from her past life to create a new one time and time again. Returning home to get another fresh start leads her back to her past. But this time, she's determined to make it work. Can two people whose past timelines are so closely intertwined make it through the secrets they wove to reach their present? They buy in game video skins, new makeup products, new shoes, new clothes, and all these little things to achieve that small amount of soothing dopamine their nervous system begs for. But, there's actually catch.

â€‰ @garrytan @Dior @CHANEL @gucci @TiffanyAndCo @elonmusk @beccabloom @JeffBezos These boredom cures only work if you're emotionally weak or poor. Rich people fall for them, too. But it takes more and more and more. Yes, the wealthy are informed by social laws more than the poor, but both are vulnerable.

â€‰ @garrytan @Dior @CHANEL @gucci @TiffanyAndCo @elonmusk @beccabloom @JeffBezos Wealthy people view poor people like another species. Your world view isn't important because you don't understand the experience of wealth. They do think they're superior to poor people. They view poor people like animals. They strip them of humanhood.

â€‰ @garrytan @Dior @CHANEL @gucci @TiffanyAndCo @elonmusk @beccabloom @JeffBezos If you haven't ever experienced large amounts of unearned wealth, or have never been in any wealthy circles, you will reject this idea. This isn't to say that all wealthy people are like this, but to arm you with a reality I know because I experienced it first hand.

â€‰ @garrytan @Dior @CHANEL @gucci @TiffanyAndCo @elonmusk @beccabloom @JeffBezos That said, wealth can get you a lot, but it can't grow back fried dopamine receptors. No amount of money will fix the burnout from chasing endless luxury. This is why wealthy people go to extreme lengths to get this feeling.

â€‰ @garrytan @Dior @CHANEL @gucci @TiffanyAndCo @elonmusk @beccabloom @JeffBezos However, it is important to understand there is insanity that comes with gaining a one time access to a $170 million/yr non earned allowance. I would not change what happened, but to know that freedom is to know suffering. But don't forget, purpose. Above all. Purpose.

â€‰ People-watching is one of my favorite pastimes, especially in Jakarta's melting pots of leisure and business, like Plaza Senayan and Ashta. Fancy people, I say to myself. The bags are mostly the usual high-end suspects: black Chanel flaps, Birkins that might or might not be real, old-time favorite Neverfulls. Predictable. But lately, something has been shifting. Increasingly, I see statement pieces from homegrown designers: Peggy Hartanto's signature heart appliquÃ© on a chic woman. Sapto Djojokartiko's fluid silhouettes and intricate embroidery on almost-sheer fabric. TOTON's soft, floral lace kebaya tops darting between brunches and galas. ArtKea's boxy striped shirts blending in with the city's creative-casual crowd. There are no obvious logos, but you just know these brands cost money. And those who know, know. Homegrown, high-end Jakarta's fashion scene is evolving, and so are its shoppers. This city, where cultures collide and creativity thrives, has become a breeding ground for a new kind of luxuryâ€”local, deeply personal and proudly embraced by its own. Coming to you every other Friday From lifestyle trends to cultural insights, The Weekender brings you quality stories and inspiring narratives to elevate your pop-culture knowledge in niche topics, including arts, well-being, environment, technology and everything in between. For signing up to our newsletter. Please check your email for your newsletter subscription. Take Bogar, 34, a start-up exec with a thing for elevated basics. He often turns to local brands for his rotation, especially those created by friends, like ANW, where he looks for elevated basics that still reflect his personal style, but with a distinct accent or twist. Outside his circle, he is drawn to high-end ready-to-wear labels like Art Kea and Jan Sober. â€œWhy local? Practicality,â€ he shrugs. â€œBecause I'm stingy. I really care about cost per wear. A lot of the foreign stuff wears out too quickly. I just can't justify it.â€ Still, there's more to the shift than economics. In Jakarta, local luxury has become something of a secret handshakeâ€”recognizable only to those in the know. Bogar points to names like Sapto Djojokartiko, which he sees as a new kind of status symbol. â€œIt's not just about the design. It's the identity, the craft, the prestige of being seen at their events. You're part of a coveted circle,â€ he says. Distry, 32, an art professional and former luxury watch insider, agrees. â€œLuxury isn't just about the high price,â€ she tells me. â€œIt's about limited access and ownership. Many people have money, so it's not just about whether you can afford it, but whether you can get it. Rarity and exclusivity are the real markers of luxury.â€ Like Bogar, Distry is a firm believer in local luxury, not out of obligation, but appreciation. â€œI'm not trying to sound nationalistic, but I genuinely feel proud when I wear an Indonesian designer,â€ she says. â€œIt also feels more exclusive than global luxury brands. It's amazing that Indonesia now has its own version of Chanel or HermÃ¨s. In ready-to-wear alone, we have Biyan, TOTON, Sapto Djojokartiko, Peggy Hartanto and more.â€ Their craftsmanship, she insists, is on a whole other level. â€œTOTON is my favoriteâ€”and pricewise, I think it makes the most sense. For me, TOTON is art, while Peggy Hartanto is a well-made, ready-to-wear label. And Biyan? That's still an aspiration, for now.â€ The city in the craft One aspect that sets these brands apart is how they do not just say they come from Jakarta, but the city itself is in the fabric of the work....

Not towards any Turkish people, but towards author of the chanel herself. â€‰ Toronto Blue Jays infielder Vladimir Guerrero Jr.'s wife, Nathalie, often posts clips and videos from their daily lives. Their small family includes their two daughters, Vlaimel & Vlaishel. Nathalie recapped the month of June with a story on her Instagram. The collage of pictures showcased her two children, alongside a selfie and a picture of herself in front of the Chanel store, a pasta-prawn preparation and two luxury bags. Nathalie's Instagram story recapping the month of June. (Source: Instagram @nathaliii30) (110-25-1) (110-25-1) (110-25-1) The adorable pictures with her two daughters featured the elder, Vlaimel, having a bowl of spaghetti, while Vlaishel could be seen posing with the Cleveland Guardians mascot during the Blue Jays' visit. While her two daughters were the main focus, Nathalie's 'Chanel' look had a chic feel to it. She could be seen carrying a big bag after her shopping at the store. In a previous Instagram post, she had shared snaps from her day out. Nathalie and Vladimir met online in 2018. The two were together before finally tying the knot in a private ceremony in 2023. Apart from being his biggest supporter at Blue Jays' games, Nathalie also runs the Vladimir Guerrero Jr. Foundation that works in sectors related to sports, education and environment, empowering the youth. Nathalie goes full marketing mode asking fans to vote Vladimir Guerrero Jr. as All-Star As a proud partner, Nathalie has been actively campaigning for fans to vote for All-Star finalist Vladimir Guerrero Jr. alongside catcher Alejandro Kirk. The two Blue Jays players are the only ones to be named the finalists after the first round of All-Star voting. Nathalie has been posting clips and fan interactions related to the All-Star voting on her Instagram stories. Nathalie's Instagram stories asking fans to make Guerrero Jr. an All-Star (Source: Instagram @nathaliii30) Vladimir Guerrero Jr. is up against Paul Goldschmidt of the New York Yankees. Both players have had similar stats so far in the first half of the season. The Blue Jays first baseman is hitting at .278 with 44 RBIs, 12 home runs and .827 OPS, while Goldschmidt is at a .284 pace with 32 RBIs, 11 home runs and .772 OPS. After the first day of voting, the Blue Jays superstar was still in the lead. Feedback Why did you not like this content? Cancel Submit Was this article helpful? â€‰ A Glimpse into Family Life In the whirlwind of a Major League Baseball season, Toronto Blue Jays infielder Vladimir Guerrero Jr. finds solace in the warmth of family. His wife, Nathalie Guerrero, frequently offers fans a window into their everyday lives through her engaging social media presence. Family Moments Captured Nathalie's recent Instagram story serves as a heartfelt recap of June, highlighting the joys and tender moments shared with their two daughters, Vlaimel and Vlaishel. The story is not just a collection of images; it is a narrative woven with love and familial bonds. Each clip and video reveals the laughter and playfulness that define their small family unit, showcasing the essence of their life together away from the baseball diamond. A Blend of Everyday Life and Luxury The collage features a variety of snapshots, from lighthearted family moments to glimpses of Nathalie's personal interests. A selfie of Nathalie radiates joy, while another image captures her standing in front of a Chanel store, hinting at her appreciation for fashion. The culinary highlight of the monthâ€”a preparation of pasta with prawnsâ€”adds a touch of domesticity, illustrating the balance between her family life and personal passions. Celebrating Life's Simple Pleasures Amidst the luxury of designer bags and the allure of fashion, Nathalie's story emphasizes the importance of family and the simple pleasures that come with it. The essence of her recap is not merely about material possessions but rather the cherished memories created with her daughters and husband. It's a reminder that even in the high-stakes world of professional sports, the heart of a family remains grounded in love and shared experiences. Through her thoughtful storytelling, Nathalie Guerrero not only highlights the joys of motherhood but also paints a vivid picture of a family thriving together, navigating the complexities of life with grace and affection. The content appear first in M Sports .

â€‰ Toronto Blue Jays infielder Vladimir Guerrero Jr.'s wife, Nathalie, often posts clips and videos from their daily lives. Their small family includes their two daughters, Vlaimel & Vlaishel. Nathalie recapped the month of June with a story on her Instagram. The collage of pictures showcased her two children, alongside a selfie and a picture of herself in front of the Chanel store, a pasta-prawn preparation and two luxury bags. The adorable pictures with her two daughters featured the elder, Vlaimel, having a bowl of spaghetti, while Vlaishel could be seen posing with the Cleveland Guardians mascot during the Blue Jays' visit. While her two daughters were the main focus, Nathalie's 'Chanel' look had a chic feel to it. She could be seen carrying a big bag after her shopping at the store. In a previous Instagram post, she had shared snaps from her day out. Nathalie and Vladimir met online in 2018. The two were together before finally tying the knot in a private ceremony in 2023. Apart from being his biggest supporter at Blue Jays' games, Nathalie also runs the Vladimir Guerrero Jr. Foundation that works in sectors related to sports, education and environment, empowering the youth. As a proud partner, Nathalie has been actively campaigning for fans to vote for All-Star finalist Vladimir Guerrero Jr. alongside catcher Alejandro Kirk. The two Blue Jays players are the only ones to be named the finalists after the first round of All-Star voting. Nathalie has been posting clips and fan interactions related to the All-Star voting on her Instagram stories. Vladimir Guerrero Jr. is up against Paul Goldschmidt of the New York Yankees. Both players have had similar stats so far in the first half of the season. The Blue Jays first baseman is hitting at .278 with 44 RBIs, 12 home runs and .827 OPS, while Goldschmidt is at a .284 pace with 32 RBIs, 11 home runs and .772 OPS. After the first day of voting, the Blue Jays superstar was still in the lead.

â€‰ Some Lorde fans who purchased a transparent CD copy of her new album, Virgin, are reporting issues with getting it to play. According to Reddit discussions and a viral TikTok video, the disc isn't being recognized by certain players, including some car stereos, traditional systems, and boomboxes. The playback issue could be caused by the clear disc's manufacturing process, which uses a different kind of reflective layer than the typical aluminum in a standard CD. This variation can cause the lasers in some players to fail to read the disc's data properly. Some Redditors have shared that they were able to play their transparent Virgin CD by switching from a player with a clear lid to a tray-loading model. However, this solution has not worked for everyone, and playback results seem to vary by user and device. Separately, fans have also noted that this physical CD release is a marked departure from Lorde's previous album, Solar Power, for which she created â€œan environmentally kind, forward-thinking alternative to the CD.â€ In other Lorde news, the Kiwi singer will kick off the North American leg of her â€œUltrasoundâ€ tour in September, which will be followed by dates in the UK and Europe. See the full list of dates below, and get tickets here. Known for her engaging posts, Nathalie offers followers a window into her world, where family moments intertwine with elements of luxury. Through her Instagram recap, Nathalie Guerrero not only celebrates the joys of motherhood but also shares the beauty of balancing family and personal interests, creating a relatable narrative that resonates with her audience. â€‰ Sofia Coppola made a film about Marie Antoinetteâ€”but maybe next, she'll consider Empress EugÃ©nie. Biarritz, the seaside town founded by EugÃ©nie de Montijo, is where Coppola came to celebrate the 25th anniversary of her film The Virgin Suicides as part of the Nouvelles Vagues Festival. Actors, directors, and festivalgoers of all ages gathered at Le Royal, Biarritz's Art Deco cinema, to see and revisit Coppola's exquisitely soaring, tragic film about the five Lisbon sisters, which launched her career in the late 1990s. Coppola's debut film immediately positioned her as one of the most singular and intimate filmmakers of her generation. Its anniversary was an opportunity to talk about the making of the film, its core femininityâ€”linked, she says, to the fact that Coppola grew up mostly around boysâ€”her appreciation for Jane Campion, and even Claude Pinoteau's La Boum, which Coppola saw years after making this film. At the end of the talk, Coppola sat down for an exclusive interview before beginning her summer in France. On July 1, she'll be in Paris for a book signing at 7L, Karl Lagerfeld 's studio-library turned Chanel cultural hub. The following day, she will be in the Cour CarrÃ©e du Louvre for a screening as part of the CinÃ©ma Paradiso program. Coppola is also working on the artistic direction of the Bal du MusÃ©e des Arts DÃ©coratifs, one of the most eagerly awaited events of Haute Couture Week. Vanity Fair: How does it feel to see Virgin Suicides again? Sofia Coppola: I'm so glad. I saw it recently for the first time in a long time, so I'm glad it holds up. How does the younger generationâ€”those born when you were making the film, or just afterâ€” perceive it? It's hard for me to say; you have to ask a young person. The time of daydreaming and becoming who you are through being in your roomâ€”I wonder nowadays how young people have that time. I'm sure there's some nostalgia, because there's a lot of stress and pressure with having a phone and social media all the time. I know my younger daughter was like, â€œOh, I wish I was around in the '90s.â€ I think it feels like a burden in some ways. Was it a time you loved? I'm just glad I was young then. You love memorabilia, collections, and archives. Have you ever thought of making a documentary about your mother? I am working on preserving some of her footage that hasn't been seen yet. So I'm working on preserving her archive. She wrote a book that we're working on getting published, and now I'm working on getting her last work out. In this work, there's the idea of transmission toward a new generation, which is also at the heart of the Nouvelles Vagues Festival, where you've just spoken. I thought it was so nice that the focus of this festival is on young filmmakers and young voices. I'm happy to show my first film here, and that it still connects with young people. I want to share my work, and hope to be encouraging if I can. Do you still have a special connection with adolescence? Yeah, I still feel connected to that side. But at this point in my life, I'm also interested in themes of older people. It's so different being a teenager today, but I still have a lot of respect for people that age because it is such a sensitive time. And when I was growing up, the movies that were made for teenagers weren't made with respect to artfulness or whatever. But yeah, I am glad to not be that age. I'm glad to be my age. Does Virgin Suicides occupy a special place in your heart? Yeah. It's my first film. I have a lot of really nice memories. It's also where I met Kirsten Dunst, and we formed our friendship. She's a close collaborator of mine, in my work and also my life. A lot of the people that worked on it, I'm still connected with. But I have a really nice memory of that summer in Toronto, making a low-budget movie and the feeling of everyone helping me. Ed Lachman, the cinematographer, really helped me learn how to develop my language on film. And I didn't know I wanted to be a director until [I read] that book. Is the first film always the most difficult? I think they're always difficult. It was hard to get it madeâ€”but when you're young, you're naive, and you don't realize how hard things are. You have a courage that helps you; when you're older, you know what it's going to take....

â€‰ "I never forget them, I cannot believe it. I was scrubbing my face with a washcloth last night," the former "Scream Queens" star tells me with a Chanel Oberlin-worthy eye roll as we look out at the ocean from our private cabana at the Dreams Bahia Mita Surf & Spa Resort. In March 2025, I traveled to Mexico with a small group of journalists to experience Pages in Paradise, a travel program developed by Apple Vacations, Penguin Random House, and Roberts' own Belletrist book club to hook up participating resorts with curated libraries, as well as book-themed cocktail hours based on Belletrist's book of the month. "Every time I come to Mexico, all I want to do is read by a pool and get off my phone," the actor tells me during a one-on-one chat. "I always remember the books that I found on vacation, so I love that this library is gonna create lasting memories. There's something really analog and kismet and fun about just grabbing a book off a shelf that speaks to you." So far, all is going according to Roberts's plan, with the exception of her missing makeup wipes. It's the second day of our trip and the two of us are currently sitting by a private pool that's just a short walk away from the Belletrist-approved library nestled inside the all-inclusive resort's 24-hour cafÃ© and gelato bar. Once she finishes our chat and an obligatory photoshoot, Roberts plans to run straight into the ocean - and she probably won't be washing her hair for the rest of the trip. "I try not to wash my hair on vacation. I put my hair into braids and jump in the ocean," she says. "That's what I do instead of shampoo and conditioner." Roberts is unwilling to risk mixing hotel products with her freshly dyed "sunrise red" hair. "I've washed my hair when I've just dyed it and it's turned a crazy color," she says. "When I have blond hair it's turned yellow, and when I've had red hair it washes it all out. So I get so scared to really give my hair a real wash." Roberts tells me she's gone as long as five days without washing her hair on a trip. "I try to get a blowout the day before I leave for vacation, and then I will ride that blowout into the dry-shampoo end." When it comes to dry shampoo, Roberts trusts Oribe Gold Lust Dry Shampoo ($52) and R+Co Death Valley Dry Shampoo ($37). Both offer travel sizes. "I don't care, I just dry-shampoo and jump in the ocean," she reiterates. "I have no shame about it . . . Nothing looks better than saltwater hair." The rest of Roberts's travel makeup routine is similarly low maintenance. "When I'm on vacation, I just do a little concealer, a little waterproof mascara, and I'm good to go," she says, recommending the Kiko Milano Maxi Mod Mascara ($18). "And then I love a little berry lip stain that also doubles as a cheek tint." Roberts has served as a Kiko ambassador since May 2024 and swears by its "amazing" sheet masks, saying, "I feel like those are a must, and those can go in the carry-on." After spending most of our time discussing makeup and books - Roberts suggests I pick up "The Husbands" by Holly Gramazio, which I devoured in three days and absolutely did not take home in my carry-on - I can't help but point out it feels like we've been sucked into a secret fourth season of "The White Lotus," a prospect Roberts would very much like to be a part of. "I'm unwell from 'The White Lotus,'" she says. "I want to be on next season, but that's such a dumb thing to say because who doesn't?" Even so, Roberts would love to play the show's next murder victim, adding, "I'll just be the body." "The White Lotus" creator Mike White could probably come up with a better part for Roberts than that, given her extensive rÃ©sumÃ© of TV and film roles she's been building since the age of nine. At this very moment, she looks poised to portray a vacationing Hollywood starlet in her white oval sunglasses, red cardigan, and adorable white polka-dot shorts that she's excited to exchange for a swimsuit. Of course, Roberts is plenty busy at the moment, between parenting her four-year-old son, Rhodes; starring in the upcoming rom-com "Marriage Material"; and producing multiple projects under Belletrist Productions, including the popular Hulu series "Tell Me Lies," which has been renewed for a third season. You'll have to forgive her for ever skipping the first season of something to keep up with the discourse. "I'm always late to the party," she says. "I always read and watch things after everyone's already talked about it, and then everyone's like, 'Shut up, we've already talked about it.' So I was late to 'The White Lotus' and now I'm totally addicted." Roberts is, however, good at keeping up with her favorite reality TV shows. "I was first to see Mike White on 'Survivor,' and fell in love with him there," she says of the HBO writer's turn on the long-running adventure series. "I think I would do well on 'Survivor,' because I do well under pressure." Though Roberts wouldn't share her strategy in case the theoretical becomes reality, she says attending an "all-girls summer camp in the middle of nowhere" each summer was her training ground. "That is survivor," she says. "My girlies who went to summer camp - real summer camp, not bougie summer camp - we're ruthless." She adds, "I don't need as many glamorous things as I think people think." Read More Details Finally We wish PressBee provided you with enough information of ( ) Also on site

â€‰ Gabe Ginsberg Lindsay Lohan has had a busy few years back in the spotlight after nearly a decade-long break from acting. Now, following a Netflix contract that included three romantic comedies and a reunion with Jamie Lee Curtis for a Freaky Friday sequel (out in August), it seems the star is taking a well-deserved vacation. (They didn't call it a Lohanaissance for nothing!) The actor, who is celebrating her 39th birthday today (HBD, LiLo!) recently shared images from her very own Roman Holiday with her husband, Bader Shammas, and her toddler son Luai, who was born in 2023. In the of images posted to Instagram, the Freakier Friday star looks radiant walking around the Italian city with her family. She even gave fans a rare glimpse at Luai, who's pictured toddling around a lush garden and being toted around on his mother's hip. Don't get me wrong, Luai is adorable, but what really struck me about this particular photo dump is Lohan's vacation wardrobeâ€”specifically her lace-on-lace layering. The Mean Girls actor wore tea-length white lace slip dress which she layered under Doen's Sohana lace button-up dress, giving an airy, â€œI just threw this onâ€ kind of vibe that's exactly how I'm trying to dress on vacation. Will I be staying at what is probably a five-star resort in Rome? No. Can I aspire to dress like someone who does? Yes, duh. Lohan wore a pair of oversize sunglasses (you can take the girl out of the 2000s, but you can't take the 2000s out of the girl) and a wide-brimmed sunhat, though I have to imagine that her choice in accessories had more to do with going incognito than making a fashion statement. That, and sun protection. A pair of mesh ballet flats with a single buckle (they look a lot like AlaÃ¯a's Mary Jane flats, which have been knocked off ad nauseum) added a modern element to the whole Dolce Vita vibe, and also matched her quilted black Chanel bag. Then there're her all-white looks, which epitomize that effortless â€œit's too hot for anything elseâ€ Mediterranean style mantra. Both dresses are slightly sheer, but feature an opaque layer. The second look has a bit of lace trim at the hem, not unlike Kate Middleton's and Jennifer Lawrence's recent white skirts. (Wee-woo trend alert.) Of course every outfit is instantly upgraded when you dress your baby to match, as Lohan did. With the Freakier Friday premiere approaching quickly on August 8, we assume we're about to see a lot more of LiLo's street style, as well as some red carpet moments. Bellisima! â€‰ They say, fashion comes its fair share of faux pas and flair! While luxurious wardrobes and style statements speak for the 'flair' part, the faux pas part most certainly includes the mispronunciations of the well-known fashion brands (despite those being extremely famous). And while these mishaps are quite clichÃ©, they're not chic at all. Because let's be honest â€“ in the world of fashion, half the battle is looking the part, and the rest of it is acing the etiquette (which includes the correct pronunciation of popular fashion brands). Mispronouncing a luxury label can cost you credibility faster than you can say â€œCÃ©line.â€ Lucky for you, we've done the hard work. From Parisian labels to Italian icons and streetwear staples, this guide is sprinkled with phonetic line-drawing, brand backstories, and quirky insider tips to help you glide through any style conversation with ease. So, say goodbye to awkward pauses and hello to stylish confidence â€“ let's break it down, brand by brand. French elegance: Subtle, chic, and tricky HermÃ¨s â€“ Not â€œHer-meez,â€ but gentle vowel start, silent 'H' and 's': â€œairâ€‘MEZâ€ or â€œerâ€‘MEZâ€, not â€œherâ€‘meez.â€ Givenchy â€“ Often butchered as â€œGahâ€‘vinâ€‘chee.â€ The correct French flourish? â€œzheeâ€‘VOHNâ€‘sheeâ€, with soft 'G', nasal 'on', and a gentle final â€œâ€‘shee.â€ Chanel â€“ Forget â€œShanâ€‘elle.â€ The proper style? â€œSHUHâ€‘nel.â€ Chic, crisp, simple, and oh-soâ€‘Parisian. Balmain â€“ Yes, it's not â€œBALâ€‘mayn.â€ Roll it out like â€œbalâ€‘MAHâ€, trailing off the 'n' softly for that French flair. Yves Saint Laurent â€“ Drop those hard Ts! The smooth version: â€œEEV sanâ€‘lohâ€‘rah(n)â€, a lovers' lane nasal finish. Christian Louboutin â€“ Strut smoothly: â€œkrisâ€‘teeâ€‘ahn looâ€‘booâ€‘TAHNâ€, not â€œtin.â€ Christian Lacroix â€“ â€œLA-kwa.â€ So â€œkrisâ€‘teeâ€‘ahn luhâ€‘kwaâ€, rolling that lâ€“r combo beautifully. Comme des GarÃ§ons â€“ Play it subtly: â€œcombâ€‘DAY garâ€‘SONâ€, letting the 's' fade, nasal 'on' intact. Italian icons: Bold, bright, and vowely Gucci â€“ It's â€œGOOâ€‘cheeâ€, emphasis on the first syllable, never â€œGooâ€‘kee.â€ Versace â€“ Despite the trendy slip, it's properly â€œverâ€‘SAHâ€‘cheh.â€ Donatella herself has piped up to confirm it. Prada â€“ Simple and sweet: â€œPRAHâ€‘dahâ€, sturdy first syllable, light second. Moschino â€“ The fun-filled style comes through in â€œmosâ€‘KEYâ€‘noâ€, not â€œmosâ€‘cheeâ€‘no.â€ Bottega Veneta â€“ Soft and elegant: â€œbohâ€‘TEHâ€‘gah vehâ€‘NEHâ€‘taâ€, a solid roll in every segment. Dolce & Gabbana â€“ Smooth Italian gloss: â€œDOLâ€‘chay eh gaâ€‘BANâ€‘ehâ€, not â€œGabâ€‘anna.â€ Spanish flair and subtle sound Balenciaga â€“ Spanish royalty. Break it into â€œbahâ€‘LENâ€‘seeâ€‘AHâ€‘gah,â€ emphasizing the â€œAHâ€ and smoothing past the â€œcia.â€ Loewe â€“ Spanish elegance meets German twist: say â€œloâ€‘WEHâ€‘vayâ€, not â€œlowâ€‘eeve.â€ Athleisure staples Adidas â€“ A German classic: â€œAHâ€‘deeâ€‘dahsâ€, emphasis on the first syllable, founder Adi Dassler's namesake. Nike â€“ Named after the Greek goddess, it's â€œNYâ€‘keeâ€, not â€œNighk.â€ Porsche â€“ Elegant German soap-opera: â€œPORâ€‘shuhâ€, with a soft â€œâ€‘uhâ€ ending. Cross-cultural gems Bvlgari (Latin-script brand) â€“ Pronounce â€œBOOLâ€‘gahâ€‘ree,â€ highlighting the â€œuâ€ after â€œB.â€ Cartier â€“ Soft, refined: â€œkarâ€‘teeâ€‘AYâ€, not â€œCarâ€‘teeâ€‘er.â€ Jacquemus â€“ From French fashion forward: â€œZHAKâ€‘moose.â€ Celine â€“ A blend of syllables: â€œsehâ€‘LEEN,â€ soft start, piercing end. Nailing the correct pronunciation of a fashion might seem like a superficial conquest â€“ but it isn't just about speaking the name; it's about stepping into the essence of each brand. Elevating your fashion conversations goes beyond clothes â€“ it's about knowing the names and pronouncing them with confidence, creativity, and cultural awareness. From the sonorous softness of French designers to the vibrant clarity of Italian labels, each namescape tells a story â€“ learn the sound, share the style. With this guide, you're not just knocking it out of the vocabulary park; you're stepping onto the stylistic stage with poise and pizzazz....

â€‰ The Starboard Group is seizing the moment. With the cruise industry experiencing a sustained rebound post-COVID-19, the Starboard Group, operator of boutiques aboard cruise liners and super yachts, has been rolling out new product initiatives and services ranging from personalizing jewelry and ear piercings, to tequila developed with the Invicta Watch Group. More from WWD Starboard also plans to launch a natural diamond program this fall, details of which will be revealed later this summer. â€œCruising has never been more popular,â€ said Caryl Capeci, Starboard's senior vice president of fine jewelry and Swiss watches. â€œThere was a stoppage of the cruise ships during COVID-19, and then it all came back. We've seen not only the number of passengers but also retail sales on cruise ships grow and grow and grow. And in June, we had record high sales volume.â€ During an interview Tuesday, Capeci cited statistics indicating the cruise industry is forecast to carryÂ 37 million passengers in 2025, up from approximately 34.6 million last year, with expectations to reachÂ 42 million by 2028. So an opportunity to capture greater wallet share from more passengers on board cruise ships exists. Last year, Starboard cruise line shops generated an estimated $800 million to under $1 billion, according to sources. Capeci declined to confirm the figure though she characterized Starboard's 2024 volume as in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Starboard works with 14 cruise lines, including Royal Caribbean, Virgin Voyages and Carnival Cruise Line, and more than 95 different cruise ships selling everything from beauty, fragrance and liquor to apparel, Swiss watches and fine and fashion jewelry. Through its cruise and luxury division, Starboard operates single-brand shops, as well as multibrand shops on ships. Among the brand shops are Omega, Brietling, Tag Heuer, Bulgari, Hublot, Cartier, IWC, Panerai, Piaget, Messika, Swarovski and Pandora. Also sold are beauty brands such as Dior, Chanel, Lancome, Clinique, EstÃ©e Lauder, Clarins and La Mer. Shops range from 100 to 750 square feet. The merchandise in the Starboard shops is duty free and tax free. Among the initiatives Capeci cited: Boutiques for Cartier, IWC Schaffhausen and Piaget aboard Luminara, the newest super yacht in The Ritz-Carlton Yacht Collection, which was launched this week. The boutiques offer Swiss timepieces, fine jewelry and accessories, as well as private viewings, in-suite appointments and sessions with brand ambassadors to explore the craftsmanship and heritage of the brands. Also on offer are designer jewelry, luxury accessories and resortwear â€” from vintage HermÃ¨s bags and Stella McCartney handbags to fine jewelry by Ileana Makri, Lauren Rubinski and Sydney Evan. Ear piercingÂ in partnership with Inverness, the ear piercing system, has been set up on 33 ships across multiple cruise lines in the past couple of months. Starboard says â€œexpertly trained retail team membersâ€ administer the piercings. The debut of Invicta Tequila is for sale exclusively aboard 26 cruise ships worldwide, produced for the Invicta Watch Group by Mexico's Casa Maestri Distillery. Onboard tastings and personalized activations are offered. Engraving stations for personalizing jewelry are being set up. Mail-order services for most of the jewelry and watch brands sold at Starboard shops began rolling out in mid-May. Passengers can view digital catalogues on iPads to select styles, ring sizes or colors that not on the ship and have them shipped home. Rolling out financing through FlexPay with interest free, interest bearing and buy now, pay later options. The rollout began four months ago on Carnival and is being extended to all Starboard cruise line partners. â€œMost guests on cruises are celebrating something with their loved ones, whether it's a birthday, an anniversary or a family milestone so they come with a desire to splurge, to discover new brands and items connected to the destination they're traveling to,â€ Capeci said. â€œBut most importantly, they want to mark the time with something meaningful, and we all know that jewelry and timepieces are among the most special ways to mark an event or a vacation, and remember time spent together with loved ones. For those reasons, most voyages we sell on do quite a nice business in fine jewelry. Fine jewelry and watches are probably 40 percent or more of our total sales. It's very significant.â€ Sales at Starboard's cruise line boutiques are selling at much higher rate than pre-COVID-19, globally, with the exception of China, Capeci said. â€œPre-COVID, we did a significant business on ships sailing out of Shanghai and mainland China. That market has not returned. â€œThe largest region in terms of retail value and sales is the Caribbean by far because of the sheer number of passengers that sail in the Caribbean and the size of the ships,â€ Capeci said. Cruises in Alaska and the Mediterranean, particularly summertime, also generate â€œvery significantâ€ business. Asked what's selling best, Capeci said: â€œDiamonds are huge. Yellow gold is huge. Materials that are connected to the destinations they travel to are very important. So if they're going to Australia, they want opals. If they're going to South America, they want green emeralds. The destination they're traveling to and the jewelry that we're offering are always connected. You could buy emeralds at home, but it's not as meaningful as it is when you just visited that location of their origin.â€ The Invicta brand, founded in La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland, in 1837, â€œis one of our most successful and longest running partners for watches,â€ Capeci said. â€œThey're moving into more lifestyle-driven programs....

â€‰ fell to his knees, planted his forearms on the black leather defence chair and started to pray. With his head bowed, revealing the shock of hair which had turned white during his 10-month stay in federal prison, the music mogul celebrated what was . Moments later he stood up from the royal blue and gold carpet in courtroom 26A and began to clap. His mother and six of his seven children, who for eight weeks have dutifully crammed into the wooden pews just feet away from Combs, erupted into applause and cheers, with some wiping tears from their eyes. Combs had been convicted of two of five federal sex crimes. But it was his that sparked an uproar of jubilation. Had Combs been convicted of sex trafficking his former girlfriends, which included the R&B singer Cassie Ventura, or racketeering conspiracy, he could have faced life in prison. Now he will likely spend a minimal time behind bars before returning to his glittering life of luxury and excess. The odds had appeared to be stacked against. Indeed, the majority of federal cases end in conviction. And this showbiz trial featured graphic videos of days-long â€œfreak offsâ€, drug-fuelled parties in which his former partners would have sex with male escorts while he watched. But the prosecution appeared to bite off more than it could chew with a complicated racketeering crime that was usually used to prosecute mob bosses. When this trial started nearly two months ago, defence lawyer Teny Geragos made an extraordinary admission in her opening statement: Combs was a domestic abuser with a vicious temper. The 55-year-old's assault of Ventura at the InterContinental hotel in Los Angeles, caught on CCTV, was â€œindefensible, horrible, dehumanising and violentâ€, she said. â€œBut it is not evidence of sex traffickingâ€, she added, â€œIt is evidence of domestic violence.â€ It was a bold and unconventional legal strategy, painting her client as a domestic abuser from the outset. But it began the work of disentangling him from the most serious charges. Much of the evidence against Combs was simply proof of a lurid, â€œswinger's lifestyleâ€, said Marc Agnifilo, the mogul's attorney, who is also representing Luigi Mangione and previously defended convicted fraudster Martin Shrekli. After jurors were shown pictures of , used in Combs's sex parties, Mr Agnifilo let off a sarcastic â€œWhoo!â€ , pointing out that the substances are not illegal. â€œThank God for the Special Response team,â€ he said, of the agents who raided Combs's homes in Miami Beach and Los Angeles. â€œThey found the Astroglide, they found the baby oil!â€ The prosecution had attempted to prove that Combs compelled his girlfriends to take part in the orgies with threats of violence, financial manipulation and even kidnapping. But time and again Mr Agnifilo said the women had the chance to leave. â€œNo one's forcing her to do this,â€ he said of Ventura. â€œShe's a woman who actually likes sex â€“ good for her.â€ He was more scathing about â€œJaneâ€, who alleged the threat to cut-off her $10,000 a month rent left her without any choice. In text messages shared with the jury, Jane wrote to Combs that their relationship had opened a â€œPandora's boxâ€. â€œIt's hurting me bc I'm so much more than being loved in the dark in hotel rooms, doing things that make me feel disgusted w myself,â€ she wrote. â€œI'm confusing your lust for me as real loveâ€¦. I don't want to fell obligated to perform these nights w you in fear of losing the roof over my head.â€ Under the terms of a â€œlove contractâ€ she signed with Combs, he agreed to pay her rent for two years â€“ and is currently still doing so, Mr Agnifilo pointed out. â€œI hope she's having a nice day,â€ he said. â€œIn a house he's paying for.â€ â€œThe thrust of the prosecution's case was focused solely on two alleged victims, Cassie and Jane, with whom Sean Combs had long-term relationships,â€ said Tony Buzbee, a lawyer who is representing some of Combs's further alleged victims in a string of civil suits. â€œPerhaps because of the nature of his relationship with those women and the length of those two relationships, I think the jury struggled with the difficult issue of consent and more broadly whether Mr Combs's conduct appropriately fit within the RICO [racketeering] statute.â€ During his rambunctious, four-hour long closing argument, Mr Agnifilo saved particular ridicule for the racketeering charge. â€œAre you kidding me?â€ he said, arguing the jury had been presented with â€œtwo trialsâ€ over the seven-week case, one involving the actual evidence and the other a â€œbadly, badly exaggerated story.â€ In order to prove a racketeering conspiracy, prosecutors had to show that he had agreed to commit at least two crimes with knowing co-conspirators. They argued that he co-opted loyal employees, including his chief of staff, Kristina Khorram, into a variety of criminal acts. But although the names of Combs's alleged accomplices came up again and again in court, the prosecution did not subpoena them, which may have confused the jury. Where are these â€œco-conspiratorsâ€, Mr Agnifilo asked? Only his client had been indicted with any crimes, and no witnesses testified to being part of a racketeering enterprise. Speaking forcefully and pacing across the court room, the attorney dwelled at length on the allegation that Combs had roped his staff into criminal acts against Kid Cudi, a Grammy-winning rapper with whom Ventura had a brief romantic relationship in 2011. There was no evidence, Mr Agnifilo said, that Combs had anything to do with a Molotov cocktail that was placed inside Kid Cudi's Porsche in 2012. Ventura testified that he had vowed to blow up the vehicle in the rapper's driveway â€“ but doing so was â€œcowardlyâ€ and â€œnot in Combs's style,â€ Mr Agnifilo said. Yes, Combs did break into the rapper's house the year before, but that was merely trespassing â€“ not an offence included in the racketeering charge. Michael Bachner, a New York-based criminal defence lawyer and former District Attorney, told The Telegraph that proving racketeering was always going to be an uphill challenge. â€œThere was evidence of people helping him, but I think it was still a stretch for them to prove that this was part of some concerted conspiracy to do it as opposed to just telling people what to do.â€...

â€‰ Something new today, starting withÂ Catastrophe - Survival Earth. Tony Robinson tells us about various global catastrophes which have often killed off the vast majority of life on Earth. Stephen Oppenheimer has a cool job title - Archaeo-Geneticist. He suggests that a super-volcano might have reduced the population of India to about 600 people. John Power has a cool job title (Volcanologist) as well as a cool name. Robert B Smith studies the Yellowstone caldera. Bill McGuire explains how Sulphur Dioxide is one of the deadly features of large volcanic eruptions. Prof. Ken Tankersley talks about the event that caused a mass extinction of "mega mammals" during the Clovis period. A layer of iron-heavy rock suggests an asteroid strike. Prof. Peter Schultz does experiments shooting heavy objects into a base of sand to test whether glaciers might have protected the Earth's surface, and preventing an asteroid strike forming a large, easily recognised crater. Ed Beshore looks for Near Earth Objects that might cause a catastrophic impact. Here's the whole programme. https://youtu.be/9ggh2iHIneM?si=rNBJPvyfhcgTYiuW  Media Centre Description: Tony Robinson investigates the theory that natural disasters and catastrophes have shaped evolution and enabled human life to flourish. An examination of the key events of the past 75,000 years, including the ice age and an asteroid strike in North America, and a look at the potential catastrophes that lie in wait. Recorded from Channel 4+1 on Monday 22nd December 2008 21:58  The last recording today is the first episode in a three part series of ghost stories for Christmas,Â Crooked House - The Wainscoting. A man brings an old door knocker to an antiques expert, and hears some ghost stories about the house it came from. Lee Ingleby plays the man, Ben. Mark Gatiss, who also wrote this, plays the "Curator". The first story concerns a Mr Joseph Bloxham, a man who has recently bought the house in question, Geap Manor and is having it modernised. He's also recently been involved in a financial "bubble", making money himself, but having seen many people lose everything when the scheme collapsed. He's played by Philip Jackson. Julian Rhind-Tutt plays his friend, Noakes, who takes him to task for his part of a scheme that led to at least one man going to debtor's prison. Andy Nyman plays his other friend Duncalfe. Bloxham is slightly annoyed that his workman who are modernising the house aren't going to be finished when they said they would. Mr Coil tells him "I can only apologise, Mr Bloxham. But real craftsmanship cannot be rushed, sir. You wouldn't want that, would you?" "No, no, of course not." "I mean, you could get in any nickninnie to take on a job like this, but you'd regret it." "Yes, yes." "Well, you have my absolute assurance that my men and me will have quit the place by the end of October." "You swear it?" "Give or take." Coil shows him the new wainscoting he's put in, with the very finest timber, as requested. Bloxham asks about some staining on the wood. "And of course, the wainscoting will soon be painted, will it not? A nice sage green. Look lovely in here, Mr Bloxham. I like a green." Some time later, Bloxham is accosted by Mrs Glanville, wife of a man who was thrown in prison for debts after the collapse of Bloxham's scheme. "My husband, sir, blew his brains out last evening." "What?" "He procured a pistol. How I know not. Then he wrote me a short farewell. And then he took his own life." "My deepest sympathies, madam." "My own dear Harry. A fine man, Joseph Bloxham. A kind man....

â€‰ Chanel's celebrated J12 watch is commemorating a quarter-century of impact with a bold step in materials science and a captivating new colorway. Unveiled at Watches and Wonders 2025, the latest iteration of the J12, featuring a case crafted entirely from lab-grown sapphire, underscores Chanel's ongoing commitment to both aesthetic innovation and technical mastery. The luxury watch market, valued at approximately $60 billion globally in 2024, continues to see demand for iconic designs and cutting-edge materials, positioning the J12's anniversary release as a significant event. The J12's Enduring Legacy: From Sailing Inspiration to Modern Icon Launched in the year 2000, the J12 rapidly ascended to prominence as a symbol of contemporary sophistication and daring design. Its fluid, aerodynamic silhouette, initially drawing inspiration from the sleek hulls of America's Cup racing yachts â€“ rather than traditional watch design cues â€“ immediately distinguished it. The early adoption of advanced materials, notably ceramic, further cemented its status as a disruptor in the world of horology.The J12 wasn't merely a timepiece; it was a statement. A New Dimension of Luxury: Introducing the J12 Bleu Chanel's latest evolution of the J12 introduces a groundbreaking element: a case constructed entirely from lab-grown sapphire. this marks a pivotal moment for the model, pushing the boundaries of what's achievable in watch case construction. Sapphire, renowned for its exceptional hardness â€“ second only to diamond â€“ provides unparalleled scratch resistance and a unique visual depth. The deep, intense blue hue is not simply a color request, but an inherent property of the sapphire itself. As Arnaud Chastaingt, Director of Chanel Watchmaking, explains, the creative process behind achieving this unique blue shade, highlighting the technical challenges and artistic vision involved. This isn't just about aesthetics; it's about mastering a complex material. The Philosophy of Creation: Authorship and Articulation in Design Innovation as a Constant: The J12's Trajectory The J12's journey over the past 25 years has been defined by a relentless pursuit of innovation. From its initial embrace of ceramic â€“ a material previously uncommon in high-end watchmaking â€“ to its current exploration of lab-grown sapphire, the watch has consistently challenged conventions. Consider the parallel with the automotive industry, where brands like Porsche continually refine their iconic 911 model with new technologies and materials while preserving its core identity. The J12 follows a similar path, evolving without losing sight of its original spirit. â€œThe J12's 25th anniversary is a testament to its enduring legacy. From its pioneering use of ceramic to its latest embrace of lab-grown sapphire, the watch continues to represent Chanel's dedication to innovation, style, and the art of watchmaking. The new J12 Bleu is poised to become the next chapter in the story of this iconic timepiece, captivating watch enthusiasts for years to come.â€ Chanel Watchmaking Daniel Kim â€” Technology Editor With a UC Berkeley computer-science degree and a decade at Wired, Daniel Kim covers AI breakthroughs, cybersecurity threats, and consumer-tech launches. He runs Archyworldys' Lab section, where hands-on reviews, structured data, and expert verdicts drive rich-snippet visibility and affiliate-revenue growth.

For me, #fashion has always been something deeper, something closer to the soul â€“ an escape, an aspiration, an art form woven into the fabric of memory and culture. Growing up in #Haiti, particularly during the era leading up to the mid-1980s, presented a complex picture of fashion. In the middle-class environment where my early years were spent, there was an undeniable exposure to high society and, with it, a glimpse into the world of high fashion. This was the time when figures like MichÃ¨le Bennett Duvalier, the First Lady, were known for their lavish tastes, reportedly spending astronomical sums on Haute Couture from European houses and exquisite jewelry. (Research confirms Michelle #Duvalier's significant spending on designers like GIVENCHY and Boucheron , making her a symbol of that era's connection to global luxury).
