â€‰ Have YOU got a story? Email tips@dailymail.com Kelly OsbourneÂ showcased her slender frame in black knitted dress as she attended the Diamonds and Dust gala night with her partner Sid Wilson on Thursday. The TV personality, 40, who is the daughter of rock legend Ozzy and TV star Sharon Osbourne, looked incredible as she attended the event at London's Emerald Theatre. She wowed in theÂ off-shoulder garment that she paired with strappy black platform heels, a crossbody black leather ChanelÂ bag and silver earrings. Kelly completed her look by styling her ice blonde locks into a towering beehive with a sweeping side fringe that further accentuated her tiny frame. As she left Dita Von Teese's new show, Kelly was seen holding hands with Slipknot DJ Sid who wore a black and white oversized shirt, black trousers and New Balance trainers. Kelly has been open about her 85lb postpartum weight loss after welcoming her son, Sidney, two, with Sid and has denied having used Ozempic to help her shed the weight. She revealed she 'rapidly' lost the weight by cutting out 'sugar and carbohydrates' and not by using Hollywood's favorite weight-loss drug. Kelly's outing comes after sheÂ shared a snap of herself earlier this year looking dramatically different,Â reigniting speculation that she's had plastic surgery. The star took to Instagram to post a couple of glamorous shots after getting her hair and makeup done, with her face looking smoother and more chiselled than ever. Captioning the photos, Kelly revealed she'd been all glammed up for her plans to be cancelled at the last minute, lamenting: 'Sat through glam only to find that my day had been cancelled. #alldressedupandnowheretogo'. However, her followers were distracted by her noticeably slimmer and tauter appearance, which highlighted her sharper jawline, voluptuous lips, and lifted brows. They raced to the comments to admit they could barely recognise the star and accused her of getting heavy cosmetic work done that had made her look as though she'd had a 'full head transplant'. They commented: 'Is Kelly Osborne in the room with us?' ; 'WHO IS THAT?? Wft....'; 'Gifted a new head for Christmasâ€¦.' ; 'totally different head'. 'Who's face is that?' ; 'Full head transplant'; 'Lots of money and a good plastic surgeon and we can all be this beautiful'. 'Wow amazing what tons of plastic surgery, ozempic and money can do'; 'Is this the same Kelly Osbourne or. .' ; 'New face, who dis?' 'Where is Kelly?' ; 'can't imagine how many surgeries, fillers, botox injections, skin treatments, etc. were involved in this transformation. When you no longer look anything like yourself, what exactly did you accomplish?' 'Teenage Kelly would not be happy about this'; 'What in the millions dollars worth of plastic surgery is this'; 'Is she AI?!' Kelly has undergone many changes in her appearance over the years. In 2020, she revealed that she had quietly undergone gastric sleeve surgery two years before, leading to a jaw-dropping 85lb weight loss. She also previously admitted to having injections to change the shape of her face, and make her jaw look 'skinnier,' after suffering with TMJ (temporomandibular joint dysfunction). However, Kelly has repeatedly and furiously denied that she has hadÂ any cosmetic proceduresÂ besides Botox. Last year, she declared that she was a 'huge fan' of plastic surgery, but insisted that she was too scared to get anything done after seeing her mother go under the knife so many times. She toldÂ People: 'I am a huge fan of plastic surgery. What it does for people is amazing. It can change people's lives and give them the confidence they've been lacking, and make people feel beautiful in the way they want to feel beautiful. 'But I've never done anything but Botox. I'm too scared. I've always been in the camp of if you think it's broken, fix it. You don't have to be stuck with a nose you hate for the rest of your life. So yes, I'm a huge fan.' She explained the root of her fear, saying: 'I watched my mum go through every recovery from everything she's ever had done, and it looks awful'. Sharon, 72,Â has undergone a range of procedures including a gastric band, full facelift, tummy tuck, an eyelift, breast implants, abdominoplasty and Botox. While she has branded her 2021 facelift the 'worst thing she ever did' after the procedure left herÂ 'looking like a cyclops' and 'Quasimodo'. Back in March last year, Sharon shocked the public after she made her return to UK reality TV on Celebrity Big Brother. The star couldn't hide her weight loss on the show as she revealed doctors 'can't figure out' why she hasn't been able to gain weight back after she stopped using Ozempic months ago. 'The doctors can't figure it out,' she said. ' But I think it's just because I'm getting older and as you get older you lose weightÂ anyway and shrink and shrivel off.' On why she decided to start receiving Ozempic injections, Sharon said 'everyone was doing it'.

â€‰ The former Spice Girl's wedding dress had to be flown across the Atlantic four times to be perfectly fitted NEED TO KNOW Victoria Beckham and David Beckham got married 26 years ago on July 4, 1999 The fashion designer wore a champagne dress made by Vera Wang before changing into matching purple ensembles with David The dress featured a 20-foot train and a sculpted neckline Victoria Beckham is an undisputed style icon, and her 1999 wedding gown just might be one of her most memorable looks. On July 4, 1999, Victoria married soccer star David Beckham at the Luttrellstown Castle near Dublin. While David wore a chic white suit, Victoria opted for a stunning champagne ball gown made by iconic bridal designer Vera Wang. The silk pleated dress featured a 20-foot train and a sculpted, strapless neckline. To top off the look, Victoria accessorized the ensemble with an 18-karat gold tiara by jewelry designer Slim Barrett. Although the couple later ditched their white ceremony outfits in favor of matching purple getups for their reception, Victoria's wedding dress remains one of the most iconic staples from their lavish wedding and in her fashion lookbook as a whole. From details on the tiara to how that cinched bodice was made, here's everything to know about Victoria Beckham's wedding dress. The corset was made by Mister Pearl David Beckham and Victoria Beckham on their wedding day. David Beckham/Instagram One of couture's most celebrated corsetieres, Mister Pearl designed the underbodice for Victoria's wedding dress, which helped augment the structural top half of her ensemble. â€œThe actual underbodice was made by a very famous couture corsetiere named Mister Pearl, who works only out of London,â€ Wang told PEOPLE in 2023. â€œHe makes corsets that have to be pulled [in] with these metal things, which is how corsets were done in the old days.â€ Mister Pearl has worked with a slew of designers throughout his career, including Thierry Mugler and Vivienne Westwood. He also famously created Kim Kardashian's cinched corset for her iconic 2019 Met Gala look. The fashion entrepreneur joked in a red carpet interview with Vogue that she wasn't sure if she could take a â€œdeep breathâ€ while wearing the staple piece. â€œIt takes about 45 minutes to lace up,â€ Wang added of Mister Pearl's unique corsets. â€œAnd it can take your waist down to literally 18 inches [like] Scarlett O'Hara.â€ The gown flew across the Atlantic four times David and Victoria Beckham during their wedding in 1999. Victoria Beckham/ Instagram Since Mister Pearl exclusively works out of England, Victoria's dress â€” specifically its sculpted bodice â€” had to fly back and forth between New York City and London. â€œI call it the transatlantic dress,â€ Wang told PEOPLE, adding that the bodice had to fly four times across the pond. Wang flew out to London to help fit the corset onto Victoria, and the former Spice Girl also had to visit New York twice for more fittings. Things took a pause, however, when Victoria became pregnant with her and David's firstborn,Â Brooklyn. â€œSo then we delayed the wedding for two years,â€ Wang said. â€œThen we resumed, or maybe a year and a half. So that is [what] I call the transatlantic wedding with Victoria and David.â€ The designer also fondly remembered a baby Brooklyn â€œcrawling around on the bed in Londonâ€ during the fittings. Her tiara was decorated with brilliant-cut diamonds David Beckham and Victoria Adams Beckham hug on their wedding day. David Backham/ Instagram Victoria topped off her bridal ensemble with an iconic staple piece â€” an 18-karat gold tiara. To create the gorgeous headpiece, the Spice World star tapped jewelry designer Slim Barrett, who has collaborated with fashion houses like Chanel and Versace throughout his career and designed pieces for Mick Jagger and Princess Diana. The tiara, named the â€œEast of Paris,â€ was made from 18-carat latticed gold and adorned with brilliant-cut diamonds and suspended diamond drops. After the wedding, Barrett kept the crown, and it was later displayed at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London for its 100 Tiaras, Past and Present show. Barrett eventually put up the tiara for auction in 2013 at Bonhams in London, where it was valued between 18,000 and 25,000 pounds. â€œInspiration for East of Paris came from my love of Eastern design and Parisian haute couture,â€ Barrett told British Vogue at the time. â€œI set out to fuse the two styles.â€ Victoria still has her wedding dress David Beckham and Victoria Adams Beckham on their wedding day. David Beckham/ Instagram Years after their wedding, Victoria has held onto her gown. In a 2018 video for British Vogue, the fashion designer whipped out the wedding dress to honor her brand's 10th anniversary and to celebrate her life in looks. â€œToday we're here at Vogue and we are shooting a cover story celebrating the rich and inspiring history of one of the most enduring style icons of all time â€¦ me, Victoria Beckham,â€ she joked at the start of the video....

â€‰ Bonjour! Stepping into the realm of Parisian chic is a journey. French fashion, known for its effortless allure, enchants the world with its adaptability. From the iconic trench coat to the stylish scarf, French style embraces a certain je ne sais quoi that is both sophisticated and casual. - To delve into French fashion, one must consider its history. - The heart of style serves as the playground for this cultural phenomenon. - Legendary names like Chanel, Dior, and Yves Saint Laurent have defined the global landscape of style. Whether you aspire to emulate this celebrated aesthetic, this guide will equip the secrets behind French style. Exploring the World Through "The" - Language Immersion Language immersion is a concept that intensely submerges you in a new speech. Through participatory engagement, you absorb the nuances of a new language by enveloping yourself in its environment. This can involve living in a country where the desired language is used, attending conversation schools, or even joining online communities. - Submergence provides a exceptional opportunity to master a language at a more profound level than traditional textbook settings allow. - With dialoguing with native speakers, you hone your oral skills and attain a real understanding of the culture associated with the terms. As you envelop yourself in a new language, you discover a abundance of thoughts and narratives. Unlocking the Power of "Comme": Everyday French Conversations Made Easy Embark on a journey into the fascinating world of everyday French conversation by mastering the versatile word "comme"|express like. This seemingly simple preposition holds immense potential, allowing you to express comparisons, similarities, and even subtleties with ease. From illustrating your favorite meal and expressing your feelings about the weather, "comme"|such as becomes an essential instrument in your conversational repertoire. - Come on explore some useful ways to incorporate "comme"|like into your daily French interactions. 4. Comme des GarÃ§ons: Deconstructing Haute Couture Comme des GarÃ§ons, established by Rei Kawakubo, stands as a paradoxical force within the realm of fashion. The label consistently challenges expected notions of beauty and design, juxtaposing elegance with experimentalism. Kawakubo's signature aesthetic often involves deconstructing iconic garments, reimagining them into fragmented and unconventional silhouettes. Her collections frequently feature a dramatic palette of black, white, and gray, punctuated by occasional bursts of vibrant shades. This deliberate use of minimalism serves to highlight the architectural more info and physical qualities of her creations. Through a series of carefully curated presentations, Kawakubo expresses complex themes that often explore identity. Her runway shows are not merely fashion displays; they are thought-provoking performances that challenge viewers to question their own perceptions of beauty, normality, and the role of fashion in society. Embracing Imperfection in Life and Design In a world that often prizes perfection, it's easy to get caught up in the pursuit of something unattainable. But what if we shifted our perspective? What if we welcomed the inherent variations that make life and design so intriguing? - Here - mindset recognizes that charm can be found in the subtle. Imagine about a hand-painted ceramic mug with a slightly wonky handle or a vintage dress with a few details. These flaws don't detract from their beauty; instead, they tell a story of time. In essence, "comme Ã§a" is about celebrating the diversity of life and design. It's about recognizing grace in the ordinary. 6. The Cultural Relevance of "Comme" in Francophone Society Within the diverse tapestry of Francophone culture, the seemingly simple word "comme" assumes a surprisingly complex role. Far exceeding its literal meaning of "like" or "as," it serves as a linguistic chameleon, effortlessly adapting to convey nuances of similarity and even shaping social interactions. From its subtle presence in casual conversations to its more pronounced impact on formal discourse, "comme" reveals itself as a fundamental building block of Francophone communication. Ultimately, understanding the multifaceted significance of this word unlocks a deeper appreciation for the richness and complexity of the Francophone world.

â€‰ By the early '90s, Helena Christensen wasn't just a model, she was a Super. Alongside Naomi, Linda, Christy, and Cindy, Helena helped redefine what it meant to be a model: not just a face, but a force. She walked for Chanel, Versace, Valentino, and fronted campaigns that shaped fashion history. But beyond the glitter and glamour, Helena's journey has always been guided by intuition, instinct, and an insatiable curiosity about the world. â€œI didn't plan far ahead,â€ she tells @itsmeanitab. â€œI kind of just floated along, but was deeply connected to how I felt deep down in my stomach.â€ Now, decades into an inimitable career, she opens up about quiet reinvention, the grace and freedom of mid-life, and why this era might just be her most meaningful yet. Read the full story at the link in bio. â€‰ How Social Media Influences Pop Culture Pop culture is simply how we talk, dress, think and feel. Back in the day, several things helped to shape pop culture. This included news outlets, celebrity gossip, and magazines. However, the world has changed. In this era, social media is the solitary driver of pop culture. Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, and X are agents that spell out how pop culture is manufactured, shared, and consumed. They're not just tools for instant and efficient communication, though. These social media platforms double as instruments for setting trends and influencing behavioural patterns worldwide. Get a deep analysis of how social media influences pop culture in today's world in this article. Source: UGC Influencers Have Become the New Celebrities Actors and musicians were celebrities some decades ago. That's not the case in today's world. As long as you've got a smartphone with an internet connection, you can create a strong personal brand that attracts millions of individuals worldwide. You've seen it. Several TikTok stars, Twitch streamers, and YouTube content creators are making a name for themselves not just in their country but in a slew of jurisdictions around the globe. Their content influences fashion, dieting, and fitness goals. They also prompt the start of social challenges and promote music and movies. With social media, influencers can connect with their audience directly. As such, they can build personal relationships with their fans. This is something most traditional celebrities can only dream of. Viral Trends and Memes Social media is all about virality. Memes and challenges can spread across the world in several minutes or hours. Here are some challenges and trends that gained traction online and quickly became a fleeting phenomenon worldwide: Dance challenges such as Say So, Renegade, Out West, Stay, Super Lonely, Attention, Vibe, and Fancy Lite. Viral challenges such as the Ice Bucket Challenge, Don't Rush Challenge, Running Man Challenge, Savage Challenge, Renegade Challenge, One Chip Challenge, Trick Shot Challenge, and Cinnamon Challenge. Memes such as The Woman Yelling at a Cat, Rick Roll, Kamala Coconut, The Military Man, Mama Luigi, Trollface, Doge, and Pepe the Frog. If something that is relatable and tells a story is posted on social media, the chances of it taking off are high. The Discovery and Popularity of Music Social media has turned the music industry on its head. You can use YouTube and TikTok to discover new artists and music. For context, a song's catchy snippet being included in a comedy skit or dance challenge can bring new artists to the limelight and boost their streams. Lil Nas X is an example of a relatively unknown artist who changed the music marketing game to gain global reverence. He started as an independent artist, posting his SoundCloud music links on X. However, it wasn't long before he was noticed and became a famous musician with two Grammy Awards under his belt. Before record labels sign artists, they look at social media charts to see if they're trending or not. Artists, on the other hand, understand this. As such, they push out their releases with trendy hashtags with the hopes of getting noticed. Social Media's Role in Pop Culture Evolution Over Time Source: UGC Virtual Gaming Social media has also affected the virtual gaming sector. Gamers are now using platforms like Twitch and Discord to connect with others, share information, and create content on their favourite games. Before a game is released to the public, it's promoted through memes and entertaining video trailers. Additionally, developers also use social media to analyse demo playtime per region on their games to see what aspects appeal to players the most. These results are also used to create future gaming content that resonates with even more players. Aesthetics and Fashion Social media's impact is also felt in the fashion industry. The visual focus content posted on Instagram and TikTok has influenced how people dress and style others....

â€‰ The live-action adaptation of "How to Train Your Dragon" has impressed audiences with its realistic graphics and heartfelt story. The movie takes place in ancient times and tells the tale of a young boy, Hiccup, who becomes friends with a lovable dragon named Toothless. But Hiccup isn't the only character that audiences can't get enough of. It's his love interest Astrid that has people turning heads. And that could be because she is the daughter of a famous actor. Astrid is played by Nico Parker. Her feature-film debut was back in 2019 when she starred in the live-action adaptation of Disney's "Dumbo." The actor is the daughter of "Westworld" star Thandie Newton. The resemblance is obvious as both mother and daughter have glowing skin and piercing eyes. Unlike her mom, Parker often wears her hair naturally to show off her voluminous tight curls. But when it comes to fashion, the young starlet has clearly inherited her parent's famous style. In 2024, Parker told Harper's Bazaar how she used to envy her mother's couture style. "Any Chanel bag that my mom owned was the most important thing in the house," she remembered. "I did a lot of stealing those! And I would do fashion shows in her room with her bags and her shoes â€” a lot of which was Chanel." And as she grows into a young woman, it's clear that Parker's love of high fashion is as present as ever! Nico Parker is rocking her own style on red carpets Sean Zanni/Getty & Tinseltown/Shutterstock Nico Parker is the latest celebrity kid that has the potential to be a fashion icon. She is not timid with her style, and wears highly glamorous outfits effortlessly. Sadly, Parker was subject to criticism for playing Astrid in "How to Train Your Dragon." She wore her natural curly hair for the role, which differed from the character's look of blond hair and blue eyes in the 2010 animated film. But Parker remained comfortable and confident in her appearance by not paying attention to her critics. She told The Times of London, "If I wouldn't value your opinion on most things in life, I can't value your opinion on my hair." Parker often opts for dark eyeliner and black ensembles, but she also likes to show off her feminine side. For the red-carpet premiere of "How to Train Your Dragon," Parker wore a lovely light-pink dress with bows down the bodice. The sleeveless dress had a layered skirt of textured materials like frills and ruffles. This harkens back to Parker's first red-carpet premiere in 2019 for the movie "Dumbo." She was just 14 at the time, and wore a dark-green velvet minidress that had an intriguing cape. The outfit proved that capes aren't just for the runway and can be styled for the everyday. Across her waist, Parker looked youthful and cute as she wore a big pink bow as an accessory. We love that she's still including graceful bows in her wardrobe. Advertisement

â€‰ Listen to author and critic Erica Wagner in conversation with Lauren Elkin, writer of â€œScaffoldingâ€, her first novel published by Chatto & Windus in 2024 which raises questions about marriage, fidelity and abortion. Through this conversation with Erica Wagner, Lauren Elkin discusses her writing process and the influence of her experience as a researcher on her work as a novelist. Together, they also talk about Paris, the city where the story takes place and where Lauren Elkin lived for many years, the feminist movements that inspired her as well as her conception of love. â€‰ Listen to author and critic Erica Wagner in conversation with Huma Qureshi, writer of â€œPlaying Gamesâ€, her first novel published by Sceptre in 2023. In her novel, the author draws a nuanced portrait of sisterhood, family, love and loss through the arc of two main characters, Hana and Mira. Throughout the conversation, Erica Wagner and Huma Qureshi evoke Alice Munro, Ann Patchett or even Ann Taylor, feminine writers who deeply inspired her to write about quiet, but significant, everyday moments. They also discuss how the author returns to the subject of real life informing fiction in â€œPlaying Gamesâ€, a recurrent theme in her writing. â€‰ Hollywood flawless filter. I thought it was just a dumb overpriced diluted highlighter/way too glowy base, but no! It's actually versatile and so beautiful, i can't imagine living without it. Fun story - my brother just got married, and I was there when his wife was getting her makeup done. Her base was SOSOSO pretty, like a real life filter. I asked the makeup artist wtf she did to make her skin so pretty? She said she just used the Flawless Filter all over, a concealer, and three different powders (Chanel, YSL, and the OG Givenchy) to mattify the majority of the face. I can't express how pretty that looked. Also my holy grail foundation till the end of times is the Armani Luminous Silk. Idk what this sorcery is but it's just so beautiful, no matter what other hyped/dupes/luxury foundations I try, I ALWAYS go back to it because it's on another level to me.

â€‰ Gracie Abrams is having a summer for the books. The 25-year-old singer-songwriter has spent the better part of 2025 on her Secret Of Us Tour which began last September, did her Glastonbury debut last weekend and today sees her opening for Noah Kahan at BST Hyde Park. â€œPlaying at Glastonbury on a Friday was such a privilege. It allowed me the time to lean in hard into the festival, which I did. That was intense and perfect for me in a great way, but it's a rarity,â€ she tells Bazaar on a sunny evening at the Broadwick, Soho. Abrams, whose first album, Minor, released in 2020, notes that her post-show rituals are often a lot more â€œvanillaâ€. â€œIt's a quick shower and I'll get in the biggest clothes I have. I'll journal for a little bit or read something before I fall asleep,â€ she reflects. In between performing in ethereal ensembles by Chanel and Rodarte (barefoot, of course), for loyal fans who get teary-eyed by her melancho-pop sounds and vulnerable songwriting, Abrams has signed on to front Hourglass Cosmetics' new complexion campaign. Abrams' clean and polished signature make-up look ties in beautifully with Hourglass' range of your-skin-but-better concealers, bases and the new Illusion Priming Moisturiser. Ahead of her special appearance in Soho's The Vinyl Factory, Abrams sat down with Bazaar to share the heartfelt story behind her bob haircut, the signature scent that reminds her of home and her go-to blush combination. On her beauty philosophyâ€¦ â€œI tend to feel the most beautiful when I have the least on my face and when I feel the most like myself. It's really just about what makes you feel like you. [With beauty] when you find the lane that makes sense for you, it's exciting and inspiring to explore it. My mum wasn't someone who wore a lot of make-up but when she did a red lip, or something extra, it always caught my attention. I also love Alexa Chung.â€ On her skincare routineâ€¦ â€œIn the morning, I use cold water, sometimes ice cubes, because I get really puffy. I'll use a simple moisturiser which I got while we were on tour in Korea and then I use the La-Roche Posay SPF. At night, I use a benzoyl peroxide between those steps, without the SPF.â€ On doing her own tour make-upâ€¦ â€œI like the time to myself in that way. I slot for 20 more minutes than I actually need, just because it's nice to have an hour of the day sitting alone in a room. I value that alone time very much, and I do think it's therapeutic. I'll listen to a podcast, I like On Being with Krista Tippett. The guests that she has on are always so beautifully spoken and experts in their respective fields, and she's an excellent moderator. [For my make-up] on stage it's really about emphasising certain features, because I'm so far away from so many people. Off-stage, I use a concealer for spot treating, a blush and do my brows. I like fine highlighting powders that both set and give your face some sheen. I'm not a lipstick person so I use a brown-ish lip liner and a glossy balm. For stage, I go a bit heavier with highlighter and blush. I fill my brows in more.â€ On her favourite blushesâ€¦ â€œI'm obsessed with Hourglass Unreal Liquid Blush in Vision and Scene, and the Diffused Heat powder blush. I initially wouldn't have leant into pinks like that, but it's so nice on the skin and it's really sheer.â€ On her signature scentâ€¦ â€œAnother 13 from Le Labo always makes me feel like I'm at home. Smells are so important when you're away from home to make you feel like you're back there. But when we were in Seoul, Le Labo does the city specific scent and that one is a new favourite as well.â€ On her bob haircutâ€¦ â€œI honestly feel the most like myself with shorter hair. It was off the back of, almost like a pre-break-up, when things inside start to feel a bit tangled up, and you feel like you need a change. I didn't know where to start so I cut it all off and felt so much lighter. People say hair holds memories and feelings. It felt good to sever ties where I needed to, which sounds harsh but it really was a lighter and nicer experience than that. I love it. I see pictures of myself with my long hair or I'll watch somebody else's show and they're using their hair like this extra limb, and I'll get jealous. I'll miss it sometimes, but I think overall, I feel way more like myself and in my skin with this hair. Bobby Eliot cuts it.â€...

â€‰ Thanks for that. May I ask what is so schizoid about what I wrote, though? Is it not coherent? Am I using too many parentheses? I admit that I came out like a wreaking ball because I am, frankly, sick of people shitting on Bleeding Edge and seeing it for, like, at least 80% less than what it really is. Here's s'more A.B. stuff: American Beauty was written as a play in the early 1990s, partly inspired by the media circus that accompanied the Amy Fisher trial in 1992. Chapter 14 of Bleeding Edge contains a fictional play called Amy & Joey (an Off-Broadway musical). Bleeding Edge's Lester's name really was at least partially inspired by the role that Kevin Spacey took in American Beauty. Mason & Dixon anachronistically alludes to the Amy Fisher, Mary Jo Buttafuoco, and Joey Buttafuoco tragedy / media circus twice. Moving right along here: This isn't the only time reading-between-the lines leads one to come across movies or music videos that Pynchon worked into Bleeding Edge. Two other examples are â€œQuigleyâ€ (2003) and Aaron Carter's â€œThat's How I Beat Shaqâ€ (2000). To clarify further, at least about Quigley: Anthony Perkins' (the Norman Bates actor) wife died in the American Airlines Flight 11 plane that hit the World Trade Center. Her mother collaborated with Salvador DalÃ­ and competed with the likes of Coco Chanel (knockoffs of this Nazi-supporter's products crop up in Chapter 2 of B.E.) Berry Berenson's son Oz was in a LOW budget b-movie alongside Garey Busey. The plot of this film basically sets up the first two paragraphs of Chapter 9 of Bleeding Edge (look to Busey's motorcycle accident results [the messages from {God} that he thought he was channeling in cryptic anagrams] and their connection to the bizarre [bizarre even for Pynchon] â€œDESPAIRâ€ anagram from Chapter 9). The gargantuan coffeemaker from Chapter 7 that Vyrva calls â€œThe Insomniacâ€ may have been pulled right outta the first 25-minutes of Quigley. (The title of that film is part of where Pynchon got the name Axl Quigley from) The first name Axl could refer to the 1994, Nancy Kerrigan ice (yeah: ICE) skating attack. The Axel jump is a figure skating move that's unique for its forward takeoff. It could also refer to a the singer of a band that's mentioned in Bleeding Edge: Guns N' Roses Much of what takes place in the first few paragraphs of Chapter 9 relates to secrets kept â€œunder the roseâ€ (in confidence; under pledge of secrecy) â€¦ (See Roseman in CoL49 and the footsie he plays with Oedipa) â€¦ (see Ch 3 of Bleeding Edge and the 'FTSE' (Financial Times Stock Exchange 100 Index) that Horst [according to Maxine's wild imaginings] plays with women Maxine fears Horst has affairs withâ€¦ women who're curiously named after brands of cigars)

â€‰ If you purchase an independently reviewed product or service through a link on our website, SheKnows may receive an affiliate commission. The late Carolyn Bessette is surging to the top of the pop culture zeitgeist again and her classic style is a part of the conversation. Ryan Murphy's upcoming series, American Love Story, featuring her love story with John F. Kennedy Jr., might have been the catalyst for the resurgence. Still, it's Bessette's fashion icon status that is making everyone take a deeper dive into her life again. TikTok is pushing the Bessette style narrative again as beauty and style mavens flock to the West Village in Manhattan to scoop up Charles J. Wahba tortoise-shell headbands sold at C.O. Bigelow pharmacy. It may seem like a simple accessory to some, but it's Bessette's relatable style that makes sense in a very expensive 2025 world. "Carolyn represents this chic, quiet luxury style, I think many women want to emulate but feel they can't afford. So, the headbands provide an affordable and accessible way to participate, " influencer Beverly Hart explained to The New York Post. Still, Bessette's fashion voice developed as a reaction to life in the public eye instead of a carefully curated image in the press. The 2024 biography, Once Upon a Time: The Captivating Life of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy by Elizabeth Beller, spoke to friends who dismissed the idea that Bessette was obsessed with her wardrobe. Pal Michelle Kessler thought Bessette would laugh at her "fashion icon " description. "She was trying to be nothing of the sort. Carolyn was trying to have an interesting life and go about her day without interruption, " Kessler said. The 2023 book, CBK: Carolyn Bessette Kennedy: A Life in Fashion by Sunita Kumar Nair, shared a similar philosophy about JFK Jr.'s wife. "She didn't seek fame but was carved in a certain light, a light she sometimes enjoyed but mostly eschewed, rarely speaking to the press. Instead, she used fashion as a vehicle for communication - at times to thwart the insatiable camera lens but mostly thriving in her chosen ensemble, " Nair wrote in the book. Instead of Chanel and Christian Dior, Bessette chose "the understated, tailored, and soft-yet-structured Calvin Klein, Prada, and Yohji Yamamoto garments, " as noted by The Cut "I think if she was alive today, she would still want to be a mystery, but fashion is where she showed herself, " Bessette's former Calvin Klein coworker Stormy Stokes said in Nair's book. "It was the part she was happy to display." Before you go, click here to see all the best pictures of JFK Jr. and Carolyn Bessette. â€‰ SortU Tiktok echoes a family noise: It is that of many and different bracelets worn in conjunction. The mantra is 'more is more', so the pulse turns into a canvas where materials, volumes and textures stratify. But how to wear more bracelets in the summer of 2025 avoiding the bazaar effect? Like every trend that landed on the platform, this common gesture has also been renamed: Bracelet Stackor pile of bracelets. Far from the idea of â€‹â€‹a single protagonist accessory, this trend invites you to multiply, superimpose, compose. But the risk of sliding in the kitsch, between excesses and disorder, is around the corner. Mosaic effect: because it likes so much The boom comes from social networks, where the hashtag #bracelets collect millions of views And suggestions. Users show increasingly creative combinations: there are those who choose only shiny metals, those who play with the colorful resin, those who combine childhood jewelry -jewelry pendants. The idea is that of Create a visual story starting from what is worn: a sentimental mosaic made of charm, stones, engravings and contrasting textures. And even the big brands have not been looking at. Van Cleef & Arpelswith his Alhambra bracelets, is among the most cited on the platform, together also to Cartier, AurÃ©lie Bidermann, or more accessible brands such as Dodus or Pandora. Also in Spiggia, AurÃ©lie Bidmann. Back to the future: the 90s and the revival on the catwalks The stratification of the bracelets is not an absolute novelty. Already in 90s It was a symbol of a certain Bohemien aesthetic, made of leather, beads and souvenirs. The fashion shows were brought back: from Miu Miu his bangles stratified on the arm, a Saint Laurent Which offers maxi golden bracelets with architectural shapes. Chanel, Instead, it focuses on silver with architectural design. Today, however, the gesture changes meaning: it is no longer only accumulation, but intention to express itself. From the spring-summer 2025 fashion shows: at the top left Miu Miu, on the right Elie Saab. At the bottom left Saint Laurent, on the right Chanel. Harmony and character: how it really works The border between expression and confusionthere is to be admitted, it is thin. The key to a Bracelet Stack success is in knowing how to balance materials and volumes. Mix metal and fabric, opaque and brilliant, vintage and contemporary, but keeping consistency. Often one is enough Defined color palettesor a symbolic guiding thread, like a marine theme, botanist or abstract, To avoid the market effect. It is an approach that also works for celebrities: Bella Hadid It is the demonstration, with its stacking mixed with gucci vintage trousers or jacquemus look seen in Cannes, in which the bracelet becomes counterpoint to the minimalism of the outfit. The wrist, today, is the new white page of the look. A place where fashion meets identity and transforms it into daily gesture. I woman Â© RESERVED REPRODUCTION

â€‰ The National Leadership conference on African American Health disparities and social justice took place June 25-29. The conference centers its work around the African American MSM community, but since last years conferenced welcomed Black Trans Men and others to participate. This year the conference was headed by its new acting Executive Director and CEO R. Wayne Woodson, Ph.D. The workshops that were provided during this conference spoke on the wide work that the community of networking organization have been during over the year. The conference themes around HIV and the continued work to end stigma and to bring ideas to better serve the communities as a whole. The conversation around homelessness and funding of programs were some of interests during the conference. Leadership Dominque Morgans "The Halo Academy" powered by The Fund for Trans Generations at Borealis Philanthropy speaker ready room spoke on the call to Donors to wake up to the fight was amazing. The room was filled with many black leaders that seem to share a call to the movement work of second chances. Stories shared by the Susan Burton's A New Way of Life Reentry Program gave the realities of women who deserve a second chance find that hope and help to get them there. Beautifully done docuseries on YouTube bring them to life. The workshop session on Navigating Housing for Black LGBTQ+Angelenos given by The AMAAD Institute also brought light to the growing disparity of homelessness around our country. While the talk was focused and centered around the work in LA the information translates for all areas. Leadership Executive Director Gerald Gartha, MBA and Housing Program Manager Chanel Lumiere gave vital information on the learning curves to starting a housing program. Exploring the areas of building relationships and how those relationships grow into partnerships to serve the community. The room also filled with eager and well participants to end the epidemic of homelessness. The organization offerings of various programs to serve the community is outstanding and is a blueprint on collective innovations to bring forth change. The conference this year was a noticeable change from last year as it was more intimate and seem to be connected to a smaller Sub Conference HISTORI HIV Implementation Science to Optimize Research Impact. The conversation around Research and HIV at the conference was great to see. The workshop held seem to be also centered around African Americans and the future of science and HIV. There were many other great moments of the conference like the Documentary on Friday of Marissa Miller the Founder of the National Trans Visibility March. Her story was compelling and gave an inside look at the woman behind the work and the Philanthropic Spirit. The exclusive screening and talkback filled us in on the courage and resilience that is needed to be leader and also a friend. Breath taking moments on living in your truth, navigating the world around family, standing up for your community and pasting the torch to future leaders all can be done. Inspiring and brilliantly told through her own words gives hope for the leaders in the room. The conference also welcomed a workshop on The Healing of the Arts in the HIV fight was given by your one and only and seemed to be received in good light. To end my final day of the conference the Saturday's breakfast started with a pleasant surprise The United State Representative Maxine Waters gave a heartfelt speech and call to us in the room. The 86-year-old powerhouse gave permission to " ACTUP " through this time in our country as we go through what she has already fought once before in the CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT. What a privilege to have shared and heard her in the same space and time in history. I am grateful to NAESM for the opportunity to share and to learn from other great leaders in the fight against the epidemic of HIV in the black community and beyond. The Call to Action for you who have read this part of the blog entry. Check out the website of the mentioned organizations or people in this article to champion the work they do. Thank you for reading my blog and Peace and Blessing.

â€‰ It did take forever and it drove me to therapy which I typically avoid like the plague. Because I was not used to doing that. I got married the 1st time at 17 n quickly had 4 children so I had always been on medicaid until my new husband so this was my first experience with a traditional health insurance. I am used to doctors throwing all the tests at the wall to see what sticks so I was baffled. You always hear that you get worse care with medicaid but I had the exact opposite opinion. In fact, when I broke my foot, my soon broke his leg and we ended up going to the same ortho. My son receives disability so he had medicaid while I have united and I literally got to see and experience a side by side comparison. I had a broken heel for 3 weeks with dr after dr trying to tell me I sprained my ankle while im telling them I've sprained my ankle plenty of times thats not what I was feeling and trying to hardest to not lose my shit on them. Finally got an mri and they found it. I ended up switching orthos to a foot specialist and found out I actually broke my heel and had micro fractures going across the top middle of my foot as well as a weird shaded thing in my ankle. I broke it Feb 2023 and I still have days that it hurts more than that day. I am shoe obsessed and had Finally completed my collection,  except Chanel, but now none of my shoes fit and if I stand more than 10 minutes I swell up and feel like im standing in a pile of fire ants. Thats what I consider a good pain day. I always have memory problems like when you forget why you went in a room except the time it scared me most was I was standing at the kitchen counter with a knife in one hand and a tomato in front of me. But even seeing what I was doing, I couldn't remember what I was doing. I dont think sleep effects it much though. I know it used to when I was younger but now its just the longer im up, the harder it is to sleep. I have issues falling asleep and staying asleep. If im not trying to sleep and just let it happen, I can fall asleep easy. I enjoy falling asleep with the TV on because it relaxes me and takes the pressure off. My husband can't stand it though so I could be in that happy place right before you fall asleep and he turns off the TV and bam! Im wide awake again! I also always have the attention span of a gold fish so I dont think it could get worse lol. I do notice more pain and I get this feeling like something is missing. It's kind of close to the feeling that you forgot something but its like something inside of me is missing and get kinda whiny. I definitely feel like all of my procedures effect me differently each time. It's definitely not a steady drop in efficiency either. It's all very random and there's no way to predict it. I've tried botox, steroid injections, ketamine infusions, nerve blocks and nothing is ever consistent. The only suggestion I have not tried is the spinal cord stimulator because that terrifies the ever loving fuck outta me! Botox though can be finicky if you dont follow after care instructions. You get tiny bubbles under your skin and if you move them, they are no longer where they need to be. I am unfortunately a person that cannot stand having a bump under my skin and will sit there messing with them without even realizing im doing it. So I truly think it not lasting as long was my fault.

â€‰ These comfy shoes keep older folks in mind with features like orthopedic support, roomy toe boxes and Velcro straps. For people who walk frequently, choosing the right walking shoe is super important to prevent your feet from aching and developing or worsening painful foot conditions. But wearing the proper supportive footwear is especially essential for older adults, said Dr. Chanel J. Perkins, a board-certified podiatrist based in Texas. â€œSupportive shoes help maintain balance and alignment, which are necessities in this population since they are at a greater fall risk,â€ she told us. â€œThey also help decrease pedal muscle fatigue and overall soreness since biomechanics forces are evenly distributed throughout the shoe.â€ Perkins described the best shoes for older people as ones that are lightweight and breathable to prevent sweaty feet. They should also be well-cushioned, have good traction on the soles to prevent slips and falls and be easy to get on and off. If you or a loved one is in need of a new pair of walking shoes, consider the ones recommended below by Perkins and other podiatrists. 1. A pair of Brooks sneakers that older women can't stop buying This Brooks Ghost sneaker is known for its signature cushioning, which provides firm support and a midsole that evenly absorbs the impact of your foot, no matter how it lands. We couldn't help but include this sneaker as an editor's pick. In previous reporting, Shopping editor Emily Ruane noted that her momÂ andÂ her daughters' nanny â€” both active older women in their 60s â€” rely on the exact same pair ofÂ GhostÂ running shoes to stay light on their feet while they garden, run after kids (and grandkids) and do a whole lot of walking. Her mother has undergone bunion surgery and has hammer toes, and likes that the shoes are available in wide widths to accommodate her custom orthotics. She finds the toe box to be roomy and well-constructed enough to comfortably accommodate her feet. (She's actually on her second pair; the first lasted her almost four years before she needed to replace them a little under a year ago.) Ruane's children's nanny logs thousands of steps a day, and she told her that, â€œ[t]hese shoes are the best.â€ And our readers (and reviewers) tend to agree. Get them from Amazon for $148.77+ in women's (available in sizes 5â€“13, four widths, and 14 colors) or from Zappos for $149.95 in men's (available in sizes 7â€“15, four widths, and eight colors). 2. Skechers Go Walk Arch Fit sneaker Dr. Mireille Blanchette, a board-certified podiatrist based in New Jersey, recommended this lace-up Skechers sneaker because of its comfort and the fact that it's machine washable to help prevent bacteria buildup. "Elders can sometimes develop foot fungus because they might not always be able to clean well between the toes and that can create a great environment for fungus," she said. The shoe is designed with a pull tab on the back to make it easier to put on and take off and is lined in breathable fabric to promote air circulation. It comes in multiple colors and in women's sizes 5.5â€“10.5 and men's sizes 7â€“15, both with wide options available. Promising review:Â "Bought these shoes for my mom. She needed something with good support that was energizing and helped with footing and movement. These shoes did the job. Her footing, posture and movement have improved tremendously. I bought them for her because I own a pair and have excellent wear with them." â€”Mom Get them from Zappos in women's for $74.53+ (originally $90) or in men's for $100. 3. Men's Adidas Ultraboost 20 sneaker PerkinsÂ recommended this Adidas option, which is made from recycled plastics and has supportive interior padding and great grip on the sole. It comes in men's sizes 4â€“14 and in multiple colors, including black, orange, black/purple, gray/mint and white. It has a sock-like fit and a "boosting" feature, a super responsive midsole that makes it easier to take steps. Promising review: "Extraordinarily comfortable shoe. I have flat feet, gettingÂ olderÂ with hip creaks here and there. My legs and joints feel great when wearing these shoes. Ultraboost is impressive stuff." â€”Amazon customer Get them from Amazon for $118.99+. 4. Women's Orthofeet Francis walking shoe Available in multiple colors, including blue, pink, maroon, gray and black, this walking shoe has a cushioned footbed and orthotic insole designed to help those with various foot conditions such as plantar fasciitis. It also has a roomy toe box for added comfort and bunion and hammertoe relief. "The slip-on design makes it perfect for seniors who have a hard time bending over to tie a shoe or for those with arthritis in the hands who find difficulty with tying laces," Perkins said. â€‰ Updated 5 July 2025 at 14:43 IST Labubu Dolls, created by Hong Kong-based artist Kasing Lung, are making waves all over the internet. Check out the most popular and rare series of vinyl plush dolls by Pop Mart. Labubu dolls have become a go-to fashion statement for the A-listers' outings. Hanging casually on Hermes, Chanel, and many other handbags of celebs, this ultra-expensive elf-eye doll has carved out its universe in pop culture. With its bug eyes, jagged teeth, and quirky tuft of hair, the Labubu doll began as a picture book character but has evolved into a global style icon. Celebrities such as BLACKPINK's Lisa, Rihanna, and Ananya Panday are frequently seen with one swinging from their bags. Labubu represents playful rebellion and a sense of individuality. Whether you're intrigued by the surprise of blind boxes, the thrill of limited seasonal editions, or the charm of region-specific exclusives, there's a wide range to explore. Each Labubu comes with its own story, look, and vibe. Here are some of the most sought-after and rare designs that might look good in your collection. Most popular Labubu dolls According to media sites, the Mosters series is popular among Gen Z. â€‰ Older Mulberry bags look very outdated and somewhat cheap (anything from the 90s or earlier), and the brand doesn't have the design history or credentials of other labels. While brands like LV (1854), Goyard (1792) and Delvaux (1829) can count their history in centuries now (and ofter were the official supplier to the crown/royalty of their given country of origin), Mulberry was founded in 1971. Their founder is still alive and well, and they didn't even really have an hit bag until the 2000s. Contrast that with things like LV literally creating the first flat topped luggage or engineering the first use of coated canvas, or Chanel creating the first bag with an actual shoulder strap, and therefore influencing the actual design form of all bags ever after, Mulberry does not have that sort of cultural cache. Is there anything that they were the first to do? Also, Mulberry has a huge marketing budget. I've got the coffee table book to prove it (or the fact that 2 of their 3 hit bags are named for and marketed by celebrity influencers: Alexa Chung and Lana Del Rey).

â€‰ Bonjour! Stepping into the realm of Parisian chic is a journey. French fashion, known for its sophisticated simplicity, enchants the world with its versatility. From the iconic trench coat to check here the flamboyant handbag, French style celebrates a certain je ne sais quoi that is both sophisticated and casual. - To appreciate French fashion, one must consider its history. - The fashion capital serves as the playground for this cultural phenomenon. - Iconic brands like Chanel, Dior, and Yves Saint Laurent have defined the global landscape of fashion. Should you desire to emulate this celebrated aesthetic, this journey will unveil the secrets behind French style. Exploring the World Through "This" - Language Immersion Language immersion is a experience that intensely submerges you in a new language. Through active engagement, you learn the nuances of a foreign language by enveloping yourself in its society. This can include living in a country where the desired language is used, attending immersion schools, or even engaging in online communities. - Entrapment gifts a exceptional opportunity to acquire a language at a more profound level than traditional academic settings allow. - With communicating with native speakers, you develop your speaking skills and attain a genuine understanding of the traditions associated with the vocabulary. As you envelop yourself in a new dialect, you discover a wealth of thoughts and narratives. The Art of Conversation: Mastering "Comme" in Everyday French Embark on a journey through the fascinating world of everyday French conversation by mastering the versatile word "comme"|as. This seemingly simple preposition holds powerful potential, allowing you to express comparisons, similarities, and even fine points with ease. From painting a picture of your favorite meal to conveying your feelings about the weather, "comme"|such as becomes an essential tool in your conversational repertoire. - Alright then explore a few useful ways to incorporate "comme"|as into your daily French interactions. 4. Comme des GarÃ§ons: Deconstructing Haute Couture Comme des GarÃ§ons, established by Rei Kawakubo, stands as a paradoxical force within the realm of fashion. The label consistently challenges traditional notions of beauty and design, juxtaposing elegance with unpredictability. Kawakubo's distinctive aesthetic often involves deconstructing iconic garments, reimagining them into fragmented and unconventional silhouettes. Her collections frequently feature a bold palette of black, white, and gray, punctuated by occasional bursts of vibrant hues. This deliberate use of minimalism serves to emphasize the architectural and tactile qualities of her creations. Through a series of carefully curated presentations, Kawakubo communicates complex themes that often explore humanity. Her runway shows are not merely fashion displays; they are stirring performances that challenge viewers to question their own perceptions of beauty, normality, and the role of fashion in society. Celebrating Imperfection in Life and Design In a world that often prizes flawlessness, it's easy to get caught up in the pursuit of something unattainable. But what if we shifted our perspective? What if we embraced the inherent variations that make life and design so unique? - That - mindset recognizes that beauty can be found in the unconventional. Think about a hand-painted ceramic mug with a slightly wonky handle or a vintage dress with a few patches. These characteristics don't detract from their beauty; instead, they whisper a story of time. At its core, "comme Ã§a" is about celebrating the messiness of life and design. It's about finding joy in the ordinary. 6. The Cultural Significance of "Comme" in Francophone Society Within the diverse tapestry of Francophone culture, the seemingly simple word "comme" assumes a surprisingly complex role. Far exceeding its literal meaning of "like" or "as," it serves as a linguistic chameleon, effortlessly adapting to convey nuances of comparison and even shaping social interactions. From its subtle presence in casual conversations to its more pronounced impact on formal discourse, "comme" reveals itself as a fundamental building block of Francophone communication. Consequently, understanding the multifaceted significance of this word unlocks a deeper appreciation for the richness and complexity of the Francophone world.

â€‰ Know by Name by Channel Miller was not on my TBR. It was added to my list this year by the #beyondthespines reading challenge. I'm so, so glad this book was included on this year's challenge list. It was hard to read - I listened to the audiobook, read by the author - but it was an important read. Know My Name by Chanel Miller is a powerful memoir recounting her 2015 sexual assault by Brock Turner at Stanford University and the subsequent legal battle and personal journey of healing. This was a challenging topic. Miller speaks in depth about her trauma and the impact of the assault also had on her family and friends. She spares no detail in recounting the invasive medical and legal processes faced by victims of sexual assault. She speaks of the emotional toll of the trial - where her identity was hidden behind the name â€œEmily Doeâ€ - and the devastation at Turner's lenient sentence. The memoir highlights Miller's journey to reclaim her identity and open herself to life during and after the years the assault and legal process stole from her. You likely remember this case or have even read Miller's viral impact statement. â€‰ SPR_COMBO[it]MILANO - DebutterÃ  in prima assoluta giovedÃ¬ 10 luglio , evento inaugurale della 62Âª edizione de l Festival di Cervo (Imperia), la performance teatrale La forza del desiderio , che vedrÃ  protagonisti lo psicoanalista e scrittore Massimo Recalcati e l ' attrice Elena And reoli . Basato su Amen , il primo testo scritto da Recalcati appositamente per il teatro, lo spettacolo (che verrÃ  replicato il giorno successivo, venerdÃ¬ 11 luglio, a Saluzzo, in provincia di Cuneo, nell'ambito del festival Borgate dal Vivo ) vede il ritorno sulle scene di Elena Andreoli , che negli anni Novanta ha girato l'Italia calcando i palcoscenici accanto a due mostri sacri come Dario Fo e Franca Rame (insieme alla quale Ã¨ stata a lungo coprotagonista in L'Eroina e Grasso Ã¨ bello) e che ha lavorato anche con Carmelo Bene . Nel nuovo lavoro di Recalcati riflessioni e paure sul proprio futuro si intrecciano: che cosa rende possibile la resistenza della vita di fronte alle avversitÃ  e alla morte? In Amen l'autore racconta come la forza del desiderio puÃ² farci rialzare anche quan d o tutto sembra perduto. Recalcati parla di un'esistenza sul confine tra la vita e la morte, tra battesimo ed estrema unzione. Della nuda fede di una madre verso il battito del cuore del figlio. Di un vecchio soldato, sopravvissuto alla guerra, che insegna la forza del passo nella neve. Sullo sfondo i ricordi di una vita e la presenza incombente della fine. Una preghiera nel nome della vita che non vuole morire. Afferm a Elena Andreoli : Â«In questo spettacolo interpreterÃ² tutti e tre i personaggi creati da Recalcati. Per una curiosa coincidenza del destino, queste figure mi sono particolarmente familiari. Il primo personaggio, infatti, non puÃ² non farmi pensare a mi o nonno materno, che tornÃ² a piedi dalla drammatica campagna di Russia. Rientrato in Italia, diventÃ² uno scrittore umoristico. Aveva fatto dell'ironia un rifugio contro il dolore, un modo per restare vivo, per riuscire a ridere ancora nonostante tutto l'orr o re vissuto. La seconda figura che porterÃ² in scena Ã¨ quella di una madre che affronta la tragedia di un figlio nato prematuro e giÃ  dato per morto ma che resiste, resiste contro ogni previsi o ne. Impossibile non identificarmi in questa donna e non pensare alla bimba che persi, vent'anni fa, quand'ero all'ottavo mese di gravidanza. Il terzo e ultimo pe r sonaggio Ã¨ proprio il figlio nato prematuro, cioÃ¨ lo stesso Recalcati, fortunatamente sopravvissuto e diventato il grande psicoanalista che conosciamo e che amiamo. Queste tre figure dialogheranno tra loro in un bellissimo esempio di meta-teatro. La forza del desi derio Ã¨ un intreccio non solo di monologhi, ma anche di biografie: la mia, quella dell'autore e quelle dei suoi personaggi. Il tutto lungo un percorso artistico che Ã¨ allo stesso tempo terapeutico: una vera catarsi, come nel grande teatro grecoÂ». U n (triplo) ruolo impegnativo, come si vede, che perÃ² non spaventa l'attrice milanese: Elena Andreoli, infatti, Ã¨ capace di passare con disinvoltura dal registro brillante a quello drammatico, dai toni ironici a quelli piÃ¹ intimi e delicati. Merito di u na dura gavetta iniziata negli anni Novanta quando, dopo aver frequentato i corsi all ' Accademia d'Arte Drammatica , alla Royal Shakespeare House di Londra e all' Actor's Studio di Londra , si Ã¨ avvicinata al teatro, lavorando con personaggi come Dario Fo, Fr anca Rame e Carmelo Bene : Â«Sono felice di tornare a riannusare il profumo del teatro, l'odore del legno del palcoscenico - dichiara Andreoli - . Dopo le prime prove de La forza del desiderio questo profumo mi Ã¨ tornato immediatamente familiare. Lo avevo respirato per tanti anni con MemÃ¨ Perlini, pioniere dell'avanguardia teatrale ngli anni '70 a Roma e grande artista visionario, poi con Dario Fo e Franca Rame e infine con Carmelo BeneÂ». La regia de La forza del desiderio Ã¨ firmata da Alberto Traverso, mentre Carlos Eduardo Zarattini ha curato il sound design. In scena, accanto a Massimo Recalcati ed Elena Andreoli ci sarÃ  anche il pianista Tony Berchmans , che eseguirÃ  musiche originali composte da lui, Zarattini, Andreoli e Traverso. Dallo spettacolo Ã¨ stato realizzato un podcast che verrÃ  pubblicato su Spotify e su altre piattaforme digitali: Â«Nel podcast sono affiancata da due attori, due voci del cinema note e premiate (Simone D'Andrea e Sebastiano Tamburrini), che interpretano, rispettivamente, Recalcati e il soldato - afferma Andreoli - io faccio soltanto il personaggio della madreÂ». Eclettica e versatile, vedremo Elena anche sul grande schermo : in autunno, infatti, uscirÃ  Stella Gemella del regista Luca Lucini , commedia (nel cast figurano come protagoniste Margherita Buy e Laura Morante) in cui Andreoli Ã¨ una cantan te jazz alle prese con un brano da lei stessa composto. Per il cinema, in passato, Elena ha lavorato con Mario Monicelli al fianco di Philippe Noiret e con Federico Fellini , di cui Ã¨ stata assistente al doppiaggio ne La voce della Luna . A proposito di doppiaggio: oltre che attrice, Elena Ã¨ una speaker e doppiatrice di talento, tanto che lo scorso autunno si Ã¨ aggiudicata il prestigioso Anello d'Oro come miglior voce femminile televisiva dell'anno (sezione programmi tv e d'informazione) p er lo speakeraggio di 4 Hotel , il seguitissimo talent show di Bruno Barbieri in onda su Sky. Il riconoscimento le Ã¨ stato assegnato dalla giuria di Voci Nell'Ombra , il festival internazionale del doppiaggio. Nel corso della sua brillante carriera l'artista milanese ha prestato, inoltre, la voce al cinema ( La voce senza volto di Filippo Soldi, candidato ai Nastri d'Argento 2024), alla pubblicitÃ  (per gli spot Chanel NÂ° 1, Mulino Bianco, Apple, Esselunga, Wolksvagen, Ike a e molti altri) e ai documentari ( Cinema Forever di Alberto Traverso, presentato e proiettato al MoMa di New York). Dal 2022, inoltre, Ã¨ la voce istituzionale del Corriere.it , la versione online del Corriere della Sera, il piÃ¹ importante quotidiano italia no. Da segnalare, infine, che Elena Ã¨ anche una sofisticata e brillante cantante jazz: dopo i due sold-out fatti registrare lo scorso anno, sarÃ  di nuovo in concerto nel foyer del Teatro degli Arcimboldi di Milano il prossimo 26 ottobre con il suo sestetto e con il grande clarinettista Paolo Tomelleri nell'ambito del festival internazionale JAZZMI. In questa occasione Andreoli presenterÃ  il su o album d'esordio, che affonda le radici nello swing ed Ã¨ un'appassionata dichiarazione d'amore per il jazz.

â€‰ SPR_COMBO[nl]In juli zorgen Paramount Network, Comedy Central, Nick Jr., Nickelodeon en MTV voor extra kleur op je scherm met een spetterende line-up aan shows. Leun achterover, ontspan en laat je vermaken! Paramount Network Week van de superhelden en schurken Deze week staat in het teken van bad guys en superhelden. Vanaf maandag 21 juli kijk je elke avond om 20.00 uur naar actiefilms zoals 'Suicide Squad', 'Birds of Prey', 'Justice League', 'The Dark Knight', 'Joker', 'Batman Begins' en nog veel meer. De strijd tussen goed en kwaad begint op Paramount Network. Naked Gun Movie WeekÂ Â  Om de bioscooppremiÃ¨re van de nieuwe 'Naked Gun'-film te vieren, brengt Paramount Network de originele trilogie terug op tv. Lach je suf van maandag 28 t/m woensdag 30 juli om 20.00 uur met 'The Naked Gun: From The Files Of Police Squad!' , 'The Naked Gun 2Â½: The Smell of Fear' en 'Naked Gun 33â…“: The Final Insult'. De drie 'Naked Gun' films zijn ook nog te zien tijdens de Zaterdagmarathon op 2 augustus vanaf 13.20 uur. Action Saturday â€“ Zaterdag 19 juliÂ Â  Op zaterdag 19 juli zit je goed voor een dag vol spektakel. Met toppers als 'Lara Croft: Tomb Raider', 'Top Gun: Maverick', 'Snake Eyes: G.I. Joe Origins' en 'Machete' wordt het een zaterdag om niet te missen. Twilight Movie WeekÂ Â  Team Edward of Team Jacob? Duik vanaf maandag 7 t/m vrijdag 11 juli om 20.00 uur in de wereld van 'The Twilight Saga'. Een week lang romantiek, spanning en bovennatuurlijke drama op Paramount Network. Op zaterdag 2 augustus zijn alle drie de films opnieuw te zien tijdens de Zaterdagmarathon, vanaf 13.20 uur. Comedy Central 'Poppa's House' â€“ Vader, zoon & veel gedoe Wat krijg je als een legendarische talkshowhost onder Ã©Ã©n dak woont met zijn net gescheiden zoon? Juist: ongemakkelijke gesprekken, botsende generaties en hilarische momenten. 'Poppa's House' is scherp, herkenbaar en onweerstaanbaar grappig. Vanaf 21 juli elke maandag om 21.00 uur met dubbele afleveringen bij Comedy Central. 'The Neighborhood' â€“ Seizoen 7 'The Neighborhood' heeft een nieuw seizoen. In seizoen 7 staan cultuurclashes, vriendschap en familiedynamiek weer centraal bij de Butlers en Johnsons. Boordevol humor Ã©n een warm hart. Kijk elke maandag om 20.30 uur naar de nieuwste afleveringen â€“ alleen bij Comedy Central. Nickelodeon & Nick Jr. 'Dora en de zoektocht naar Sol Dorado' â€“ filmpremiÃ¨re In deze nieuwe live-action film gaan Dora, Diego en hun vrienden op een spannend avontuur door de jungle. Ze moeten op tijd de legendarische schat Sol Dorado vinden, voordat anderen met minder goede bedoelingen hem te pakken krijgen. Een avontuurlijke speurtocht vol gevaren, vriendschap en ontdekkingen. De film is voor het eerst te zien op zaterdag 5 juli om 12.00 uur op Nickelodeon. 'Dora Fiesta' â€“ 25 jaar avontuurÂ  Dora viert haar 25e verjaardag en dat doen we groots op Nick Jr. Vanaf 7 juli zie je elke maandag tot en met vrijdag om 9.30 uur (NL) en 12.15 uur (BE) nieuwe afleveringen van het gloednieuwe 'Dora'-seizoen. Ga mee op avontuur met Dora en haar beste vriend Boots in een magisch regenwoud vol verrassingen. En alsof dat nog niet genoeg is, vieren ook 'PAW Patrol' en 'Rubble & Crew' het feestje mee. From the iconic trench coat to the stylish scarf, French style embraces a certain je ne sais quoi that combines structure and fluidity. - To delve into French fashion, one must examine its influences. - The heart of style serves as the epicenter for this cultural phenomenon. - Legendary names like Chanel, Dior, and Yves Saint Laurent have shaped the global landscape of trends. If you dream to emulate this celebrated aesthetic, this guide will equip the secrets behind French style. Exploring the World Through "Comme" - Language Immersion Language immersion is a phenomenon that thoroughly submerges you in a new tongue. Through active engagement, you absorb the nuances of a new language by engulfing yourself in its society. This can involve living in a country where the target language is spoken, attending conversation schools, or even joining online communities. - Submergence offers a exceptional opportunity to master a language at a advanced level than traditional classroom settings allow. - Through communicating with native speakers, you develop your aural skills and attain a real understanding of the traditions associated with the terms. When you envelop yourself in a new dialect, you reveal a treasure trove of ideas and stories. Mastering "Comme": A Key to Smooth French Conversations Embark on a journey through the fascinating world of everyday French conversation by mastering the versatile word "comme"|as. This seemingly simple preposition holds great potential, allowing you to express comparisons, similarities, and even fine points with ease. From painting a picture of your favorite meal and conveying your feelings about the weather, "comme"|similar to becomes an essential tool in your conversational toolkit. - Come on explore some useful ways to incorporate "comme"|like into your daily French interactions. 4. Comme des GarÃ§ons: Deconstructing Haute Couture Comme des GarÃ§ons, established by Rei Kawakubo, stands as a paradoxical force within the realm of fashion. The label consistently challenges conventional notions of beauty and design, juxtaposing elegance with experimentalism. Kawakubo's signature aesthetic often involves deconstructing classic garments, transforming them into fragmented and unconventional silhouettes. Her collections frequently feature a stark palette of black, white, and gray, punctuated by occasional bursts of vibrant hues. This deliberate use of minimalism serves to highlight the architectural and tactile qualities of her creations. Through a series of carefully curated presentations, Kawakubo expresses complex themes that often explore perception. Her runway shows are not merely fashion displays; they are provocative performances that challenge viewers to reconsider their own perceptions of beauty, convention, and the role of fashion in society. Celebrating Imperfection in Life and Design In a world that often prizes perfection, it's easy to get caught up in the pursuit of something unattainable. But what if we shifted our perspective? What if we welcomed the inherent imperfections that make life and design so unique? - This - approach recognizes that delight can be found in the subtle. Consider about a hand-painted ceramic mug with a slightly wonky handle or a vintage dress with a few seams. These characteristics don't detract from their appeal; instead, they reveal a story of time. At its core, "comme Ã§a" is about appreciating the messiness of life and design. It's about recognizing beauty in the unassuming. 6. The Cultural Relevance of "Comme" in Francophone Society Within the diverse tapestry of Francophone culture, the seemingly simple word "comme" assumes a surprisingly complex role. Far exceeding check here its literal meaning of "like" or "as," it serves as a linguistic chameleon, effortlessly adapting to convey nuances of similarity and even shaping social interactions. From its subtle presence in casual conversations to its more pronounced impact on formal discourse, "comme" reveals itself as a fundamental building block of Francophone communication. Ultimately, understanding the multifaceted significance of this word unlocks a deeper appreciation for the richness and complexity of the Francophone world.

â€‰ Books!!! Great sewing books are inspiring and often priced so they feel like an indulgence. A few I have and love are listed below. If you know she likes / is inspired by a particular designer -- for example, Cocoa Chanel -- that also provides lots of options. A list of some of my favorites, in no particular order: Real Clothes, Real Lives: 200 Years of What Women Wore (Smith College Historic Clothing Collection) by Kiki Smith and Vanessa Friedman [This is a sourcebook of women's clothing through the years with fantastic photos. It focuses on daily wear items, like day dresses aprons, and uniforms -- not evening wear or couture. It's inspiring and makes an excellent coffee table book.] Vintage Details: A Fashion Sourcebook by Jeffrey Mayer and Basia Szkutnicka [Highlights different garment details and categorizes by decade. Great close-up photos of interesting garment details from the outside of the garment. Covers coats, suits, dresses, and other items.] What Shall I Wear: The What, Where, When, and How Much of Fashion by Claire McCardell. New edition has a forward by Tory Burch. [This is a GEM. Claire McCardell was a highly influential American designer who is credited with creating American sportswear. This is her reflection on the role of fashion in a woman's life. it's lovely. If not a gift for her birthday, perhaps a sweet just-because gift some time. As a quick note: It was written in 1957 and a few sentences come off as a bit dated by today's standards. However, IMO, it doesn't distract.] Ann Lowe: American Couturier by Elizabeth Way and Heather Hodge. [Ann Lowe was a gown designer and seamstress who designed Jacqueline Kennedy's wedding dress and bridesmaid dresses, as well as gowns for many other famous and influential people. She was a black woman who designed for white women and received little credit in her lifetime. Her story is just staring to be known. This is a coffee table sized book with lots of photos -- including some really helpful inner construction photos -- and Ann's story. I believe it  was created to accompany a retrospective museum exhibit.] I hope this helps!!

â€‰ Old Favs: I've been leaning into Summer colors, and blues are a particular favorite of mine. I broke out my Sailor Moon palettes from Colourpop yesterday and tried to do a cute little periwinkle + peach sky vibe. It turned out alright! Adding Chanel's Beige Lumiere gave it some much needed light. Colourpop does do pastels pretty well, but I did make sure to wear MAC's eye primer. New Favs: Guerlain's Emerald Feathers palette -- I just couldn't resist, and omg. If you were thinking of getting Lisa Eldridge's vs this one, I'd go for Guerlain's, BUT the green is more intense in Guerlain's vs LE's true khaki, plus you have a little more options with LE. Still, this made the green / gold in my brown eyes pop! I had 1 person tell me I looked great, and my Door Dash driver was flirting with me, lol! Idk if it was the eyeshadow but woo. Lancome's Juicy Tube in Lavender Latte -- I think this is beautiful and with that peachy-blue look I mentioned, I paired this over top of Romand's Juicy Lasting Tint in Mulled Peach. I was an OG fan of these back in the day, so I knew I'd grab one eventually. I will say I do not like the floral taste of this. It has a fruity scent, but a floral taste. No matter how I try, I can't get into flowers in tea, vape juice, food, and now makeup. They don't belong in my mouth, lol. After a bit you don't notice it though, and these do adhere well because they're a little sticky, but in the right way, not the uncomfy kind. Fenty's Smurfette Gloss Bomb -- This is PURPLE, and the sparkles in this are way more intense than Lancome's. Also adheres well, but does feel heavy. Not a good thing to apply before bed because my lips felt gross in the morning, lol! It's really cute though and... Smurfette <3 Weird collab but I likey. Mid: The Saem's Jelly Blusher in Dusty Vine -- I love a dusty purple blush, and they are hard to find, since most go pink or disappear to nothing. This almost disappears to nothing. It's extremely faint. Worked great with my eyeshadow for a crease shade on that peachy-blue look, but primer is probs what made it pop out. You can build it, but it takes a lot. Nice for subtle dusty purple I suppose. Idk, I've never been impressed with any of The Saem's color products. Reminds of drug store I'd buy 15 years ago. Their under-eye concealer is insanely good though. Edit: And it's not a jelly. It's a matte powder. No shine. Idk what's up with the name, lol.
