â€‰ In the grand Salon d'Honneur at the Grand Palais, the Chanel Fall-Winter 2025/26 Haute Couture collection unfolded as a serene celebration of nature, simplicity, and refined elegance. Designed by the Chanel Creation Studio and set against a decor crafted by Willo Perron, the show evoked the intimate ambiance of Gabrielle Chanel's legendary Haute Couture salons at 31, rue Cambon, where Mademoiselle herself pioneered a return to understated sophistication. Photo Credit: Courtesy of Chanel This collection is a breath of fresh air, drawing inspiration from the vast English countryside and rugged Scottish moors that once captivated Gabrielle Chanel. It reimagines winter classics through a pastoral lens, presenting suits in earthy tones of ecru, ivory, brown, green, and black. Borrowing proportions from menswear, these pieces prioritize freedom of movement, embodying Chanel's revolutionary vision of liberating women's bodies. The collection's fabrics tell a story of harmony between nature and craftsmanship. Tweed, a Chanel hallmark, is reinterpreted with innovative textures: a knitted allure transforms it into a white coatdress adorned with embroidered braids, a suit jacket resembling a cozy jumper, and mohair suits in rich autumnal shades of green and plum. BouclÃ© tweed mimics the soft warmth of sheepskin in a black-and-white coatdress, a skirt suit, a long gilet, and ivory short trousers, hand-painted and embroidered for added artistry. Feathers elevate tweed to faux-fur elegance in a trouser suit, a long coat, an embroidered over-cape, and a short blouson jacket, blending rustic charm with couture finesse. Photo Credit: Courtesy of Chanel Wheat ears, a cherished symbol of abundance for Gabrielle Chanel, weave their way through the collection as a poetic motif. They appear as delicate feathers in the chiffon flounces of a black-and-white strappy dress, embroidered along the neckline of the wedding dress, and as chevron-inspired patterns on a pants ensemble. Jewel-buttons, many bearing the wheat ear emblem, add a touch of opulence. Multicolored floral embroidery blooms across an embroidered pea coat and a satin crÃªpe pinafore dress, completing the pastoral narrative. As the collection turns to sunlight, it captures its radiant glow with golden jewel-buttons, intricate embroidery, and ennobled gold and silver lace. A flounced dress in shimmering orange lamÃ© radiates warmth, embodying the collection's luminous finale. Each piece reflects Chanel's commitment to modernity, honoring the woman who reshaped fashion by prioritizing comfort and movement. Photo Credit: Courtesy of Chanel The Chanel Fall-Winter 2025/26 Haute Couture collection invites us to reconnect with nature and embrace freedom. By channeling Gabrielle Chanel's trailblazing spirit, this collection redefines luxury as effortless, refined, and deeply rooted in the beauty of the natural world. For those seeking greener pastures, Chanel offers a vision of couture that is both timeless and forward-looking, a fitting tribute to Mademoiselle's enduring legacy. The post appeared first on Haute Living.

â€‰ An ambassador for Chanel since 2018, PenÃ©lope Cruz attended the fashion house's fall 2025 couture collection show during Paris Couture Week on Tuesday, wearing a look from the brand. The Oscar-winning actress donned a Chanel jacket, featuring a tailored silhouette with allover shimmering details intricately woven into the fabric. Cruz's outfit also included a black jacket with off-white trim and pearl detailing, along with sinuous cuffs and subtle pinstripe lines of sparkling details. The actress carried a Chanel quilted bag and wore a pair of black heels to complete her ensemble. The actress' shimmering black suit, part of Chanel's cruise 2026 collection, made its runway debut last April. The Villa d'Este hotel in Italy served as the backdrop for the collection's showcase, featuring designs that paid homage to the Romy Schneider wearing Gabrielle Chanel designs in his 1962 movie â€œBoccaccio 70,â€ per Luisa Zargani's WWD review of the collection. Highlights from the collection included â€œtweed miniskirts in a beautiful wisteria hue that matched the blooms on the terrace, for example, and short taffeta dresses in a peach or pink color with flounces and ruffles â€” although at times the frilly effect could have been toned down a bit,â€ Zargani added. The collection marked a turning point for the French luxury fashion house. Matthieu Blazy, who spent much of his formative years at Bottega Veneta, was named Chanel's creative director in December 2024. The designer's first collection for the label will be featured in October. As of last April, the designer is reportedly assembling his team. Ahead of the fall 2025 couture show, guests from Sofia Coppola to Cruz, Keira Knightley and more kicked off Paris Couture Week with the Bal d'Ã‰tÃ© at the MusÃ©e des Arts DÃ©coratifs on Sunday in Paris. Cruz also wore a Chanel selection from the label's spring 2025 couture collection to the fete. Chanel Fall 2025 Couture View Gallery Launch Gallery: Chanel Fall 2025 Couture

â€‰ Raphael Saadiq talks upcoming one-man show tour, BeyoncÃ©'s work ethic and his work on 'Sinners' LOS ANGELES (AP) â€” Raphael Saadiq has always admired the boldness of stand-up icons like Dave Chappelle and Eddie Murphy who commanded the stage alone with only their stories. Now, the three-time Grammy winner is taking a similar leap, stepping into the spotlight solo for his own one-man show tour. The intimate tour called No Bandwidth will pull back the curtain on Saadiq's life and music, weaving never-before-told stories with performances spanning Tony! Toni! TonÃ©! , Lucy Pearl and his solo catalog. The tour kicks off in Sacramento on Sept. 7, marking a return to the stage that began with a recent limited four-city sneak peek in New York, Los Angeles and his hometown of Oakland. Music Review: English post-punks Wet Leg level up on sophomore album, 'Moisturizer' A few songs into the second studio album from buzzy English post-punks Wet Leg, singer Rhian Teasdale yells â€œlevel up!â€ And level up they have. The alt-rock group took their time to complete their sophomore release, titled â€œMoisturizer.â€ It was worth the wait, says The Associated Press' Jim Pollock in his review. The album is a terrific soundtrack for a long, hot summer. The band's sound is built on Teasdale's deadpan delivery and guitarist Heather Chambers' chunky, jagged bursts. On â€œMoisturizer,â€ they have greatly expanded their skills and range. But they have also retained the raunchy, goofy energy that gained them an adoring audience in the first place. Oprah Winfrey's latest book club pick, 'Culpability,' delves into AI ethics NEW YORK (AP) â€” Oprah Winfrey has selected Bruce Holsinger's novel "Culpability" as her latest book club pick. The story explores the ethics of artificial intelligence through the lens of an American family. Winfrey praised the book on Tuesday, the day it was published, calling it timely and riveting. Holsinger, an English professor at the University of Virginia, expressed gratitude for the honor, noting his long admiration for Winfrey's book club. The announcement continues Winfrey's partnership with Starbucks. Her interview with Holsinger was filmed at a Starbucks in Seattle. It's available on her YouTube channel and podcast platforms. Chanel turns 110, supersizing its couture salon in a lavish palace set PARIS (AP) â€” Chanel has marked 110 years of its haute couture by recreating its atelier inside the freshly restored Grand Palais for Paris Couture Week. Meanwhile, the fashion world counts down to the debut of Chanel's new designer Matthieu Blazy. Tuesday's show by one of the world's most powerful luxury houses was intimate yet monumental, old world yet futuristic. Front-row regular Naomi Campbell said that "there's warmth, intimacy, nostalgia. Chanel can recreate anything, and it works.â€ The studio team is holding the fort after Virginie Viard's abrupt and unceremonious exit last year. It anchored the show in classic codes but played with wit and lightness. StÃ©phane Rolland lets couture speak for itself with space-age glamor PARIS (AP) â€” StÃ©phane Rolland went back to what he does best on Tuesday: unadulterated couture. This season at Paris Couture Week, Rolland stripped away gimmicks and let the clothes do the talking, unveiling a dazzling palette of ivory, black, and red â€” with giant spangles shimmering like stardust or cosmic fish scales. A live string orchestra set the mood as Rolland's signature silhouettes reshaped the female form: mermaid gowns hugged the body, giant tulle trains trailed behind, and severe white dresses with razor-sharp shoulders brought a surreal, intergalactic edge. Space-age references ran throughout, from pointy shoulders to jewels worn as talismans â€” adorned on gowns or set on the forehead like interplanetary insignia. Cierra Ortega exits 'Love Island USA' villa following backlash over resurfaced racial slur posts LOS ANGELES (AP) â€” â€œLove Island USAâ€ says contestant Cierra Ortega has left the show â€œdue to a personal situationâ€ during Sunday's episode, just a week before the finale will air. Her departure follows weeks of uproar from viewers after old social media posts in which Ortega used a racial slur against Asian people resurfaced. The show, which is on its seventh season, didn't provide a direct reason for her departure and a spokesperson declined to comment Monday. Ortega's family posted to her Instagram story Sunday evening following the departure announcement asking the public for compassion, patience and â€œbasic human decency.â€ Pearl Jam drummer Matt Cameron says he's leaving the band after nearly 30 years AP Entertainment Writer (AP) â€” Pearl Jam drummer Matt Cameron says he's leaving the band after nearly 30 years. The 62-year-old Cameron announced his departure in a social media post on Monday. He says he has taken his â€œfinal steps down the drum riser for the mighty Pearl Jam,â€ and thanked the band members for giving him the opportunity of a lifetime. The band called Cameron a â€œsingular and true powerhouse of a musician" in a statement. Cameron didn't give a reason for his departure. Cameron played drums for Seattle grunge legends Soundgarden for more than a decade before joining Pearl Jam....

â€‰ Paris Couture Week 2025 saw an unforgettable moment when Lisa Haydon took over the runway as Rahul Mishra's muse, leaving the audience awe-inspired. Held on July 7 inside the stunning refectory of CollÃ¨ge des Bernardins, Rahul Mishra's show offered a poetic narrative through fashionâ€”and Lisa embodied that story in its purest form. Dressed in an ethereal white ensemble, she became the living symbol of Mishra's Fall Couture 2024 collection, aptly titled Becoming Love. Lisa Haydon, known for her timeless elegance and striking presence, was nothing short of celestial in a sheer sequin corset gown designed with Rahul Mishra's signature love for intricate Indian craftsmanship. The dress glistened under the Parisian lights, drawing attention to the delicate floral motifs and the fluid artistry behind its creation. A floor-length silhouette, cinched bodice, and refined layers of sheer detail rendered Lisa a goddess-like figure on the catwalk. The collection Becoming Love is Mishra's introspective ode to the transformative journey of loveâ€”evolving through seven deeply emotional stages: attraction, infatuation, surrender, reverence, devotion, obsession, and finally, death. Lisa Haydon did more than model the garment; she became the narrative's visual heartbeat. Her graceful movements and regal presence reflected each stage of Mishra's love story, making the runway moment a meditative performance rather than a mere fashion showcase. Read more: Sangeeta Bijlani: From Miss India to Bollywood Stardom and Beyond Adding to her divine appearance was the elegant jewellery from Tanishq Diamonds's 'Radiance in Rhythm' collection. A bold necklace paired with matching earrings accentuated Lisa's sculpted features, adding sparkle without overshadowing the artistic brilliance of her gown. Her slicked-back hairstyle and understated makeup further amplified the ensemble's romantic and artistic core, allowing the outfit's message of emotional depth and natural beauty to shine through. Lisa's walk wasn't just about haute couture; it was a tribute to Indian artistry, a salute to nature's elegance, and a bold proclamation of love in all its stages. From the choice of fabric to the layered detailing, every element paid homage to Indian craftsmanship, reimagined for a global couture audience. The shimmery florals on her dress were not just embellishmentsâ€”they were metaphors for growth, renewal, and transformation. As one of the most talked-about appearances of the evening, Lisa Haydon's runway moment resonated far beyond fashion circles. Her performance at Paris Haute Couture Week 2025 marked a proud moment for Indian fashion on the international stage. With American rapper Cardi B making a fashionable late entry, the star-studded event gained even more traction and buzz. Rahul Mishra's show was a testament to the power of storytelling through design. The setting, CollÃ¨ge des Bernardins, with its historical reverence, served as the perfect backdrop to narrate Mishra's concept of becoming loveâ€”a journey as spiritual as it is emotional. Lisa Haydon's radiant portrayal of this vision stood out, not just because of her appearance, but for the emotion she channeled with every step. Read more: Bhumi Pednekar's Monochrome David Koma: Sleek Power Dressing Redefined. The ongoing Paris Haute Couture Week, which runs till July 10, is already making headlines with shows by leading fashion houses like Chanel, Giorgio Armani PrivÃ©, Elie Saab, Zuhair Murad, and Balenciaga. Yet, it is moments like Lisa Haydon walking for Rahul Mishra that redefine fashionâ€”not merely as an industry but as a form of expressive, emotional, and cultural art. In the end, Lisa Haydon did not just walk the runwayâ€”she celebrated it. In a setting soaked in history, wearing a creation steeped in tradition and storytelling, she reminded the world that couture can be deeply human. Her presence in Paris was not only a fashion highlight but a celebration of Indian pride and poetic elegance on the world stage.

â€‰ ARTIST'S HOME: The late poet and artist Jean Cocteau could add Loro Piana to his list of fashionable affiliations, which already include Coco Chanel and Elsa Schiaparelli, among others. The Italian luxury house's fall 2025 ad campaign was photographed by Mario Sorrenti inside Villa Santo Sospir, the French intellectual's residence in the south of France surrounded by lush greenery. In keeping with its recent habit of choosing artists' private homes as the backdrop for its campaigns, Loro Piana traveled from Casa das Canoas, the Oscar Niemeyer-designed residence in Brazil that served as the set for the spring campaign, to Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat on the French Riviera. Models Alix Bouthors, Leon Dame, Long Li, Awar Odhiang and Binx Walton are captured enjoying a fictional weekend at the secluded villa, bathed in warm light and filled with artworks, including the murals drawn free hand by the late Cocteau on the walls between windows, above the fireplace and along the circular columns dotting the residence. â€œThe mesmerizing Villa Santo Sospir, with its unique artistic legacy, was the ideal place to shoot Loro Piana's fall 2025 campaign. The tattooed walls of the house perfectly enhanced a collection filled with painterly references of landscapes around the world,â€ Sorrenti said. â€œWhat emerged is an elegant lively ease, an organic flow of shapes, colors and textures, exuding a profound yet effortless sophistication.â€ The fall collection, unveiled during Milan Fashion Week last February, spotlighted the relationship between Loro Piana and nature, which it celebrated by focusing on lands close to its history and precious fibers. The collection's journey touched down in Argentina, the Scottish Highlands, as well as New Zealand and Australia, home of its merino wool, for a refined traveler's wardrobe crafted from top-notch fabrications exuding nonchalant sophistication. The tactile and textured quality of the garments and embroidery is enhanced by the patterned walls and sophisticated decor of the villa in the ad campaign images bowing on Thursday.

If he would analyze himself a bit and look in the mirror he would reslise that if he keeps being more invested in not loosing  sunday'd dungeouns & dragons games, he will definitely necer loose his virginity. Do you know what they do with all those eyeballs? ( Apart from showing them off to their ghetto wasp bros? ) First they play rock-paper-scissors to see who gets the crunchy part of the cornea, literally the only part they eat. The rest? They don't recycle it. No. They have entire eyeball trophy walls in their nests, each with a little name tag, date, location, even the weight. They pose with the eyeballs like influencers showing off a new Chanel bag, post it on Waspagram, hashtags and all. But they don't fool me. I know they're hanging out in parks, smoking real pot, not as in bees honey potsâ€¦those are bee hp ey pots. And bees are alright, a bit arrogant sonetimes, but totallymanageable. Now Wasps? They enslave cockroaches to carry them around like tiny horses because apparently flying is just too mainstream. Like imagine I walked around with a sharp medieval sword sticking out of my ass 24/7, twerking aggressively into people. Would anyone invite me to a birthday party? No, they'd call the police. There was no way I was letting this bastard ruin my Halloween. I'd already bought my slutty police officer costume and wasn't about to switch it for a sad-ass Jack Sparrow. So I snapped. â€œI'm gonna get you, Billy Charles Junior!â€ I yelled. That wasp looked triggered. Only his mom used his full name when she was pissed. I cornered him. He fought back, I'll give him that, but in the end, he took his last buzz. I tried scratching some pieces of Billy off the newspaper, and then looked him in the eyes and whispered, â€œNot so immortal now, huh MF?â€ I could have been talking to his butt gun, I couldnt really guarantee  after a newspaper hit. Judging by the splatter, I probably struck him at 120 waspo-meters an hour. Just enough to cause an instant, painless death, luckilty...

â€‰ Chelsea Odufu is a director and multidisciplinary artist known for crafting bold, culturally-resonant commercial and experiential work. She has directed campaigns for brands such as Dr. Martens, Target, Chase Sapphire, Chanel, Bose, and Walgreens, bringing a cinematic eye and deep storytelling sensibility to every project. Rooted in her background as a visual artist working across film, sculpture, and installation, Chelsea approaches branded work with a distinctive aesthetic and emotional depth. Her fine art practice, which has been exhibited at institutions including the Los Angeles Contemporary Art Museum, The Shed, Dakar Biennale, Christie's London, Seattle Art Museum, and the Harvey Gantt Center, fuels her ability to build immersive worlds that are both conceptually rich and visually striking. Whether creating a film, commercial, or a full-scale brand experience, her work always centres story, soul, and style. Name: Chelsea Odufu Location: USA Repped by/in: Chromista LBB> What elements of a script set one apart from another, and what sort of scripts get you excited to shoot them? Chelsea> For me, it's always about the feeling underneath the script. A great one speaks through the page â€“ it pulses with rhythm, imagery, and soul. If it has a clear sense of world, tone, and emotional stakes, I'm in. Scripts that feel alive and allow for layered visual interpretation or world-building are what excite me most. I'm drawn to scripts that carry a heartbeat â€“ ones that don't just tell a story, but vibrate with cultural, emotional, or spiritual texture. LBB> How do you approach creating a treatment for a spot? Chelsea> I treat it like an invitation into a new reality. I start with tone â€“ how should this feel in the body? From there, I build a visual language, often weaving in references from fashion, music videos, cultural images, architecture, or nature. I anchor everything in intention, then structure the treatment almost like a visual essay. It's less about selling and more about conjuring: helping people feel the frequency of the story before it's even shot. LBB> If the script is for a brand you're unfamiliar with or a market you're new to, how important is it for you to do research and understand that strategic and contextual side of the ad? How do you do it? Chelsea> It's crucial. I can't authentically express something unless I understand the world it lives in. I'll research the brand's visual history, voice, mission, and market presence, but I also dig deeper. Who are they really talking to? What's not being said? I want to understand both the culture and the counterculture. I spend time watching their audience, listening to the tone of the streets, and tuning into what resonates emotionally in that space. LBB> For you, what is the most important working relationship for a director to have with another person in making an ad? And why? Chelsea> The creative director or lead agency voice is key. That relationship sets the tone for everything else. It's where trust, flow, and respect for the core idea live. When that relationship is strong, it creates space for experimentation, clarity, and alignment so the idea can evolve in the best way possible. But I also really value my relationship with the DoP because, together, we translate spirit into image. LBB> What type of work are you most passionate about? Is there a particular genre, subject matter, or style you're most drawn to? Chelsea> I'm most drawn to work that merges the metaphysical with the sensory: futurism, mysticism, identity, memory. I love when visual storytelling allows you to slip between dimensions, whether it's through surrealism, rhythmic editing, or symbolic world-building. I'm excited by cultural specificity, movement, intimacy, and anything that centres the experience of those who often live in the margins. LBB> What misconception about you or your work do you most often encounterâ€”and why is it wrong? Chelsea> People sometimes assume my work is too artistic or too experimental to sell a product. That's a misconception. I believe deep feeling, cultural richness, and visual poetry are what move audiences. I've proven you can make work that's emotive, visually distinct, and aligned with the brand without compromising vision. We don't have to dilute the magic for it to be effective. LBB> Have you ever worked with a cost consultant and if so, how have your experiences been? Chelsea> Yes, and when approached collaboratively, they can be invaluable. I welcome anyone who helps us stay grounded in reality, especially when building ambitious or nontraditional concepts....

â€‰ NEED TO KNOW Keira Knightley and her husband James Righton made a rare public appearance together at the Chanel Haute Couture Fall/Winter 2025/2026 show in Paris on Tuesday, July 8 The couple have kept their relationship out of the public eye, and one of their last sightings together was in July 2024 at Wimbledon Knightly and Righton wed in 2013 and celebrated their 12 year wedding anniversary in May Keira Knightley and her husband James Righton had a date night! The couple made a rare public appearance together at the Chanel Haute Couture Fall/Winter 2025/2026 show in Paris on Tuesday, July 8 â€” where the Black Doves star, 40, dressed to up to the nines for the occasion. Knightley wore a black halter panel dress with white ribbon print and paired it with a black leather clutch and black leather heels. The star's cropped hair was done up in sleek light waves as she posed alongside her beau, who wrapped an arm around her waist. As for Righton, he donned a blue striped button up with a matching dark blue jacket and pants. He completed the look with black leather loafers and a golden watch on his left wrist. Swan Gallet/WWD via Getty Keira Knightley, James Righton at the Chanel show as part of Haute Couture Fall/Winter 2025 on July 08, 2025 in Paris, France. Knightly and Righton â€” who wed in 2013 and share two children: Edie, 9, and Delilah, 4 â€” have kept their relationship out of the public eye for several years, only making appearances here and there. The pair were previously spotted at the Wimbledon quarterfinals in London in July 2024, and at the ERDEM & Gay's The Word Pride Cocktail on July 3, 2025, in London. The pair, who celebrated their 12th wedding anniversary in May, previously revealed during the Ruthie's Table 4 podcast in August 2024 that she met her husband not long after her agent told her he had dreamed she would soon meet her future husband. "So that week my agent said to me, 'I've had this dream â€“ I was single â€“ I've had a dream that you're meeting your future husband this week,' and I was like, 'That's exciting,' " she shared. "So I got invited out to loads of things and I have to say I'd met a load of people that week and I was like, this isn't happening." Knightley recalled that she decided to attend an Academy Awards viewing party that she otherwise did not care to attend in the hopes she would meet somebody. Initially, the event proved a bust, until her friend Tim Phillips called and told her he would come by with friends. Arnold Jerocki/GC Images James Righton and Keira Knightley in Paris, France. Never miss a story â€” sign up forÂ PEOPLE's free daily newsletterÂ to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offerâ€‹â€‹, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. "Anyway, the door of this private room opens and my friend Tim's head comes around [with another friend] and the third head to come around was James," she said. "And James grabbed a seat and said, 'Hello, I'm your future husband,' and there he is. And we basically ate and drank until we got married. Well, drank until I got pregnant.â€ The Atonement actress also noted that she and Righton also had timing going for them. She said on the joint podcast that she thinks she and Righton would never have begun dating if she had not acted in a play based in London. More in Celebrity "It was great because it was a bunch of girls, we were all in our early [to] mid-twenties," Knightley said. "We were all single and we were having a really, really, really, really good time and so I met [James] in the middle of that when he was also having a really, really, really, really good time."

â€‰ The filmmaker and her musician husband, Thomas Mars, share children Romy and Cosima Michelle Lee Link copied Swan Gallet/WWD via Getty Cosima Mars, Sofia Coppola and Romy Mars attend the Chanel Fall/Winter 2025 couture show in Paris NEED TO KNOW Sofia Coppola turned the Chanel runway show into a family affair alongside her two daughters, Romy Mars and Cosima Mars On July 8, the trio were among the stars sitting front row for the Paris Haute Couture Fashion Week event, dressed in coordinating pastel outfits Sofia welcomed Romy and Cosima with her husband Thomas Mars in 2006 and 2010 respectively All eyes were on Sofia Coppola and her family at Paris Fashion Week. The filmmaker and Oscar winner, 54, stepped out for a rare outing alongside her daughters, Romy and Cosima Mars, at the Chanel Haute Couture Fall/Winter 2025 fashion show on July 8. Inspired by the brand, the trio wore coordinating pastel looks with a preppy twist to the star-studded front row, which also housed Lorde, Gracie Abrams, Keira Knightley and Kirsten Dunst, who starred in multiple of Coppola's films, including 1999's The Virgin Suicides. Stephane Cardinale - Corbis/Corbis via Getty Romy Mars, Sofia Coppola and Cosima Mars at Paris Fashion Week As the matriarch, Coppola wore a laid-back look featuring a gray T-shirt layered under a round-collar baby blue jacket teamed with white pants, a chainlink shoulder bag and slingback heels. Romy, 18, selected a baby blue minidress teamed with black ankle-strap heels, silver jewelry and a quilted clutch, while Cosima, 15, went for a baby pink co-ord and block heels. The teens also showed off their personalized glam. While Romy opted for a dramatic eyeliner look and a romantic half-up hairstyle with curled ends, Cosima decided to match her outfit with blush pink makeup. Coppola â€” who welcomed Romy in November 2006 and Cosima in May 2010 with her husband and Phoenix lead singer, Thomas Mars â€” has largely kept her family life out of the limelight, though has opened up about motherhood in past interviews. â€œI'm always asking working mothers questions,â€ she told PEOPLE at the 2010 screening of her film Somewhere. â€œI'm trying to figure it all out because I feel like I'm just learning," she said, adding that "having a really great nanny to help me while I'm working so I don't worry and know that they're taken care of [is key].â€ Never miss a story â€” sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offerâ€‹â€‹, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. Romy Mars/Instagram Sofia Coppola with her two daughters The PEOPLE App is now available in the Apple App Store! Download it now for the most binge-worthy celeb content, exclusive video clips, astrology updates and more! Years, later Coppola told the The Guardian in 2017 that she chose to keep her children out of the public eye because, "I don't want them ever to be jaded," she explained. â€œI never saw the point of taking little kids to movie premieres and stuff. I just want them to have a childhood.â€ Yet, recently Romy in particular, has been making her own mark on Hollywood. She attend a Marc Jacobs fashion show with Coppola in February 2020 before making her modeling debut in a Heaven by Marc Jacobs campaign later that year. And while she was previously known to not have public social media accounts, Romy went viral on TikTok in 2023 for sharing that she'd been grounded because she "tried to charter a helicopter from New York to Maryland" on her dad's credit card. The video has since been deleted. Romy also started her music career in 2024, releasing singles "From a Distance" and "Stuck Up." This past May, she debuted her recent track, "A-Lister," a pop song she co-wrote that features tongue-in-cheek commentary on the surface-level lifestyles of the rich and famous. Read the original article on People

And while she was previously known to not have public social media accounts, Romy went viral on TikTok in 2023 for sharing that she'd been grounded because she "tried to charter a helicopterÂ from New York to Maryland" on her dad's credit card. â€‰ PARIS (AP) â€” Only Chanel would call its legendary Rue Cambon salon â€œtoo smallâ€ â€” then rebuild it, supersized, in a palace. On Tuesday, as the house marked 110 years of its haute couture â€” a century and more of Coco Chanel's revolution in how women dress â€” it blew up its atelier as a giant set inside the freshly restored Grand Palais, turning intimacy into spectacle for a nature-drenched show at Paris Couture Week. Chanel, whose founder banished corsets and reimagined luxury as liberation, showed just how far that legacy stretches â€” from the tiny salons of 1915 to its modern colossus. It was a flex only a handful of luxury giants could pull off â€” and perhaps, as one front-row guest suggested, a dazzling distraction as the fashion world counts down to the debut of Chanel's new designer Matthieu Blazy. PenÃ©lope Cruz, Keira Knightley, Naomi Campbell, Kirsten Dunst and the house's tightest VIP circle scaled gilded steps, sweating past marble and gold, to enter the reconstructed atelier. The set by Willo Perron was classic Chanel â€” intimate yet monumental, Old World yet futuristic. â€œIt just felt special,â€ Campbell said, â€œlike stepping into a memory and something completely new. There's warmth, intimacy, nostalgia. Chanel can recreate anything, and it works." Chanel goes country More drama unfolded on the runway. This was couture as nature fantasy, filtered through the Chanel prism. Menswear tailoring added swing to sculpted jackets and coatdresses, while mohair suits in deep greens and plums channeled autumn's hush. BouclÃ© tweeds mimicked sheepskin; feathers and tweed created illusionary faux fur. Gold-sprayed wheat ears â€” the house symbol of abundance â€” were everywhere: stitched into flounces, embroidered on necklines, set on every guest's seat. The theme may have been country, but make no mistake: This was as close as Chanel gets to â€œroughing it.â€ Technique dazzled at every turn: jewel-buttons, embroidered florals and a finale of lamÃ© so luminous it mimicked sunlight on harvest fields. The studio team, holding the fort after Virginie Viard's abrupt and unceremonious exit last year, anchored the show in classic codes but played with wit and lightness. That obsessive handwork matters â€” not just for tradition, but for business. Chanel is fashion's juggernaut: Privately held, the brand reported $18.7 billion in revenue for 2024, cementing its status as one of the world's most powerful luxury houses. Couture may be the crown, but its influence drives global sales in fragrance, bags and jewelry, making it the envy of rivals. New era for the luxury giant Change is always looming at Chanel. For more than 30 years, Karl Lagerfeld transformed the brand from Parisian legend to pop phenomenon, staging ever-grander spectacles at the Grand Palais. After his death in 2019, Viard, his longtime deputy, guided Chanel into a softer, more discreet era. Now the industry is holding its breath for Blazy, a Belgian talent with stints at Margiela, Celine and most recently Bottega Veneta, where he won fans for his blend of innovation and reverence for craft. Campbell said of Blazy, whom she knows personally: â€œHe's focused, open-minded â€” he'll bring something special.â€ Tuesday's show unfolded inside the Grand Palais' newly restored Salon d'Honneur, its gold and stone revealed after a 600-million-euro, multiyear restoration co-funded by Chanel. It's more than a venue; it's an advertisement of the house's power and commitment to Parisian heritage. Thomas Adamson, The Associated Press

â€‰ Have YOU got a story? Email tips@dailymail.com Sofia Coppola brought along her two teenage daughters to Tuesday's Chanel Haute Couture Fall/Winter 2025-2026 fashion show. Romy, 18, towered over the Priscilla director whileÂ Cosima, 15, also stood slightly taller than their 54-year-old mother. The filmmaker stands at 5'4" without shoes, but the women all added height to their frames with classic round-toe Chanel heels. Sofia - who starred in The Godfather Part III -Â  was dressed in a heather gray top, subtly patterned sky blue jacket, and white trousers. She accessorized with a quilted white Chanel purse, and her shoulder-length bob was styled in a side part and loose waves. Her children were equally fashionable, with her firstborn child clad in a pale blue shift dress with a fringed hemline. She toted a tiny, matching pastel box purse while punctuating the ensemble with Mary Jane style shoes. Romy's younger sister opted for a pink mini dress with a matching cardigan, adding two-toned slingback footwear. Speaking to Vogue after the Chanel presentation, Romy called it 'the most beautiful show.' Sofia shares her brood with longtime husbandÂ Thomas Mars, who is the lead singer of the band Phoenix. Their older daughter made headlines in 2023 when she went viral for revealing that her parents grounded her for trying to charter a helicopter. At the time, she'd uploaded a clip to TikTok explaining that she was punished for attempting to use her dad's credit card to fly from New York to Maryland 'to have dinner with my camp friend.' Romy shared that she was killing her time at home by making a vodka pasta sauce. In the clip she also admitted that her parents' 'biggest rule' was that she was not allowed to have public social media. 'But TikTok's not going to make me famous, so it doesn't really matter,' she rationalized. Her mother Sofia, who is known for fiercely protecting her family's privacy, later told The Hollywood Reporter she was 'not thrilled' about the viral moment. 'She's funny,' she said. ' But people discussing my parenting publicly is not what I would've hoped for.' In May Romy showcased her music ambitions as she released a catchy soft-pop tune called A-lister. And the nepo baby enlisted none other than her mother to direct its accompanying music video. Despite her previous claim that she was not permitted to have public social media accounts, she now has a public Instagram page with 160,000 followers.

â€‰ "Hearst Magazines and Yahoo may earn commission or revenue on some items through these links." It's safe to say that Sofia Coppola just scored major cool mom points. This morning, the Oscar-winning director attended the Chanel Couture fall/winter 2025 presentation in Paris and was joined by her two teenage daughters: Romy, 18, and Cosima, 15. Marking a rare appearance, the mother-daughter trio sat front row as they watched the Chanel in-house team's final collection ahead of Matthieu Blazy's takeover. Coppola and her daughters, Romy and Cosima, were decked out in head-to-toe Chanel. Stephane Cardinale - Corbis - The matriarch and longtime Chanel ambassador wore a subdued outfit consisting of white jeans, a gray t-shirt and a collarless blue jacket, while her daughtersâ€”whom she shares with French musician Thomas Marsâ€”opted for a more colorful palette for their Chanel couture front-row debut. Romy wore a sleeveless blue knit mini dress, while her younger sister wore a pink waffle knit mini dress with a coordinating cropped cardigan. All three accessorized with Chanel cap-toe shoes and bags. Romy, a rising musician on social media, shared a of her getting ready with her glam squad, who created her dramatic winged eye look and half updo. Also sitting front row with the Coppola-Mars' was Kirsten Dunst, Coppola's frequent collaborator. The actress kept her look simple, wearing an all-black outfit. The Coppola-Mars' were joined by Kirsten Dunst at the presentation. WWD - Today's outing comes just days Romy and Cosima also joined their mom at the Le Bal d'Ã‰tÃ©, a summer ball which Coppola art directed at the MusÃ©e des Arts DÃ©coratifs to kick off Couture Week. The girls have been making more and more appearances as of late since reaching their teenage years. Earlier this year, Cosima attended Anna Sui and Marc Jacob shows during New York Fashion Week, while Romy joined her grandfather, Francis Ford Coppola, at Cannes last year for the premiere of Megalopolis. Coppola, who comes from Hollywood royalty herself, has famously valued privacy and raising her daughters outside of the Hollywood spotlight. She previously opened up about how being private â€œseems normal to meâ€ and how she was â€œraised to be so private.â€ That, however, went out the door in 2023 when Romy went viral on TikTok after she was grounded for trying to charter a helicopter so she can have dinner with a camp friend. The outing marked a rare appearance for Coppola's daughters (here, Romy). WWD - Months later, Coppola commented on the incident, telling the Hollywood Reporter that â€œsocial media is so opposite of how I grew upâ€ and â€œit was the best way for her to be rebellious." "I got a lot of compliments on her filmmaking. And comedy,â€ Coppola added. â€œShe's funny. But people discussing my parenting publicly is not what I would've hoped for.â€

â€‰ Chanel's Golden Couture Shines During Paris Haute Couture Week Chanel returned to the Grand Palais this morning for its Fall 2025 haute couture collection, held in the venue's Salon d'Honneur during Paris Haute Couture Week. Inspired by the simplicity of nature and Chanel's 31 rue Cambon ateliers, the line was the last created by the label's in-house team before new creative director Matthieu Blazy's first runway debuts in October. Tweed skirt suits, separates, and dresses were crafted in smooth knits and soft mohair, cast in tonal shades of deep gold, cream, plum, black, and dark green. Added levity came from multicolored flowers, seen in embroidery on dresses and coats. Wheat earsâ€”which Gabrielle Chanel saw as a symbol of abundanceâ€”were prominent throughout the collection, embroidered across dresses, embossed on sparkling buttons, and clutched in a golden bouquet held by the show's finale bride. A star-studded crowd was in attendance for the occasion as well, including Lorde, Gracie Abrams, Keira Knightley, Naomi Campbell, Laufey, Kirsten Dunst, Sofia Coppola, Romy Mars, Cosima Mars, Marion Cotillard, and more. All images: Courtesy of Chanel Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman, and Neiman Marcus Face Dropping Summer Sales It's shaping up to be a challenging sales year for luxury brandsâ€”including Saks Fifth Avenue. The retailer, which merged earlier this year with Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman in a $2.7 billion deal, has faced a sales drop of 28% compared to 2024, according to The Business of Fashion. Alongside Saks, Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf's sales also dropped 26% each compared to last year. The shift follows Saks Global's release of its financial performance in May, where the combined revenue of Saks, Neiman's, and Bergdorf's dropped 10% to $7.3 billion. The group's low sales also follow the luxury slowdown of 2024 that's continued into 2025, with decreasing sales affecting brands including Chanel, HermÃ¨s, Gucci, Burberry, and more. Saks Fifth Avenue (Shutterstock) Role Model Fronts VMan's July 2025 Issue VMan has a brand-new cover star: Role Model (AKA Travis Pillsbury). The musician covers the magazine's new July 2025 issue, outfitted in Calvin Klein's denim and sharp separates. While speaking with writer Charlie Kolbrener in his accompanying feature profile, Role Model chats about the rerelease of his album Kansas Anymore, new role in Lena Dunham's upcoming Netflix film Good Sex, and friendship with fellow star Gracie Abramsâ€”who he's also touring with this year. â€œShe was one of the first people I met and hung around with when I first moved to LA, and was just very welcoming,â€ Pillsbury said. â€œShe was about to put out her first EP Minor. I feel like I've had the privilege of watching her from that very beginning moment to now doing massive arena shows around the world and exploding, rightfully so. It's cool now, I get to watch it side stage. It's a very full circle moment for me personally. The dynamic pair's resulting line explores themes ofÂ futurism, New York City culture, and modern Black identity. Their collection features video game-inspired graphic prints across a colorful tank top, two T-shirts, and a collaborative version of Jacobs' signature Sack handbag. All images: Courtesy of Marc Jacobs TSA Is Phasing Out Its Shoe Removal Policy During Airport Check-In Tired of taking your shoes off during TSA check-in? You might not have to for much longer! The policy, which has existed at U.S. airports from the Transportation Security Administration since 2006, is being phased out this year, according to People. Some airports have already let passengers keep their shoes on while checking in, including Baltimore/Washington International Airport, Portland International Airport, Philadelphia International Airport, Fort Lauderdale International Airport, Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport, and Piedmont Triad International Airport. As of Monday, the New York City's LaGuardia Airport and Los Angeles International Airport have also apparently begun implanting the new policy as well. However, if passengers' shoes trigger security scanners, they will still have to remove their shoes to be screened. (firstVIEW) Additional reporting by Julia Karns and Katie Bradshaw. â€‰ Carole Bouquet is a French legend, and the former Bond girl is looking better than ever these days. Best known for her role as Melina Havelock opposite Roger Moore as James Bond in 1981's For Your Eyes Only, the model and actress went on to be the face of Chanel No. 5, the French fashion house's most famous perfume. That's why it's no surprise to see her at their Fall/Winter 2025/2026 fashion show as part of Paris Fashion Week on Tuesday in Paris, France. While it's a delight to see Bouquet, 67, at the show, the stunner isn't always spotted at big events. However, she looked better than ever in a glittering suit with drop earrings and black sandals. (Photo by Stephane Cardinale - Corbis/Corbis via ) (Photo by Stephane Cardinale - Corbis/Corbis via ) SIGN UP for Parade's Daily newsletter to get the latest pop culture news & celebrity interviews delivered right to your inbox Of course, Bouquet's acting career is still thriving. She made waves with a cameo on Sex and the City as Aleksandr Petrovsky's ex-wife, but has had endless roles in everything from In Therapy to Apple TV+'s recent French-language series, La Maison. But no matter the role, it's safe to say that Bouquet is still having plenty of fun. In a 2014 interview for the Cannes Film Festival, she reflected on how much pleasure she gets from tackling diverse roles. "For me, cinema is like a keyhole through which we can find out what is happening in the world. I grew up and discovered life through film. Films also have to get people engaged and the films we are going to see are, in my opinion, very engaged. For me cinema remains an art," she explained. â€‰ I would argue against Wonder  Woman being a magical girl, because she is an Amazon, a superhero, a demi-goddessâ€¦ Not a magical girl. Demi-goddess and goddess aren't magical girl, including in Japan, nor are Scarlet Witch, or Ms Marvel, and other mutants or Inhumans even with transformations. I think the Â«Â magical girlÂ Â» we consider first in  Western world need to be among creations post the creation and cementing of é­”æ³•å°‘å¥³. Magical girl genre came from Japan and our definition of it comes from it. Otherwise if if the definition simply stops at Â«Â  girl with powers, and possibly change costumesÂ Â» we could literally go up to Antiquity myth, if not prehistory myth And Japan could technically also go back for millenias prior Anyway I think Magical Girl appeared as a genre in 60-70's ? I am really not sure but on the top of my head for western genre I would say Princess Gwenevere and the Jewel Riders. I remember them transforming and having their superpowers from the jewels they haveâ€¦. Edit : I checked on the first magical girls and I think we can also basically ignore any witch who doesn't uses a wand or something to chanel a power and/or that transform (the latter isnnt necessary though). So basically the western witches like MCU Agatha or Sabrina or Halliwell sisters also don't fit ? â€‰ Chanel Fall Winter 2025-26 Haute Couture â€œIn the Silence of the Fieldsâ€. Story by Eleonora de Gray, Editor-in-Chief of RUNWAY MAGAZINE: https://t.co/DGrqIfbFZQ #Chanel #Runway #HauteCouture #Chanelshow #EleonoradeGray #PFW #RunwayMagazine https://t.co/rvO6xJy7JX

â€‰ The Chanel haute couture show began the day on a soft note â€” or pillows, rather. Held in an upper gallery of the Grand Palais, the setting featured plush velvet sofas and muted light, as an homage to Coco Chanel's salon. It was more apartment than runway, and the stars in attendance seemed to melt into its giant couches. â€œThis room is, first of all, the most comfortable room I think I've ever seen a fashion show in,â€ said Kirsten Dunst, still shaking off jet lag and adjusting to Paris time. With two kids at home in L.A., she keeps a tight schedule and the actress said she hadn't found her equilibrium quite yet, having arrived before the Bal d'Ã‰tÃ© on Sunday. Dunst, who's marking the 25th anniversary of Sofia Coppola's â€œThe Virgin Suicides,â€ reflected on the film's new life via TikTok. â€œFor it to live on in the way that it has is so meaningful,â€ she said, as it grabs the attention of another generation. Her second collaboration with Coppola, â€œMarie Antoinette,â€ has also been rediscovered by Gen Z, often prompting teen girls to DM her with questions about the French queen, she said. â€œIt's probably more accepted and relevant because of the times we're in,â€ she added. â€œIndie films, like when 'Virgin Suicides' came out, were more male dominated, and judged â€” like who were the reviewers?â€ she said, reflecting on the cultural shift. Dunst has two new projects back to back: â€œThe Entertainment System Is Down,â€ the latest from two-time Palme d'Or winner Ruben Ã–stlund, and â€œRoofman,â€ a heist dramedy costarring Channing Tatum. More in Entertainment The former is set on a plane filled with bored passengers, and filming predates TikTok's â€œraw doggingâ€ travel trend, where users document themselves braving long flights without entertainment. â€œRuben is always a few steps ahead,â€ Dunst said, noting the project's surreal tone and ensemble cast, including Keanu Reeves. â€œIt was such a singular experience I don't think anything else will compare.â€ The film will be hoping for a Cannes berth. â€œYou know Ruben, he wants that third Palme,â€ she joked. Coppola, seated with daughters Romy and Cosima Mars, who is currently interning at Chanel, presented â€œThe Virgin Suicidesâ€ at the Louvre last week and the Biarritz film festival over the weekend. â€œI'm glad it holds up,â€ she said of the film's enduring legacy. She recently directed a video for budding musician Romy â€” though she said she was only following Romy's cues â€” and revealed she and Dunst are eyeing another film collaboration, with details still under wraps. Coppola likened TikTok to the DIY spirit of '90s indie 'zines. â€œIt's something I don't understand, but it's fun to see how creative they are,â€ she said. â€œIf it had been around, I probably would've filmed for it.â€ Keira Knightley also noted an anniversary. Her Jane Austen adaptation â€œPride & Prejudiceâ€ celebrated its 20th anniversary earlier this year, which set off a slew of essays and think pieces about its enduring cultural significance. But the actress hasn't watched it in as many years. â€œIf my kids are ever interested in watching it, maybe I will,â€ she said. â€œSo far, they're just absolutely anti watching me in anything.â€ She recently wrapped â€œThe Woman in Cabin 10,â€ a psychological thriller shot aboard a luxury superyacht. It was an experience she found somewhat less than luxe. â€œIt was a little snug,â€ Knightley said, of 100-plus cast and crew on board. â€œI think it put me off the yachting experience for a while.â€ PenÃ©lope Cruz, another Chanel ambassador and longtime devotee of the brand, visited the atelier the day before. â€œSome gowns take over 800 hours to make,â€ she said. The Oscar-winner recalled sewing with her grandmother as a child â€” a ritual that took ages but â€œfelt almost meditativeâ€ and created a bond across generations. â€œIt's really beautiful that a brand like Chanel keeps fighting to maintain that,â€ she said. â€œEverything nowadays is instant gratification. If we don't preserve the things that require time and rhythm, we lose something.â€ Cruz is also starring in two upcoming films: first, â€œThe Bride,â€ directed by Maggie Gyllenhaal, and â€œThe Invite,â€ by Olivia Wilde. The former offers a new twist on the traditional Frankenstein tale. â€œShe's done something so new and wild and rock 'n' roll,â€ Cruz said. She plays a detective with mixed feelings about the monster she's hunting. She's also directing her first documentary, a project two years in the making. â€œIt's a very important story to me,â€ she said, though keeping mum for now. â€œI didn't want misunderstandings about what it is.â€ She's buckling down in the editing studio this fall, aiming for a cut by spring. Naomi Campbell was coiffed in a New Romantics-style '80s pouf. â€œI love '80s pop. It's my time, my era,â€ she said, though she's currently vibing to Burna Boy and Wizkid....

â€‰ Perfume, derived from the Latin phrase *per fumum* meaning â€œthrough smoke,â€ has been an integral part of human civilization for millennia. Used in rituals, medicine, personal grooming, and status display, perfume is a sensory art form that has evolved with human culture. From its sacred origins in ancient Egypt to its widespread availability in today's global market, the story of perfume is as rich and layered as the fragrances themselves. # Ancient Beginnings: Egypt and the Cradle of Fragrance The earliest known use of perfume dates back to ancient Egypt, around 3000 BCE. Fragrance held a profound spiritual significance for the Egyptians. Perfumes were used in religious ceremonies, embalming processes, and as offerings to the gods. Fragrant oils and incense were considered a bridge between the earthly and the divine. Temples were often filled with scented smoke from burning myrrh, frankincense, and kyphi, a complex blend of resins, herbs, and honey. Wealthy Egyptians applied perfumed oils to their bodies not only for personal enjoyment but to mask body odor and protect their skin from the harsh desert climate. Perfume also signified social and spiritual status. Pharaohs were often buried with jars of precious scented oils and incense to accompany them into the afterlife. Archaeological evidence, such as the discovery of perfume vessels in tombs and artistic depictions on temple walls, attests to the deep-rooted significance of fragrance in Egyptian life. # The Influence of Mesopotamia, India, and China Simultaneously, other ancient civilizations developed their own perfumery traditions. In Mesopotamia, cuneiform tablets from around 1200 BCE describe the distillation of aromatic substances. Tapputi, a Mesopotamian woman mentioned on a cuneiform tablet, is often considered the world's first recorded chemist and perfumer. In ancient India, perfumery was closely tied to Ayurvedic medicine. The *Charaka Samhita* and other ancient texts describe aromatic oils and their therapeutic uses. Sandalwood, vetiver, and jasmine were commonly used in spiritual rituals and personal adornment. In China, fragrances were incorporated into traditional medicine, religious ceremonies, and daily life by the Han dynasty. Perfumed sachets were used not just for scent but also to ward off disease, aligning with Taoist and Confucian practices. # The Greek and Roman World: Perfume as Luxury and Science The Greeks adopted and refined Egyptian perfumery techniques, adding their own innovations. Theophrastus, a student of Aristotle, wrote one of the earliest known treatises on scent in his work *On Odors*. Greek perfumers began experimenting with infusions of aromatic materials in oils, laying the groundwork for modern techniques. The Romans expanded the reach and popularity of perfume across the empire. Fragrances became a daily indulgence among the elite, who used them in baths, cosmetics, and even to scent walls and fountains. Pliny the Elder lamented the excesses of Roman society's obsession with perfume, noting the massive importation of ingredients from across the empire. Roman innovations in glassmaking also helped in the development of more advanced storage vessels for perfume, making it easier to transport and preserve delicate fragrances. # The Islamic Golden Age: Science Meets Scent With the fall of the Roman Empire and the rise of the Islamic caliphates, perfume culture shifted eastward. Between the 8th and 13th centuries, Islamic scholars made monumental contributions to perfumery. Avicenna (Ibn Sina), a Persian polymath, is credited with perfecting the process of distillationâ€”particularly steam distillationâ€”which allowed for the extraction of essential oils from flowers like roses. Fragrance was deeply embedded in Islamic culture, inspired by religious teachings that emphasized cleanliness and the use of pleasant scents. Perfumes were used in mosques, homes, and daily life. Markets in cities like Baghdad, Cairo, and Cordoba offered an array of fragrant materials: musk, ambergris, oud, rose, and spices from across the known world. This period also saw the writing of sophisticated treatises on the preparation and blending of perfumes, making fragrance both an art and a science. # The Renaissance and the Birth of Modern Perfumery in Europe Perfume re-entered Western Europe through trade with the Middle East and North Africa, becoming a symbol of wealth and refinement among the European aristocracy. The 14th century saw the development of â€œHungary Water,â€ one of the first alcohol-based perfumes, made for Queen Elizabeth of Hungary. This innovation marked a shift from oil-based to alcohol-based perfumes, which were lighter and evaporated more quickly. By the 16th century, France had become a center of perfume production. Italian perfumers, invited by Catherine de' Medici, brought their skills to the French court. Grasse, a town in southern France, soon emerged as the epicenter of the European fragrance industry due to its ideal climate for growing flowers like lavender, rose, and jasmine. Perfume use flourished in the French court under Louis XIV, who was famously known as the "Perfume King." Scented gloves, handkerchiefs, and wigs became fashionable among nobles, and entire rooms were perfumed to mask the unpleasant odors of urban life. # Industrialization and Global Expansion The 19th century ushered in industrialization, revolutionizing perfumery through synthetic chemistry. Scientists isolated aromatic compounds such as vanillin and coumarin, enabling perfumers to create consistent, affordable fragrances....

â€‰ Third Time's the Charm is not only the name of a new restaurant opening in Red Hook: It is also the story of Chris Milazzo, a so-called â€œrecovering lawyer,â€ who launched the pizza pop-up Bad Cholesterol a couple of years ago, and became a fixture at Talea taproom. He's now on his third act, opening an actual restaurant, targeting a September opening. â€œWe're thinking of Charm as a supper club for the rest of us,â€ Milazzo said in a press release. â€œNo membership fees. No celebs. Just a place to tuck in, put your elbows up, and befriend the bartenders.â€ Sourdough pizza will, of course, continue to play a role, but the menu will also veer into other childhood favorites, like a riff on the Bloomin' Onion and chicken nuggets. Third Time's the Charm is joined by partner Sean Klim (who was in the kitchen at Bad Cholesterol and chef Sam Savage (who also worked on the pop-up). It replaces what was operator Erin Norris' longtime restaurant Grindhaus, there since 2013, and which had more recently rebranded to OurHaus, at 275 Van Brunt Street, near Visitation Place, in Brooklyn. This Williamsburg diner will be torn down Shame on Williamsburg developer Yoel Schwimmer, who will tear down the last-of-its-kind diner storefront at 221 Wythe Avenue, in the process of turning the lot into a mixed-use building, Crain's New York reports. It's a fate this space has long been waiting for. What was once Wythe Diner has been vacant for years, but it was an architectural feat with its standalone structure in a neighborhood dominated by a sea of new towers. We held out hope that another restaurant would eventually reopen there: From 1997 until 2010, it was a restaurant called Relish. In 2011, Cafe de La Esquina opened before shutting in 2018. Then, as these things go, Blank Street Coffee ran an outdoor coffee cart in the backyard in 2020. In 2023, lights were turned on again by a limited-run activation by Chanel, symbolizing the way the neighborhood is getting gentrified into a luxury district. Large dumpling chain lands in Manhattan Originating in China, with 800 locations abroad, Dumpling Xi has added a second location in New York, following its debut in Flushing a couple of months ago. Now, Dumpling Xi â€” which originated in Hegang in 2002 â€” has opened at 71 Fourth Avenue, at East 10th Street, in the East Village. A menu includes dumplings with fillings like zucchini-egg-fried-shrimp, shrimp-fish-roe, and pork-celery. Bring back Soeun When Soeun, the SoHo macrobiotic restaurant, closed in 2019 after first opening in 1971, it prompted public outcry. Following the closing of Lola Taverna, the most recent tenant in the space, a tacky Greek clubstaurant, actress ChloÃ« Sevigny posted on Instagram stories this week asking, â€œIf anyone had a lifeline to bring back Soeun.â€ For what it's worth, there's still a Soeun in the East Village, but it's not the same.

â€‰ 6 Content Marketing Conferences to Attend in 2025 But sometimes, it's a great idea to leave the desk and socialize with other human beingsâ€”ideally on your employer's dime 6 Content Marketing Conferences to Attend in 2025 Article Performance Data from Ahrefs The number of websites linking to this post. This post's estimated monthly organic search traffic. As content marketers, we spend most of our time sitting in front of a screen, buried in a Google Doc. But sometimes, it's a great idea to leave the desk and socialize with other human beingsâ€”ideally on your employer's dime ğŸ˜‰ Conferences are a great excuse to hang out with other content marketers, talk shop, learn some new tricks, and learn how to do less work today with generative AI. Without further ado, here are the biggest and best content marketing conferences happening throughout the rest of 2025. Dates: August 24-26 Think of CEX as the â€œbuild-and-monetize-your-audienceâ€ bootcamp. Founded by Joe Pulizzi (the guy who literally wrote the book on content marketing), the show is laser-focused on turning writers, podcasters, and video creators into full-blown business owners. Expect success-story keynotes, brutally honest revenue breakdowns, and tactical breakouts on newsletters, community, and productized services. Notable sessions include: Dates: September 3-5 Hosted by content marketing OG HubSpot, INBOUND offers hundreds of talks, deep dives, fireside chats, and meetups on topics ranging from brand strategy to AI. Here's the recap video: You can even watch their previous years' talks on their INBOUND YouTube channel. For example, here's HubSpot co-founder Dharmesh Shah's talk from INBOUND 2024: Dates: September 15-17 Arguably the content marketing conference, Content Marketing World has been pumping out content talks and inspiration for fifteen years solid. Here's last year's recap: Some notable talks from the upcoming CM World 2025 include: Dates: October 2-3 What used to be a single day event in London has expanded to a 2-day event in Manchester, UK, hosted by ProCopywriters (a membership community for copywriters.) Intended for copywriters, creatives, and content strategists, the agenda focuses heavily on the qualitative aspects of content that often go overlookedâ€”creative processes, tone of voice, and creating emotional connections through copy. This year's talks include sessions like: Dates: October 5-8 LavaCon is a content conference with a very technical focus, with over 70 sessions dedicated to helping companies solve â€œcontent-related business problems, increase revenue, and decrease production costsâ€. In practice, that means speakers from Netflix, Lockheed Martin, Cisco, Salesforce, and JPMorgan Chase, and topics like: Dates: October 14-15 2024 was the launch of our first ever fully-fledged SEO and digital marketing conference: Ahrefs Evolve. (Read about how we planned and organized the entire conference here.) Check out a recap of how 2024's Ahrefs Evolve went: This year, we've decided to move our conference to the U.S! This time round, it won't just be an SEO conference; we're going bigger and beyond and getting the best marketing minds to come down for a great two days of tactical talks, panel discussions, and more. If you opt for a VIP ticket, you'll even get a private yacht networking event with the Ahrefs team and all the invited speakers. Pretty cool, huh? I've focused this list solely on in-person, content-specific conferences, but there are a ton of content-adjacent (and even online events) happening throughout the year. For example, Heading to a content conference that I haven't covered? â€‰ There's no denying the enduring impact Scotland had on Gabrielle 'Coco' Chanel. It was the spot where, for ten long years, the designer would regularly frequent during her affair with the Duke of Westminster. Spending long weekends fishing alongside her lover and the likes of Sir Winston Churchill (the former Prime Minister once wrote in a letter to his wife that 'She fishes from morn till night & in 2 months has killed 50 salmon'), it is in the Highlands where she first fell in love with the Duke's rural wardrobe, taking cues from his well-worn tweeds for her own designs - a fabric that would soon become synonymous with all things Chanel. It's as paramount to the house's history as the glamorous clientele she would soon be regularly dressing from the intimate salons of the couturier. Today, at the Grand Palais, Chanel chose to honour both of these story arcs with a show housed in a replica of the rooms where Princess Grace of Monaco might have ordered her custom skirt suits in the 1950s, and with a collection peppered to perfection with Scottish riffs. On the front row, Charlotte Casiraghi held court, dressed in a powder-blue twin set; Sofia Coppola arrived with daughters Romy and Cosima in tow; and even Lorde, having just surprised Glastonbury with a surprise set, made an appearance. Maybe we really are having a Lorde Summer after all? It comes at the cusp of a new era of Chanel. The house's latest Artistic Director, Matthieu Blazy, is yet to debut his inaugural line for the house which will come later this year, so in part, today was a swan song of the past few seasons designed entirely by the in-house studio team who took on the responsibility following Virginie Viard's departure back in 2024. Blazy was sat front row himself in support, surely taking note of the impeccable craftsmanship his petites mains will be able to concoct for his October premiere. What came out from the white-carpeted, mirrored-walled, sweeping-curtained oasis was a celebration of Chanel's most timeless Ã©lan. A series of elegant, ever-lasting and enchanting ensembles the house's VICs (Very Important Clients) will no doubt be snapping up instantly, quite possibly from the very real couture salon over on rue Cambon. Opening with a sea of delectable cream and ecru hues, shredded-hem tweed dresses made their way down the catwalk paired with sued thigh-highs and chunky walking boots providing a thoroughly modern take on country walk-ware. Then came the all-important twin sets as shades emboldened in golds and forest greens, and finally crescendoing into daring, dynamic eveningwear. There were billowing chemises worn atop gilded ruffle skirts, floral pailette-adorned bodices which tucked into silk tulip skirts, and midriff-baring caped numbers in midnight-coloured lamÃ©s that commanded attention from Chanel's most audacious clientele. Finally the crowd bore witness to the new season's bride - a tradition of the house first conceived by the late Karl Lagerfeld in the mid 1980s. For Autumn-Winter '25, she's ethereal, entrancing and otherworldly. Donning a sequin tunic which opened out into a flowing tulle mermaid skirt, her veil was kept in place by one simple white band decorated with beads. She carried a sprig of golden wheat - a symbol that Coco Chanel herself associated with good luck, perhaps from her time spent beside the rolling fields of Scotland. Blazy is soon to blaze sat upon the throne of Paris's greatest fashion empire, but in the meantime, Chanel's Studio Team celebrate all that has come before this moment. Â© CondÃ© Nast Britain 2025

â€‰ The industry's elite has descended on Paris once more, to showcase the uppermost echelon of artisanry â€“ the haute couture collectionsâ€¦ Chanel Chanel's AW25 collected shimmered with operaâ€‘house grandeur â€“ imagine oversized bows and tassels cascading like diamond fringe, with sparkling embellishments spun into the very fabric of tweeds. The maison's signatures were out in force â€“ plenty of camelias and wheat ear motifs â€“ but it was the pearl adorned boots that truly caught our eye. Ashi Studio Ashi Studio's AW25 couture show in Paris was a lesson in opulence, featuring corseted gowns in duchesse satin and whisper-fine Chantilly lace engineered into architectural forms; their silhouettes balancing power and intimacy with the moody sensuality of Serge Lutens and the opulent allure of Madame Claude. Rahul Mishra Rahul Mishra's AW25 couture collection, Becoming Love, unfolded in Paris as a visual Sufi poem, each intricately hand-embellished look narrating a passage through the seven sacred stages of love, from tender longing to transcendent surrender. Beneath the soaring arches of the CollÃ¨ge des Bernardins, gilded heart-armour, cascading pearl bustiers, lotus-laced sheaths and Klimt-gold halos took hold. Tony Ward Couture Tony Ward's AW25 couture presentation in Paris, titled Entre RÃªve et Regard, felt like an intimate exploration of fashion history, showcasing baroque-inspired embroidery, velvet dÃ©vorÃ© cutâ€‘outs, and bespoke 3D appliquÃ©s that enveloped the body in ultra-romantic sheaths. Corseted waists, voluminous sleeves, metallic layers and sheer lace came together under HÃ´tel Pozzo di Borgo's grand arches â€“ this was a collection that brought drama in spades. Georges Hobeika Georges Hobeika's AW25 couture show presented a collection founded on soft, otherworldly pastels, each look adorned with lace, feathers, and crystals that made ensemble look luminescent. The father-and-son atelier crafted a story of grief transfigured into grace, beginning with mourning-black velvets and evolving into celestial whites and blushes. Embroidered stars, feathered flourishes, and cascading crystal veils culminated in a final bridal look like no other. Schiaparelli Daniel Roseberry's Schiaparelli AW25 couture collection transported the audience into a mysterious nocturnal realmâ€”using a striking palette of black, white, and silver as his backdrop for provocative anatomical details like a beating heart necklace and eye-adorned column gowns. The collection played with contrasts, pairing sharply tailored matador-inspired jackets and bold sculptural bustiers alongside flowing, bias-cut fabrics, merging the refined grace of the 1940s with the power dressing of the 1980s. This was couture as wearable cinema.

â€‰ The Victoria and Albert museum is preparing to open the first UK exhibition devoted to haute couture house Schiaparelli. Set to launch in March 2026, the retrospective will chart the history and impact of Italian fashion designer Elsa Schiaparelli, who founded Maison Schiaparelli in the 1920s. It will also explore the present-day incarnation of Schiaparelli, which is now in the hands of creative director Daniel Roseberry. Schiaparelli: Fashion Becomes Art will be staged in the Sainsbury Gallery and comprise more than 200 objects, including garments, accessories, jewellery and paintings. The exhibition, created in close collaboration with Schiaparelli, will be the first of its kind to spotlight the London branch of the house, according to the museum. Highlights include the Skeleton dress, which features quilting resembling large bone, the Tears dress, which features a unique â€œtearâ€ print,Â and a hat shaped to look like an upside-down shoe â€“ all conceived in collaboration with surrealist artist Salvador Dali. The exhibition will reference the popularity of Schiaparelli's designs for film and the theatre with artworks by Spanish painter Pablo Picasso, French poet Jean Cocteau, and US visual artist Man Ray on display. Tristram Hunt, director of the V&A, said: â€œSchiaparelli: Fashion Becomes Art will celebrate one of the most ingenious and daring designers in fashion history. â€œThe V&A holds one of the largest and most important fashion collections in the world, and the foremost collection of Schiaparelli garments in Britain. â€œSchiaparelli's collaboration with artists and with the world of performance make the Maison and its founder an ideal subject for a spectacular exhibition at the V&A.â€ Delphine Bellini, chief executive of Schiaparelli, said: â€œElsa Schiaparelli's fearless imagination and radical vision redefined the boundaries between fashion and art. â€œThis exhibition celebrates her enduring influence through iconic collaborations with 20th century masters and a pioneering fusion of creativity and commerce. â€œWith its unparalleled collections, expertise in fashion and design, cultural reach, and ability to bridge tradition and innovation, the Victoria and Albert Museum offers the perfect setting to showcase her legacy alongside Daniel Roseberry's creations, which carry her surrealist spirit forward blurring lines with bold, sculptural designs that both honour and reinvent her vision for a new century.â€ The exhibition is the latest in the V&A's series of major fashion exhibitions which includes retrospectives of Gabrielle Chanel, Christian Dior and Alexander McQueen. Schiaparelli: Fashion Becomes Art will run from March 21 to November 1 2026. Tickets will go on sale in Autumn 2025.

â€‰ While Paris Haute Couture Fashion Week is in full swing, fashion events go far beyond the catwalks. As major fashion houses unveil their most ambitious collections, the fashion capital is also turning into an open-air museum. From Worth to Chanel, exceptional exhibitions immerse visitors in the history, reinventions, and artistic experiences surrounding couture. Here are the must-see events of the season. 1. Worth. Inventing Haute Couture This exhibition, presented by the Palais Galliera in collaboration with the Petit Palais, pays tribute to Charles Frederick Worth, the British designer considered the father of haute couture. In the late 19th century, Worth revolutionized fashion by putting his name on his creations, working on commission, and customizing pieces for individual clients. The exhibition reveals spectacular gowns, archival sketches, and rare documents tracing the birth of the haute couture system as we know it today. A must-see to understand the roots of Parisian luxury. The exhibition â€œWorth. Inventing Haute Coutureâ€ is open until September 7 at the Petit Palais, Avenue Winston Churchill, 75008 Paris. 2. Balenciaga by Demna On Wednesday, July 9, Demna will unveil his latest FW26 collection for Balenciaga, the house he has led as artistic director since 2015. He will officially leave the role the following day, July 10, to join Gucci, a move announced back in March. To mark the occasion, Balenciaga is dedicating an exhibition at the Kering headquarters. Sculptural silhouettes, extreme volumes, and unconventional materials tell the story of how Demna has deconstructed and reimagined couture through a critical lens since 2015. A powerful tribute to innovation that resonates with the house's groundbreaking shows. The exhibition â€œBalenciaga by Demnaâ€ is open until July 9 at Kering headquarters, 40 rue de SÃ¨vres, 75007 Paris. 3. Paul Poiret. Fashion is a Party The MusÃ©e des Arts DÃ©coratifs is devoting a major retrospective to Paul Poiret, a legendary early 20th-century designer. By freeing women from corsets, exploring fluid cuts and Oriental inspirations, Poiret revolutionized the female silhouette. His love of parties, exotic settings, and rich textiles shines through in an immersive scenography. Evening gowns, sumptuous coats, and original edition perfumes reflect the boldness of a man who saw fashion as total art. This iconic Belle Ã‰poque designer inspired the likes of Christian Dior and Alphonse Maitrepierre. The exhibition â€œPaul Poiret. Fashion is a Partyâ€ is open until January 11, 2026, at the MusÃ©e des Arts DÃ©coratifs (MAD), 107 rue de Rivoli, 75001 Paris. 4. The New Rotation at Galerie Dior This retrospective gathers 150 designs with original sketches, archives, and photographs, showcasing Dior's rich heritage and the timelessness of its modernity. Through thirteen themes, the exhibition explores the house's universe: from a love of gardens to the magic of balls, from the creative freedom of the Miss Dior line to the artisanal excellence of haute couture workshops. It also offers an immersive experience in the Room of Wonders, designed as a cabinet of curiosities, and highlights Dior's iconic elegance and the captivating aura of J'Adore. Galerie Dior, 11 rue FranÃ§ois-Ier, 75008 Paris. Open from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m., closed on Tuesdays. Last entry at 5:30 p.m. 5. Moda Povera V: RenÃ©e's Clothes Olivier Saillard, fashion historian and performer, pays tribute to his mother RenÃ©e by transforming her wardrobe into a haute couture collection, blending fashion and memory in a moving performance. Halfway between a happening and an exhibition, this fifth edition of the Moda Povera project invites us to rethink clothing as an intimate, political, and poetic gesture. In a deliberately simple staging, it reconciles a poetic vision of fashion with independence from the luxury system, while delivering an extremely personal and emotional performance in honor of his mother, a taxi driver and part-time seamstress. The exhibition â€œModa Povera V. RenÃ©e's Clothesâ€ is open from July 10 to 13 at the Grand Palais, Galerie 2, Gabrielle Chanel entrance, Avenue Winston Churchill, 75008 Paris.
