â€‰ Olivia Dunne was recently spotted in a glamorous avatar as she donned a chic white outfit for the 2025 TIME100 Creators Launch Party at Gansevoort Rooftop in New York City. The former gymnast has been keeping herself busy with new ventures after retiring from the sport. Dunne announced her retirement from gymnastics following her fifth-year appearance with the LSU program. For the event, the former gymnast was seen opting for a white outfit, coordinating a tank top with a white mini skirt. She paired the look with minimal yet statement jewelry, including heart-shaped earrings and bracelets. She completed her look with a white luxury Chanel handbag. Flaunting her attire, she shared a mirror selfie on her Instagram story. Screenshot of Dunne's Instagram story. The former collegiate gymnast also visited the Sports Illustrated studio, on the SoHo street, a neighborhood in Lower Manhattan, New York City, known for its designer boutiques, fancy chain stores, and high-end art galleries. She recently walked the runway after collaborating with the brand for the third time. Screenshot of Dunne's Instagram story. Dunne collaborated with Sports Illustrated for the third time, while also gracing the cover this year. "It was always a goal of mine" - Olivia Dunne makes her feelings known after receiving the honor of Time's Top 100 Creators list Olivia Dunne attends as the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Social Club celebrates the launch of the 2025 Issue. (Photo by ) Olivia Dunne was recently named in Time's Top 100 Creators list. She received this honor alongside Ilona Maher, Mr. Beast, Joe Rogan, IShowSpeed, Charli D'Amelio, Alix Earle, and Khaby Lame. The former collegiate athlete received this honor for her incredible presence on social media, accumulating a massive following of 15 million across her social media platforms. Following the achievement, she stated how she broke the stigma and became the highest-paid collegiate athlete when it was least expected from a gymnast. â€œIt was always a goal of mine to get that blue check mark on Instagram,â€ Dunne, said. â€œI actually drew it on a piece of paper, cut it out, and stuck it on my mirror.â€ â€œI can tell you one thing, nobody expected a gymnast to be at the forefront of NIL and collegiate athletics,â€ said Dunne. â€œBreaking down barriers and beating everyone's expectations was very fun. The legacy that I'm leaving, I hope it's bigger than me.â€ (via time.com) Following the retirement, Olivia Dunne now wants to focus on modeling, acting, and longer-form YouTube videos. Thank You for feedback About the author Janhavi Shinde Janhavi is a Sports Management graduate working as a US Olympics journalist at Sportskeeda. She emphasizes meticulous research and fact-checking before creating content, relying on multiple sources including social media platforms like Instagram and Twitter, as well as various sports publications. She has competed in the 10m Air Rifle Shooting event at the national level alongside renowned athletes such as Anjali Bhagwat, Apurvi Chandela, and Anjum Moudgil, which further fueled her passion for the sport. Abhinav Bindra is her favorite Olympian, and she particularly cherishes his and Neeraj Chopra's gold medal victories as they revolutionized Indian athletes' mindset towards achieving sporting excellence. If given the opportunity to introduce a new sport to the Olympics, she would choose American Football for its widespread appeal and intense competition. Apart from reporting on the latest news in the world of Olympics, she likes to immerse herself in reading, painting, and traveling. Know More

â€‰ Paul Skenes' girlfriend Olivia Dunne has been busy after retiring from gymnastics following her fifth and final year with the LSU Tigers. Dunne has been busy making the most of her NIL commitments since her retirement. She featured on the cover of Sports Illustrated Swimsuit magazine this year and has been making rounds on the internet for her viral catwalk in Miami. She's also supporting the Pittsburgh Pirates pitcher by making regular appearances at his games. On Thursday, Dunne hit the streets of SoHo, New York and posted stories on social media. She rocked a white one-piece mini dress, complementing her blonde hair with a white Chanel handbag slung over her shoulder. Moments later, she shared a behind-the-scenes glimpse from what appears to be a Sports Illustrated Swimsuit shoot prep area. She tagged the location as SoHo, New York, and scribbled â€œSports Illustrated Swimsuit" in the story. On Wednesday, Olivia Dunne earned the honor of being among the world's most influential digital voices. TIME magazine named her in its inaugural TIME100 Creators 2025 list. She was placed among the elite â€œTitansâ€ of the online world. Dunne was placed among the likes of Alix Earle, Khaby Lame, Mr. Beast, Sean Evans and others. She posted an Instagram story, where she expressed that she was "honored and humbled" by the accolade. In another story shared, she wrote: While she continues to make strides in her professional career, Pirates ace Paul Skenes made a splash by earning a selection for the All-Star game on July 15 in Atlanta. He's pitching to a 1.94 ERA this season and has gone 4-7 in his starts.

â€‰ Hello Patrons! :)      So I decided to switch it up today. Instead of giving my thoughts on my current read I wanted to do the Mid Year Freak Out Tag that floats around this time of year. Let's get into it! Best Book You've Read So Far this Year? My Friends by Fedrik Backman. A great return to form from an author I loved in the past. Atmosphere by Taylor Jenkins Reid. I have been waiting YEARS for this book, and I was so scared it wasn't going to be good but it was lovely. Courtesy of Goodreads. Great Big Beautiful Life by Emily Henry. The premise made me pause because it was so like The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo but Henry put her own spin on it and I had a fun time reading it. Curtesy of Goodreads     The Favorites by Layne Fargo. I went in with 0 expectations. I had a blast listening to it at work. I teared up a little at the end. Not full sobs but not just misty eyed. It is so messy but so good! Courtesy of Goodreads     Kate & Frida Kim Fay. I read another book by Fay and learned one afternoon in March she had come out with a new book and I automatically requested it from my library. It is a epistolary historical fiction novel of two women in 1994. It covers the conflict in Serbia and Bosnia. I learned a lot and had a great time reading the book. Courtesy of Goodreads     Best Sequel You've Read So Far This Year? Wild and Wrangled by Lyla Sage. This is technically a finale but I loved it so much I had to put it here! Courtesy of Goodreads     The Ragpicker King by Cassandra Clare. I liked this so much better than book 1. I had such low expectations and I was pleasantly surprised. Curtesy of Goodreads     Kills Well With Others by Deanna Raybourn. Fun continuation of a fun series. Older lady assassins fighting crimes being vigilantes. Courtesy of Goodreads     A New Release You Haven't Read But Want To? Better in Black by Cassandra Clare (I sadly have to wait until early December!) These are a return to the Shadowhunter universe with a bunch of short stories! This was a kickstarter project and I am so glad it's coming out in print. Courtesy of Goodreads     Most Anticipated Book for the Rest of 2025? Besides Better In Black, I think my most anticipated release would have to be The Lost Story of Eva Fuentes by Chanel Cleeton! (I only have to wait until September for this one.) It's historical fiction goodness centered on Latina characters. Courtesy of Goodreads     Biggest Disappointment So Far? Curtain: Poirot's Last Case by Agatha Christie. I was just so bored the entire time. Just so anticlimactic. Courtesy of Goodreads     Biggest Surprise This Year? Adventures in the Louvre by Elaine Sciolino. This is a nonfiction book about the Louvre in Paris. Super interesting! Loved the narrator of the audiobook. Courtesy of Goodreads     The Favorites by Layne Fargo....

â€‰ Why Thailand is obsessed with Labubus Welcome to the world of Thailand's latest art toy obsession along the likes of Cry Baby If you've been wondering why everyone in Bangkok is dangling strange little dolls from their designer bags, meet Labubu and Cry Baby, Thailand's latest pop culture obsessions. Labubu, a mischievous elf with pointy ears, serrated teeth, and wild hair, was created by Hong Kong artist Kasing Lung in 2015. Inspired by Nordic mythology, Labubu first appeared in The Monsters' story series. Though the monsters include characters like Zimomo and Spooky, Labubu quickly became the breakout star, especially after BLACKPINK's Lisa flaunted one on her handbag. What pushed Labubu into the mainstream? It's a 2019 collaboration with Chinese collectable giant POP MART. The toys are mostly in the form of blind boxes, so you never know which version you'll get until you open it, making the hunt half the fun. And yes, Labubu is a girl. She's unique: no tail, a toothy grin, and over 300 character variations, from fantasy-themed figurines to dessert-colored plush pendants with movable limbs. These plushies, especially the Tasty Macarons series, have become coveted bag charms in Thailand. Cry Baby, her gloomy-but-cute counterpart, also found fame with fans who relate to its pouty mood and teary eyes. But here's the ultimate flex: Thai collectors are matching Labubus with HermÃ¨s Birkins, Chanel crossbodies, and luxury car dashboards. It's high fashion meets chaos, and everyone wants in. From late-night capsule machine queues to Facebook trade groups, the craze is real. Whether you're a toy collector or just Labubu-curious, these pint-sized icons are here to stay in Thailand. â€‰ Designed by Peter Marino, the 4,778-square-foot space features expanded space for fashion, watches & fine jewelry and fragrance & beauty. Chanel will reopen its boutique within the Bellagio Resort and Casino in Las Vegas on Friday following a major redesign. Designed in partnership with Peter Marino, the house's longtime collaborator, the 4,778-square-foot, single-level boutique draws inspiration from the city of Las Vegas, combined with the refined atmosphere of Gabrielle Chanel's own apartment at 31 rue Cambon in Paris. Chanel first opened its boutique at the Bellagio in 1998. â€œFor us, Las Vegas is such a dynamic market with incredible clientele and ultra luxe fashion,â€ said Rebeka McCabe, Chanel's general manager of fashion, in a Zoom interview. She described Vegas as a global destination for business and leisure and hub for top clients, both local and domestic. Last year, Las Vegas attracted 41.7 million visitors overall, according to the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority Research Center. Chanel has three boutiques in Las Vegas at The Shops at Crystals, The Wynn Las Vegas, and the Bellagio Resort, which has the largest Chanel store in Vegas in terms of front-of-house square footage. â€œWhat is unique to the Las Vegas market is that we have these three distinct boutiques that service their own unique client base and have a different experience within the Las Vegas market,â€ said McCabe. â€œTo be able to create these unique environments within the city that enable our clients â€” both new and existing â€” to experience Chanel and continue in elevated ways is always a key strategy for us.â€ The renovated space at the Bellagio features three ready-to-wear try-on rooms compared to the prior two, a ready-to-wear room that can be privatized for clients, a dedicated area for textiles including two walls for eyeglasses (compared to one eyewear wall previously), an expanded shoe salon, and dedicated areas for watches and fine jewelry, and fragrance and beauty. Among other luxury brands that have boutiques at the Bellagio are Dior, Fendi, Gucci, HermÃ¨s, Louis Vuitton, and Valentino. In describing Chanel's Vegas customer, McCabe said, â€œThey [the customers] have a large propensity to travel â€”Â they have multiple homes within the U.S., and we are seeing an increased rise in clients who are making Las Vegas their primary residence.â€ She added that they previously saw Vegas as having a smaller local and largely tourist customer. â€œNow we're seeing this beautiful local client develop there, that we're really excited to build a relationship with within the city,â€ she said. Set between the resort's existing limestone columns, Chanel's newly designed facade features white marble that is sculpted to evoke the elegance of pleated fabric. Adorned with large display windows and accessory vitrines, the textured white stone transitions into a curved black fluted stone showcase dedicated to Chanel fine jewelry. The contrasting display echoes the qualities of the fashion textiles used by the house. The layout encompasses a total of seven individual salons. Marino designed custom hand-woven carpets and textured upholstery fabrics for the space. Upon entering, clients are first welcomed into two areas for leather goods and accessories, followed by two distinct spaces for fragrance and beauty and watches and fine jewelry. There is a dedicated shoe salon featuring a pair of Liane Chandeliers made of 24-karat gold and decorated with hand-cut rock crystals by goldsmith Goossens. In the back of the boutique, two connecting ready-to-wear salons are decorated with custom furniture. The first contains an Ingrid Donat coffee table with a pair of Venini crystal vases designed by Marino, decoratively placed on top. Two Rene Cresson Louis XV Style armchairs are positioned around the table with a Goossens â€œZenâ€ table lamp placed on the console behind the custom upholstered sofa. With an ivory textured plaster wall finish, the second and final salon showcases a custom AndrÃ© Dubreuil coffee table as well as a round Thierry Leproust side table between two armchairs. Marino selected a mix of artwork to display inside the boutique, with most placed within the three exclusive fitting rooms. The first fitting room features an oil and enamel canvas by Robert Donatelli, an Italian postwar and contemporary artist. In the vestibule outside the second fitting room, there is a Robert Mapplethorpe frame gelatin silver print. Inside, guests will find a black oil on white linen abstract painting by German artist Chris Succo. Next door, in the third fitting room, is a gold resin and acrylic canvas by Gianfranco Zappettini, an Italian abstract painter. In the watches and fine jewelry salon, a gold modeling paste canvas by Florian and Michael Quistrebert is mounted in a prominent spot behind a desk and three custom upholstered chairs with gold hand embroidery to match. For the boutique's opening, Chanel's 2024/2025 MÃ©tiers d'art collection is available. The shop will also feature the new fall 2025 pre-collection. The assortment features silhouettes such as short sporty knit sets, relaxed vintage-inspired denim, rich tweeds, and delicate lace accents woven throughout. Within the watches and fine jewelry salon, a custom crackle lacquer wall mirrors the Coromandel screens in Gabrielle Chanel's apartment. Featured are a selection of the Coco Crush, No. 5 and Camelia fine jewelry collections. The salon also offers pieces from the Ruban and ComÃ¨te collections, as well as a range of timepieces including the J12 in black and white high-resistance ceramic, and designs from the Premiere collection. In addition, there is a dedicated area that features the full range of Chanel fragrance, makeup and skin care products. Last month Chanel was the first luxuryÂ fragranceÂ brand to take to Sphere, the Las Vegas landmark that opened in 2023, as reported. The week-long activation was comprised of a 90-second spot, which aired multiple times daily, for a limited-edition incarnation of No.5 L'Eau. While the new Chanel store was under construction, the luxury brand operated a temporary store at the Bellagio. â€œThe benefit of Vegas is you're always inspired by the energy of the city. I think that generally it's a really nice time to purchase something that reminds you of that visit, or encapsulates the energy of the city,â€ said McCabe. McCabe expects a â€œhigh penetration in ultra-luxe itemsâ€ to be bestsellers. â€œWith this expanded ready-to-wear assortment and fitting rooms, we'll have a strong representation of runway looks from MÃ©tiers d'art, complemented by a selection of elevated jackets and knits that I think will be very impactful. And we'll have other key leather good styles from MÃ©tiers d'art, including a strong selection of Chanel 25 [The hobo-designed Chanel 25, available in three sizes, adopts three of the signature codes of its forerunners: the quilted leather, the braided chain and the pockets], and nano shopping [handbag] in a variety of colors which we also think will be very impactful in the market,â€ she said. She also highlighted a MÃ©tiers d'art flat bag completely covered in gold, copper, and black Strass crystals â€œwhich I think is really extraordinary.â€ â€œThere's also a strong emphasis on novelty. We see novelty being a growing category in our leather goods, and in neutral colors, balanced with a few icon investments to provide options for every client,â€ said McCabe....

"North America Jewelry Market Research by Arizton"Industry Analysis Report, Regional Outlook, Growth Potential, Price Trends, Competitive Market Share & Forecast 2025-2030. â€‰ Healthy, glowing skin straight from your bathroom Last year, we renovated our house. It cost a fortune. So holidays abroad were well and truly put on hold. As a result, I have become a dab hand at faking that gorgeous glow that you really only get after a week or two on holiday. I'm talking unrivalled radiance, sun-kissed cheeks and golden limbs that make every outfit look better. As a beauty editor, I've made it my mission over the past year to find the products that warm up the skin to make me look (and feel) healthier quickly. From tinted SPFs and bronzers, to instant tans and illuminating primers, trust me when I say I have done the legwork to find out which products apply well, look most natural and crucially, make me look radiant and tanned. Because, call me fickle, that's all I really ever want. Here I break down the different steps of my ultimate instant glow routine, which I swear by... My love of self-tan started with tanning drops. As a naturally fair 'English rose', I had always been incredibly nervous of fake tan and the inevitable mishaps that come with it. However, when I was introduced to the Isle Of Paradise Self Tanning Drops, I liked that they gave me the sense of control. It wasn't long before these little drops of sunshine became a firm fixture in my everyday skincare routine. I believe the recommendation is to use them every other day, but a few drops in my moisturiser every morning means that my skin always has a lovely, glowy canvas to apply the rest of my products. The Caudalie Self-Tan Sun Drops have become another favourite. To avoid any obvious tell-tale signs around my hairline, I use a big kabuki brush to buff my moisturiser and tanning drops in, which allows for a more natural finish. Isle of Paradise elf Tanning Face Drops in Medium Self-Tan Sun Drops Once I've applied my moisturiser, laced with tanning drops, I go in with my SPF. I've always loved a product that does more, and a base product with added sun protection is right up my street. Heliocare's 360 Colour Water Gel Bronze SPF50+ gives my skin just the right amount of coverage, evens out any irregular tone in an instant and blends in beautifully. The texture is similar to a lightweight foundation, so once I've applied it with my hands, I often buff it in with a foundation brush in areas that need thinning out slightly, like around my nose. Despite its name, it warms, rather than bronzes, the skin. And it does so beautifully. The viral Beauty of Joseon Daily Tinted Fluid Sunscreen is another knockout product, with 12 shades to choose from. 360 Colour Water Gel Bronze SPF50+ Beauty of Joseon Daily Tinted Fluid Sunscreen SPF30 PA+++ Every time I wear the L'OrÃ©al Paris Lumi Glotion, I receive a compliment. Not only does it add a touch of colour to the skin, but it's the pearlescent sheen that it leaves behind that really makes a difference. You can use it as a primer, as I like to, tapped in as a highlighter or mixed in with your foundation for a more subtle finish. Vieve's iconic Skin Nova Instant Radiance Primer works similarly, but without the bronzing effect. Both transform tired skin in an instant. L'OrÃ©al Paris Lumi Glotion Skin Nova Instant Radiance Primer Bronzer is arguably the must-have product in any glowing skin routine. Everybody has a preferred texture; mine will always be cream. I have dry and often dehydrated skin, so I prefer cream and liquid textures that won't settle in dry patches or fine lines. I couldn't write about tanned-looking skin without including Chanel's mega (in size and results) Les Beiges Healthy Glow Bronzing Cream. Not only does it give a natural-looking effect (which is down to its velvet matte finish), but it lasts and lasts, so is worth the investment. Earlier this year, the shade range grew, meaning it finally works for all skin tones. I can't ignore the fact that this giant bronzer does not travel well, so when I'm away from home or on the go, I use the Westman Atelier Face Trace Contour Stick in Truffle. This twist-up cream bronzer has a slightly dewier finish compared to Chanel's, but the pigment payoff is great, and stick formulations make for easy application. Les Beiges Healthy Glow Bronzing Cream Westman Atelier Face Trace Contour Stick in Truffle In the middle of last summer, blonzing (a technique that blends bronzer and blusher together) became a viral make-up trend....

â€‰ Milan, July 2025 â€“ Rene Caovilla, the Venetian luxury shoemaker revered for its exquisite craftsmanship and storied couture collaborations, returns to the Parisian spotlight this haute couture week with the unveiling ofÂ The Jungle Coutureâ€”a made-to-order collection that celebrates the brand's deep roots in fashion history while embracing a wilder, expressive vision of femininity. Long known for crafting showstopping footwear for couture houses such as Valentino, Chanel, and Diorâ€”each partnership spanning decades of creative allianceâ€”Rene Caovilla now takes centre stage with a collection that unites two contrasting forces: the discipline of couture and the instinctual beauty of the natural world. The result is a provocative, intensely detailed collection that vibrates with fuchsia hues and animalistic intensity. Among the five standout designs, two creations are nothing short of artistic feats. The first, a sheer tulle boot embroidered with more than 1,400 delicate flowers and butterflies, required approximately 120 hours of meticulous handwork. The secondâ€”a 105mm heeled ankle bootâ€”features over 8,000 glistening crystals set into fuchsia tulle, an audacious play on transparency and sparkle that evokes both delicacy and daring. Together, they represent the apogee of the Maison's technical virtuosity and daring creativity. Three additional silhouettesâ€”offered exclusively by order either in-store or through Rene Caovilla's digital platformsâ€”complete the collection. The Jungle pump and slingback emerge in vivid fuchsia satin and tulle, each accented with over 150 crystals in intricate, jungle-inspired motifs. Meanwhile, the Jungle SuperCleo sandal, a couture evolution of one of Caovilla's most iconic styles, is reimagined with theatrical appliquÃ©s that evoke untamed flora and primal glamour. All styles inÂ The Jungle CoutureÂ are handcrafted in Italy at the Rene Caovilla atelier, ensuring every detail reflects the Maison's unwavering dedication to artistry, elegance, and precision. This collection isn't just footwearâ€”it is couture made wearable, a poetic clash between modern opulence and raw wilderness. Available only during Paris Haute Couture Week,Â The Jungle CoutureÂ will be presented exclusively at the Rene Caovilla boutique in Paris. Each piece is a testament to the Maison's past and a bold gesture toward a more audacious future in luxury design. Rene Caovilla's return to the couture calendar withÂ The Jungle CoutureÂ signals more than just a seasonal collectionâ€”it marks a reaffirmation of the brand's ability to channel historical elegance into futuristic expression. By infusing the precision of haute couture with untamed motifs and materials, Caovilla bridges the gap between traditional artistry and boundary-pushing fashion. Each piece tells a story of duality: control and chaos, delicacy and power, tradition and rebellion. Fuchsia, the chosen colour palette of the collection, takes on symbolic resonance throughout. In the Maison's hands, it is no longer merely vibrantâ€”it becomes a statement of bold femininity, wild allure, and seductive confidence. Whether adorning a delicately embroidered boot or accentuating the curves of the Jungle SuperCleo sandal, this vivid shade becomes the connective tissue that unifies the collection's vision, weaving together nature's unruliness with couture's formality.

â€‰ At the Museum of Arts and Design at 2 Columbus Circle in New York in early June, Jonathan Adler, the potter and founder of the home furnishings company that bears his name, looked up at a blue and white ceramic apothecary jar he had designed in 2018. It had wavering stripes and the letters LSD on it. '' It's a nod to my love of Delft pottery and reimagined as if the potter was on an acid trip,'' Adler said, adding that he does not partake. Around him, an opening night party for the show he had assembled from the museum's extensive ceramics collection and his own work raged and raved. Adler, 58, moved among family, friends and vitrines spotlighting notable ceramic art works that had inspired him since he was a pottery-obsessed ''nerd'' growing up in New Jersey. He often took the train to the institution then known as the American Craft Museum and located on East 53rd Street. Many of the 300 or so objects on display -- divided into categories including animals, erotica, optimism, metallica and more -- offered a provocative lesson about humor and irreverence in the history of ceramics. In a section about Americana, Adler's grenade vases and rocket decanters (inspired by euphemisms for inebriated like ''bombed,'' ''blasted'' and ''tanked'') sat in dialogue with Howard Kotler's American Supperware from the late 60s. Kotler's plates depict flags and the White House in states of collapse. '' His work spanned so many different ideas and not only mixed materials but mixed art with commerce,'' Adler said. A section devoted to erotica took in Adler's porcelain breast-patterned vases and his suggestive banana versions, playing off Marvin Lipofsky's glass lips from 1967. In a section concentrating on animals, Adler admired a 1994 cast bronze ''Monkey Chair'' with primate faces and bodies as arms, and swirling tails as the back. '' Judy Kensley McKie finds ways to toy with animal forms in an idiosyncratic and fantastic style,'' he said of the Boston-based sculptural furniture maker who is now in her 80s. As he breezed past works from the museum's collection, he admired them like old friends. '' Ruth Duckworth's work removes the noise of decoration to expose pure form,'' he said of her white cups backed with square blades. The section inspired by the Funk Ceramics movement that came out of San Francisco in the late 1960s (it included Robert Arneson, Viola Frey, Peter Voulkos and others) consisted almost entirely of jokes and gags. Adler's needlepoints of ''Shrooms,'' his shoe-sized acrylic pills and a gilded ceramic lollipop holder vied for laughs with Arneson's earthenware ''Self-Portrait of the Artist Losing His Marbles'' (1965) and David Gilhooly's ''Bread Frog as a Coffee Break'' (1981), a kind of miniature glazed earthenware totem pole. ''Funk is one of my favorite genres because it was subversive and weird and crazy and silly,'' Adler had said earlier in a slide presentation about the show. '' One of the things funk people loved was making puns, and it kind of shows how on some level language can stimulate creativity and how there's a dialogue between language and objects.'' In fact, one of the first studios where he worked throwing pots, in Hell's Kitchen, was called Mud, Sweat & Tears. His stoneware ''Macho Macho Mugs'' made with faces of the Village People, is here for laughs, too, among walls that could almost be mistaken for a shop display, but with curatorial panels that analyze and comment. And yes, several Adler pieces are for sale in the museum shop -- nothing new in a post-Keith Haring world of crossed lines of art, design and commerce in museums. ''If Kehinde Wiley or Takashi Murakami has a show, they have merchandise for sale in the shops, and a show also promotes sales in their galleries,'' said Ezra Shales, a professor of craft and design history at the Massachusetts College of Art and Design, who teaches Adler to his students as an example of virtuosity in the way he makes humor look beautiful. '' Jonathan's work has historic references but without the weight,'' Shales explained. But joking aside, Adler's affection for the often overlooked medium runs deep. ''He's extremely knowledgeable about the history of ceramics, and has a lot to say about inspiration and technique,'' said Elissa Auther, the chief curator of the Museum of Arts and Design. She acknowledged that showing the work of a living designer has a commercial crossover but explained that she wanted to bring someone in to interpret the museum's collection alongside her own curatorial observations. Adler, she pointed out, knew how he wanted to display everything, and gave explicit directions to Simon Doonan, his husband and the creative director behind the cheeky window displays of the former Barneys New York. One corner of the show is a recreation of Adler's studio, with inspirational objects on shelves and clippings and quotes on the walls. '' Make Pots Not War,'' one reads. Adler's company, which was acquired this year by Consortium Brand Partners with plans to expand beyond his 10 locations in the United States and London, has annual sales of $150 million. Not bad for a Brown University undergraduate who took pottery classes down the hill at the Rhode Island School of Design (known as RISD) in the late 1980s and made, among other things, a Chanel teapot. ''But when I applied for their M.F.A. program in ceramics, they rejected me,'' he said. By 1992 the Museum of Arts and Design (operating then as the American Craft Museum) was selling one of his first striped ceramic vases, and in 1998, he opened his first store in SoHo. His career from there spun out (pun intended) to include the interior design of the Parker Palm Springs Hotel, serving as a judge on Bravo's ''Top Design'' and creating a life-size dream house in Malibu for Barbie's 50th anniversary. But even with all that, his potter's soul remains. He put it simply: ''I'm a grown man who gets to play with mud all day.'' A couple of days after the opening, Adler was in his studio on West Broadway in SoHo, which is behind a window in the back of his kaleidoscopic store full of chandeliers, sofas, pillows, and myriad midcentury-inflected objects that he has referred to as his ''prescription for antidepressive living.'' Two of his associates were muddy from sculpting the Foo Dog vases that Adler, who still tries out new ideas as maquettes in clay, had imagined. On the shelves all kinds of past design ideas thrown on a wheel and often fired in the kiln on site -- ashtrays, vases, busts and more -- had accumulated like so many spurned lovers. '' So many things I make fail,'' Adler sighed. '' The truth is that every idea I have is ridiculous and to try to make anything when there are so many things on the planet already is preposterous, I know that, but to do what I do you have to have a bubbling sense of possibility.'' He looked over a set of ashtrays he named for decidedly unglamorous towns. ''They're going to bomb,'' he said. '' But I challenge myself to not be too rational.'' â€‰ Dublin, July 11, 2025 Â  Â  The "Luxury Apparel Market to 2029" report has been added to offering. This report offers an analysis of both the historic and forecast data of the global luxury apparel market through to 2029. It provides a insights into key trends within the luxury apparel market, alongside sales and growth across different regions and category groups. It also highlights key global luxury apparel brands and their current competitive position. The luxury apparel market is expected to have contracted 2.4% in 2024, due to macroeconomic challenges such as inflation in Europe and the US and the downturn in China affecting consumer spending. Between 2024 and 2029, clothing is projected to achieve the strongest category CAGR of 3.1%, driven by ultra-wealthy shoppers prioritizing trend-driven purchases, with womenswear expected to outperform. Asia-Pacific is set to achieve the strongest regional 2024-2029 CAGR of 4.0%, fueled by the recovery of China, along with strong economic growth in emerging markets. Louis Vuitton remains by far the largest luxury apparel brand, slightly gaining share to 9.8% in 2024. Hermes is was the biggest winner in 2024, with its share rising 0.7ppts to 6.0%, thanks to its exclusivity and superior quality retaining ultra-wealthy luxury shoppers. Scope The luxury market will slightly outperform the total apparel market from 2028 onwards as macroeconomic conditions improve The Asia-Pacific region will continue to grow share, thanks to its fast-growing income levels Footwear will continue to underperform out to 2029, as consumers favour trainers from premium and mass market brands Reasons to Buy Gain an understanding of the drivers and inhibitors in the global luxury apparel market Understand where the demand lies within the global luxury apparel market across categories, and brands, to allow you to maximise customer acquisition. â€‰ While the collection was destined for creative director Matthieu Blazy's debut, it was, for now, the work of his talented studio team. The presentation was a feast for the senses, with an abundance of textures; dramatic feathered shoulders and ragged fringe accents on tweed tunics embodied a playful but also somewhat overwhelming use of volume. The oversized silhouettes, while eye-catching, bordered on overpowering, making some garments feel suffocating rather than liberating in their aesthetic. The Paris Fashion Week for Fall 2025 brought with it the highly anticipated debut of Matthieu Blazy's haute couture collection, an event that positioned the spotlight squarely on Chanel's illustrious heritage. The in-house design team presented a visually stunning tribute to Gabrielle â€œCocoâ€ Chanel's enchanting connection to the Scottish Highlands, weaving together elements of the natural landscape with high fashion. Attendees were treated to a remarkable array of fashion, featuring ethereal ivory tweeds, rugged walking boots, and exquisitely embroidered tulle capes that bore an enchanting resemblance to shearling and swansdown â€” creating a harmonious blend of texture and technique that whispered sophistication. Everyone, Breath In To Smell Some Coffee RN, Express Your Gratitude to Robert Wun. Set against the serene backdrop of a softly lit ivory salon above the Grand Palais, the presentation felt almost otherworldly. The atmosphere was beautifully curated, evoking memories of past Chanel shows: plush quilted cushions adorned with intricate details, reflecting mirrored walls, and the lingering echoes of the rich history associated with Rue Cambon. It was more than a runway; it transformed into a sacred space designed for couture's most discerning clientele, enveloping them in an intimate ambiance. Despite the breathtaking craftsmanship displayed in each piece, there lingered a sense of something critical being absent â€” a singular, bold vision powerful enough to ignite a fashion revolution. Nevertheless, what the collection delivered was quintessentially Chanel: elegance interwoven with intimacy, leaving a tantalizing hint of something grand waiting just beyond the horizon. Paris Haute Couture Week 2025; Iris Van Herpen Stitches Living Algae Into the World of Fashion. Transporting the audience back to the very origins of Chanel haute couture at 31 rue Cambon, the Fall-Winter 2025/26 collection not only celebrated nature but also brought forth an autumnal palette that gracefully danced between rich greens, deep plums, and soft ecrus. The fabrics showcased a stunning reinterpretation of bouclÃ© and tweed, either painted or embroidered, that underlined the innovative spirit of the fashion house while remaining rooted in its history. Noteworthy was the use of wheat ears, a symbol of abundance that held significant meaning for Gabrielle Chanel. They adorned garments in the form of dazzling buttons or intricate embroidery, showcasing the exceptional skills of the Haute Couture ateliers. Ultimately, the Fall/Winter 2025 haute couture show heralded a much-awaited return to the fashion house's spiritual birthplace, both in a literal and metaphorical sense. Nature served not only as a muse but also as a central theme, reflecting the creative studio's vision that drew deep inspiration from the Scottish Highlands and English countryside â€” the very landscapes that once mesmerized Chanel and influenced some of the house's most beloved codes, including the ubiquitous use of tweed. On the runway, the reinvention of tweed was nothing short of transformative. Pieces resonated with the essence of knitwear, as seen in a luxurious plum mohair suit, while a snowy white coat dress featured exquisite braiding that elevated its sophistication. Further illustrating this genius craftsmanship, tweed was cleverly manipulated to mimic the softness of sheepskin, artfully paired with feathers for a trompe l'oeil effect, showcased across an array of short jackets, gilets, and flowing long coats. Each design echoed Chanel's timeless elegance while hinting at a new chapter waiting to unfold in its storied legacy. (The above story first appeared on LatestLY on Jul 11, 2025 03:26 PM IST. For more news and updates on politics, world, sports, entertainment and lifestyle, log on to our website latestly.com).

â€‰ Regarding Europe's downfall. More often than not , a frog living in a well thinks it's the end of the world. Explore other countries mate you will realise. Let me give you some examples - 1. Healthcare - when was the last time a person with any injury had a surgery done without a wait period of 6 months? You guys literally leave people to die but not treat them. When was the last time you were able to get a paracetamol for a heavy fever waiting days for a doctors appointment and a prescription? Drugs are easier to find in EUROPE than life saving medicines One of my friend had an ACL tear skiing and wanted to get an MRI done and the wait time was what like 6 months in the UK. 2. Technology - 95% big tech companies are either from US or China. I guess you will not want to talk about this. 3. Manufacturing - When was the last time you heard that the semiconductors in your phone are made in europe? Or ships are built in europe? Or clothes are made in Europe. All you get is fooled by Louis Vuitton , Chanel and Prada to pay high prices for cheap bags made in China. Well I guess you would have seen those tiktoks. If you haven't, it would not be a surprise. China alone accounts for 30% of entire world's manufacturing of all products. Asia combined 60%. 4. Economy - peanut sized economies with no growth rate think their country does not have a downfall. Wake up mate. The highest GDP country in Europe - Germany's economy is not even the size of one province in China out 23. 5. Immigrant issue - Do the world a favour and take all of them. Europe will have more radical islamists terrorists than middle east + pakistan + Afghanistan combined. Your politicians are going to destroy you. You will find out in the next 20 years. I can go on and on but can't deal with your superiority complex. And when it comes to my inferiority. Brother come and visit China once and you will realize who is inferior ğŸ˜‚. Wake up brother and MEGA - Make Europe Great Again. I am not sure anymore how to explain the advantages of UPI over NFC. So here is the list - 1. No Specialized Hardware Required: UPI transactions can be performed using any smartphone with a camera and internet access, relying on QR codes or UPI IDs. In contrast, NFC payments require both the customer's phone and the merchant's terminal to have NFC capability. This is not common in countryside and leads to higher upfront costs. 2. Wider Accessibility: UPI works on basic smartphones and even feature phones via USSD, making it accessible to a much broader population. NFC payments are limited to users with NFC-enabled devices. Many samsung phones dont even support NFC. 3. Lower Cost for Merchants: Merchants only need to display a printed QR code for UPI, avoiding the cost of purchasing and maintaining NFC-enabled POS terminals. This makes UPI viable even for small vendors. 4. Direct Bank Account Integration: UPI payments are made directly from bank accounts, supporting both peer-to-peer and merchant payments....

â€‰ The SÃ£o Paulo location marks The Macallan's second shop-in-shop in Latin America BRAZIL. The Macallan (Edrington Group) has partnered with Avolta to open its first shop-in-shop at SÃ£o Paulo Guarulhos International Airport, Brazil. Located in Terminal 3 International Departures, the store marks the premium Scotch whisky's second shop-in-shop in Latin America, reinforcing its commitment to delivering elevated, experience-led retail in key global travel locations. The opening at SÃ£o Paulo Guarulhos is a high-profile platform for The Macallan. Positioned alongside global luxury names including Chanel, Dior and LancÃ´me, the shop-in-shop places The Macallan at the heart of the airport's premium retail offering. The store brings The Macallan's whisky-making heritage to life through a striking, interactive and immersive retail environment. A bold red backdrop highlights the prestige range, while a transparent LED faÃ§ade draws travellers into the space. (Above and below) An interactive discovery journey showcases The Macallan's Six Pillars and whisky-making traditions through a seamless blend of digital storytelling and sensorial elements Inside, travellers can discover The Macallan's Six Pillars: mastery, exceptional oak casks, sherry seasoning, natural colour, 'curiously small' stills and The Macallan Estate. Through immersive visual storytelling, interactive digital touchpoints and curated tastings, travellers can learn about The Macallan's signature copper stills, natural colour, sherry cask maturation and Speyside heritage and craftsmanship. A prominent Six Pillars multi-sensory experience and interactive digital tools â€“ such as the 'Discover Your Expression' whisky profiling experience â€“ help travellers explore the brand's portfolio and identify the whisky that best suits their palate. In addition, brand ambassadors are on hand to guide shoppers through tastings and provide tailored recommendations across various bottlings. (Above and below) The Macallan shop-in-shop offers a tailored retail experience, including guided tastings, in-depth product education and digital tools designed to match whisky expressions to shopper preferences The SÃ£o Paulo location features a curated selection of The Macallan's hero single malts, including limited editions only available in The Macallan shop-in-shops. Notably, this includes the brand's travel retail-exclusive Colour Collection alongside prestige bottlings such as The M Collection, The Harmony Collection and TIME:SPACE Mastery. Personalised gifting services complete the offer. Avolta Managing Director Brazil Gustavo Fagundes commented, â€œWe are delighted to strengthen our partnership with The Macallan through the launch of this first-ever shop-in-shop in Brazil at Guarulhos International Airport. â€œBy combining The Macallan's heritage and prestige with Avolta's bold approach to retail, we are able to deliver a benchmark luxury spirits experience, taking us one step further in our mission to revolutionise the traveller's journey.â€ (Above and below) Travellers can explore rare prestige releases, including TIME:SPACE Mastery and The M Collection Edrington Regional Managing Director Global Travel Retail Kasper Andersen commented, â€œThe opening of The Macallan shop-in-shop in SÃ£o Paulo marks a significant milestone in our Latin American journey. Guarulhos International Airport is a critical gateway, connecting millions of travellers each year, and this new space brings The Macallan's story and craftsmanship to life for a wider audience. â€œBy partnering with Avolta, a driving force in Americas travel retail, we are able to offer an elevated retail experience that showcases our commitment to innovation and prestige within the channel. This launch further cements our presence in the region and reflects our vision to bring the very best of The Macallan to both loyal collectors and those discovering our brand for the first time.â€ The travel retail-exclusive Colour Collection enjoys pride of place at the front of the store Edrington Commercial Director Global Travel Retail Wilcy Wong added, â€œLatin America is a key focus for us at The Macallan and we're excited to see our first shop-in-shop in Brazil open at SÃ£o Paulo Guarulhos International Airport. â€œThis launch reflects the strong collaboration with our partners and our shared commitment to creating meaningful experiences for travellers. We're looking forward to welcoming guests and giving them the opportunity to explore our rare expressions, personalised services and the craftsmanship behind every bottle.â€ The launch marks a milestone in The Macallan's strategic expansion in Latin America, following the debut of its Panama shop-in-shop . According to Edrington, the opening underlines its ambition to enhance brand visibility and consumer engagement in travel retail. Travellers can customise their purchases via a bespoke gifting station complete with gift-wrapping and branded ribbons

â€‰ It's a brand the Princess of Wales had enjoyed earlier in her royal life. Rachel Burchfield is the contributing royals editor at InStyle, where she covers news about the British royal family on a daily basis, including the work and wardrobes of Kate Middleton and Meghan Markle. Close Princess Diana on June 17, 1997. Credit: Getty Though Princess Diana wore Chanel tweed suits earlier in her royal life, in her later yearsâ€”and especially after her 1996 divorceâ€”she found it difficult to wear Chanel for the most heartbreaking reason. The brand's interlocked Cs iconic logo reminded her too much of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowlesâ€”whose affair dominated much of Diana's 15-year marriage to Charles. As Diana herself said in a 1995 interview, there were three people in her marriage, so it was a bit crowded. In the final years of her life, Princess Diana was a fan of many designer labelsâ€”think Versace and Dior, for startersâ€”but one fashion house she avoided? Chanelâ€”and for the most heartbreaking reason. It's not because she wasn't a fan of their clothesâ€”it boiled down to her husband Prince Charles's longstanding affair with Camilla Parker Bowles, an affair that had plagued much of their marriage. Chanel, of course, is known for its interlocking Csâ€”and this reminded the Princess of Wales too much of Charles and Camilla. Because of Chanel's iconic logo, Diana â€œcould no longer bring herselfâ€ to wear the brand, People reported. Princess Diana wearing Chanel earlier in her royal life. Getty After marrying in 1981, Charles and Diana separated in 1992 and finalized their divorce in 1996â€”just one year before her untimely death. Though she had worn Chanel tweed suits early in her royal life, after her divorce, Diana couldn't wear Chanel because, as Australian designer Jayson Brundson told Harper's Bazaar, â€œShe said, 'No, I can't wear linked Cs, the double C.â€ Brundson styled Diana for a hospital charity event during what would ultimately become her last visit Down Under in 1996. After choosing a pair of Chanel shoes to compliment her cream Versace skirt suit, Diana demurred at wearing them. â€œI asked why, and she said, 'It's Camilla and Charles,'â€ Brundson recalled. Princess Diana in Sydney, Australia on November 1, 1996. Getty Princess Diana in Versace on October 31, 1996 in Sydney, Australia. Getty â€œIt was definitely the timing, it being post-divorce,â€ he continued. â€œShe would have seen linked Cs, and they would have just reminded her of Charles and Camilla. The shoes were quite boldly Chanelâ€”I think they had gold linked Cs on them. And I think for photo optics, people would have honed in on that considering it was so fresh after the divorce, as well.â€ Adding insult to injury, during her marriage to Charles, Diana found a pair of cufflinks Charles owned engraved with interlocked Csâ€”which she interpreted as an homage to Charles and Camilla. â€œIt's hard to believe that anyone as intelligent and well-read as the Prince of Wales could be so stupidâ€”so utterly incapable of imagining what a new wife might conclude if her husband carried a photograph of his old girlfriend in his diary,â€ royal biographer Penny Junor wrote in her biography of Camilla called The Duchess: The Untold Story. Princess Diana in Chanel earlier in her royal life. Getty Speaking to Andrew Morton for his bombshell 1992 biography about her called Diana: Her True Story, Diana recalled Charles sending Camilla flowers with a signed card reading â€œTo Gladys from Fredâ€â€”their nicknames for one another. â€œ[I met her] very early on,â€ Diana said of Camilla (via People). â€œI was introduced to the circle, but obviously I was a threat. I was a very young girl, but I was a threat. We always had discussions about Camilla, though. I once heard him on the telephone in his bath on his handheld set saying, 'Whatever happens, I will always love you.' I told him afterwards that I had listened at the door, and we had a filthy row.â€ About two weeks before their wedding on July 29, 1981, someone in Charles's office told Diana that he had a bracelet made for Camilla with â€œGâ€ and â€œFâ€ (for Gladys and Fred) intertwined on it. â€œI was devastated,â€ Diana said. Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer after their wedding ceremony at St. Paul's Cathedral on July 29, 1981. / Fox Photos / Hulton Archive â€œSo I had lunch with my sisters and said, 'I can't marry him, I can't do this, this is absolutely unbelievable,'â€ Diana recalled. â€œThey were wonderful and said, 'Well, bad luck Duch [Diana's childhood nickname], your face is on the tea towels, so you're too late to chicken out.' So we made light of it.â€ Diana added that, on their honeymoon, she noticed cufflinks on her husband's wristsâ€”â€œTwo Cs entwined like the Chanel Cs,â€ she said. â€œGot it in one; knew exactly. ' Camilla gave you those, didn't she?'...

â€‰ Among the highlights of Paris Haute Couture Week in July 2025, after Demna Gvasalia's final show for Balenciaga, the Autumn/Winter 2025/2026 Couture collections paved the way for fashion that is both artisanal and technological. It joyfully recycles (Glenn Martens for Maison Margiela, Germanier) and places respect for nature (Ronald van der Kemp and Iris van Herpen) at the heart of an innovative creative process. The first thing to note is the list of notable absentees, largely due to the game of musical chairs played by the major fashion houses. Jonathan Anderson (Dior) reserved his first haute couture collection for January 2026. Duran Lantink (Jean Paul Gaultier) will show in September 2026, marking the end of the guest designer model and the return to ready-to-wear collections. Pierpaolo Piccioli (Valentino) and Matthieu Blazy (Chanel, who nevertheless presented a collection) were also absent. French houses like Alexis Mabille and Julien FourniÃ© were also missing. Balenciaga: Gvasalia being Gvasalia before his departure for Gucci Balenciaga Couture 2025 Credits: Â©Launchmetrics/spotlight The highlights remain, starting with Gvasalia's last show for Balenciaga, held in the intimate setting of the house's historic salons (Avenue George V, Paris 8áµ‰). Intimate, in a manner of speaking, as the crowd amassed at the entrance to see the cohort of stars invited to the front row (Aya Nakamura, Katy Perry, Nicole Kidman, Lauren SÃ¡nchez Bezos, Cardi B, etc.) or to walk the runway (Kim Kardashian, Isabelle Huppert, Naomi Campbell). Contrasting with this "look at me, I'm famous" aspect, the show's soundtrack listed the first names of the collaborators, ending with Demna and followed by the song "No Ordinary Love" by Sade. This reflected the "no ordinary" fashion that Gvasalia offers. In this instance, it was a "best of" of his signature style (which could also be found in the exhibition dedicated to him): women's suits with oversized shoulders and structured couture dresses, oversized men's jackets, and a tribute to the nightdress worn by Elizabeth Taylor in the film "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" for Kim K. Kim Kardashian for Balenciaga Couture 2025 Credits: Â©Launchmetrics/spotlight The only nod to his predilection for streetwear, absent from the show, was an unprecedented act. Gvasalia took a turn around the catwalk dressed in a black hoodie, oversized military print trousers, and a baseball cap (worn under the hoodie, for style). Backstage, he reportedly said: "Dressed in a hoodie and jeans, with a baseball cap, I feel like I'm coming out" (source The Cut). This was a clever way of suggesting that everything will change when he becomes creative director at Gucci, whose first show is announced for March 2026. Maison Margiela and Germanier: the future of fashion will embrace the joy of recycling, or not at all To embody this link between couture and street culture, one had to look to Glenn Martens' first collection for "Artisanal", the name given to the house's couture collections. To pay tribute to Martin Margiela, the creator of the eponymous brand, the new creative director held the show in the basement of the Centquatre (Paris 19áµ‰), the last place where Margiela had shown. Maison Margiela FW25 Credits: Maison Margiela Building on the house's DNA (recovery, upcycling, anonymity, the repurposing of objects), Martens favoured a decor of torn wallpapered walls. He covered the models' faces with masks made from crushed metal boxes, varnished paper, and illusion tulle (an openwork fabric fashioned from a network of regular meshes of fine polyester threads). He created looks made from crumpled plastic bags and an impressive gold dress made from recycled computer wires and cables. Look 10: Dress with a heart-shaped draped skirt in gold fabric woven with metallic threads. Credits: Maison Margiela Along the way, Martens showed that couture is the ideal way to adapt to a new and necessary way of making fashion, both ecologically and ethically. The future of fashion lies in the ability of houses to adapt to what natural resources remain. It will involve recycling, or not at all, to paraphrase Malraux. In this, couture plays a key role, especially as it is part of an artisanal, experimental, and artistic approach. Recycling is precisely the strong point of Swiss designer Kevin Germanier, who told FashionUnited: "The day my couture is not made from recycled elements, it will no longer be worth attending my shows." He added in the press release, about his collection "Les Joueuses": "We are living in a heavy time, politically, socially, and economically. My role is to bring light, and that's what drives my work. This collection is a direct response to that. I wanted joy on the catwalk." This is to contrast with a certain lack of enthusiasm for sewing scraps. Germanier Autumn/Winter 2025/2026 Haute Couture Credits: Germanier With silhouettes in upcycled leather previously used for Eurovision 2025, a signature technique of weaving recovered beads, a final dress designed from recycled Japanese paper, and feathers from past creations, the message is aligned right down to the decor. The decor was made of plastic balloons, "rejected for sewing defects, but which will be used for my next show," Germanier explained to FashionUnited. Germanier Autumn/Winter 2025/2026 Haute Couture Credits: Germanier Ronald van der Kemp and Iris van Herpen: when couture makes nature, recycled or living, a creative material Another key player in change is Dutchman Ronald van der Kemp, who only upcycles offcuts and recovered luxury fabrics. For his AW26 couture collection, "Call of the Wild", he went even further by creating an ode to nature, particularly the Amazon rainforest, and by exploring biomimicry. "We don't realise how many solutions we have," said expert Alain Renaudin at Paris Good Fashion. RDVK Ronald van der Kemp Autumn/Winter 2025/2026 Haute Couture Credits: Â©Launchmetrics/spotlight This reconnection with nature definitely comes to us from the Netherlands with another renowned designer: Iris van Herpen. She highlighted the relationship between humans and the sea, underlining the fragility of this vital ecosystem via a multi-sensory sound/light/scent ambiance (in partnership with perfumer Francis Kurkdjian). Van Herpen used textile fibres created in the laboratory by microbial fermentation from plant-based, biodegradable, innovative, and luxurious materials....

â€‰ Britain Wimbledon Tennis Morgan Riddle the girlfriend of Taylor Fritz of the U.S. arrives to take her seat before her boyfriend plays Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in a men's singles semifinal at the Wimbledon Tennis Championships in London, Friday, July 11, 2025. (AP Photo/Kin Cheung)ASSOCIATED PRESS LONDON (AP) â€” Morgan Riddle's effect on semifinalist Taylor Fritz's rise in the rankings has been significant. . Riddle has been at the All England Club this year and others in her role as a fashion influencer, telling her hundreds of thousands of social media followers how tennis has become "the chicest sport in the world.â€ She's been featured in Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and the New York Times' Style section. She was seated at Centre Court on Friday . Riddle frequently is at tournaments to cheer for him. They were featured in the Netflix tennis documentary â€œ .â€ Morgan Riddle went from Minnesota to New York and multiple internships Riddle, 27, is a Minnesota native who attended Wagner College in New York City. Riddle explained that the internships included gigs at a magazine, a newspaper, a government office, a coffee company startup and a real estate company, with tasks including social media. Riddle and Fritz met about five years ago. Taylor Fritz credits Morgan Riddle's influence last September â€” his first appearance in a Grand Slam final â€” and reached a career-high ranking of No. 4 in November. He says it's important to have someone â€œpush you in the right direction all the time, supporting you. " He spoke about Riddle's role after his 6-3, 6-4, 1-6, 7-6 (4) victory over Karen Khachanov in the quarterfinals. â€œThere's an obvious correlation between my results and ranking and the time we've been together,â€ he said. â€œI would have to say she's been a big help to me, just kind of keeping me focused, having someone who cares and just pushes you to just do better and do the right things, be healthier.â€ Morgan Riddle promotes fashion and explains 'tenniscore' Riddle has worked with the All England Club to create video segments called â€œWimbledon Threads.â€ Wearing brands such as Chanel and Jimmy Choo, she details trends like â€œtenniscore.â€ â€œ'Tenniscore' isn't just about pleated skirts and vintage polos. It's about aspirational minimalism with a competitive edge,â€ she said in a video last week entitled â€œ .â€ She added that Wimbledon has â€œhelped tennis become the chicest sport in the world.â€ Riddle isn't afraid to throw a few zingers. â€œOf course we're here for the tennis but what was once a strictly sporting event has also turned into a global fashion spectacle. I know some of you may not want to hear that but just because the fact annoys you, doesn't make it any less true,â€ she said. That segment has 12,300 views as of Friday â€” a different Wimbledon video featuring a kid asking Aryna Sabalenka about pancakes has more than double that. Riddle's clips on TikTok, where she has nearly 600,000 followers, are more popular. She also has more than 450,000 followers on Instagram. Fritz often takes photos of her to post on social media. â€œI've definitely gotten a lot better over the last couple of years but very reluctantly,â€ he said last year. â€œIt's very embarrassing in public when I'm taking pictures (and) people are looking at me taking pictures of her. But you got to do what you got to do sometimes. She also takes good pictures of me.â€ AP tennis

â€‰ LONDON (AP) â€” Morgan Riddle's effect on Wimbledon semifinalist Taylor Fritz's rise in the rankings has been significant. He says so himself. Riddle has been at the All England Club this year and others in her role as a fashion influencer, telling her hundreds of thousands of social media followers how tennis has become "the chicest sport in the world.â€ She's been featured in Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and the New York Times' Style section. She was seated at Centre Court on Friday for her boyfriend Fritz's match against Carlos Alcaraz. Riddle frequently is at tournaments to cheer for him. They were featured in the Netflix tennis documentary â€œ Break Point.â€ Morgan Riddle went from Minnesota to New York and multiple internships Riddle, 27, is a Minnesota native who attended Wagner College in New York City. â€œBy the end of my junior year, I had completed seven internships,â€ she said in a Wagner College video about the Class of 2019 member. Riddle explained that the internships included gigs at a magazine, a newspaper, a government office, a coffee company startup and a real estate company, with tasks including social media. Riddle and Fritz met about five years ago. Taylor Fritz credits Morgan Riddle's influence Fritz was the U.S. Open runner-up last September â€” his first appearance in a Grand Slam final â€” and reached a career-high ranking of No. 4 in November. He says it's important to have someone â€œpush you in the right direction all the time, supporting you. " He spoke about Riddle's role after his 6-3, 6-4, 1-6, 7-6 (4) victory over Karen Khachanov in the quarterfinals. â€œThere's an obvious correlation between my results and ranking and the time we've been together,â€ he said. â€œI would have to say she's been a big help to me, just kind of keeping me focused, having someone who cares and just pushes you to just do better and do the right things, be healthier.â€ Morgan Riddle promotes fashion and explains 'tenniscore' Riddle has worked with the All England Club to create video segments called â€œWimbledon Threads.â€ Wearing brands such as Chanel and Jimmy Choo, she details trends like â€œtenniscore.â€ â€œ'Tenniscore' isn't just about pleated skirts and vintage polos. It's about aspirational minimalism with a competitive edge,â€ she said in a video last week entitled â€œ How Wimbledon made tennis chic.â€ She added that Wimbledon has â€œhelped tennis become the chicest sport in the world.â€ Riddle isn't afraid to throw a few zingers. â€œOf course we're here for the tennis but what was once a strictly sporting event has also turned into a global fashion spectacle. I know some of you may not want to hear that but just because the fact annoys you, doesn't make it any less true,â€ she said. That segment has 12,300 views as of Friday â€” a different Wimbledon video featuring a kid asking Aryna Sabalenka about pancakes has more than double that. Riddle's clips on TikTok, where she has nearly 600,000 followers, are more popular. She also has more than 450,000 followers on Instagram. Fritz often takes photos of her to post on social media. â€œI've definitely gotten a lot better over the last couple of years but very reluctantly,â€ he said in an interview with The Associated Press last year. â€œIt's very embarrassing in public when I'm taking pictures (and) people are looking at me taking pictures of her. But you got to do what you got to do sometimes. She also takes good pictures of me.â€ AP tennis: https://apnews.com/hub/tennis

" He spoke about Riddle's role after his 6-3, 6-4, 1-6, 7-6 (4) victory over Karen Khachanov in the quarterfinals. â€œThere's an obvious correlation between my results and ranking and the time we've been together,â€ he said. â€œI would have to say she's been a big help to me, just kind of keeping me focused, having someone who cares and just pushes you to just do better and do the right things, be healthier.â€ Morgan Riddle promotes fashion and explains 'tenniscore' Riddle has worked with the All England Club to create video segments called â€œWimbledon Threads.â€ Wearing brands such as Chanel and Jimmy Choo, she details trends like â€œtenniscore.â€ â€œ'Tenniscore' isn't just about pleated skirts and vintage polos. It's about aspirational minimalism with a competitive edge,â€ she said in a video last week entitled â€œ How Wimbledon made tennis chic.â€ She added that Wimbledon has â€œhelped tennis become the chicest sport in the world.â€ Riddle isn't afraid to throw a few zingers. â€œOf course we're here for the tennis but what was once a strictly sporting event has also turned into a global fashion spectacle. I know some of you may not want to hear that but just because the fact annoys you, doesn't make it any less true,â€ she said. That segment has 12,300 views as of Friday â€” a different Wimbledon video featuring a kid asking Aryna Sabalenka about pancakes has more than double that. Riddle's clips on TikTok, where she has nearly 600,000 followers, are more popular. She also has more than 450,000 followers on Instagram. Fritz often takes photos of her to post on social media. â€œI've definitely gotten a lot better over the last couple of years but very reluctantly,â€ he said in an interview with The Associated Press last year. â€œIt's very embarrassing in public when I'm taking pictures (and) people are looking at me taking pictures of her. But you got to do what you got to do sometimes. She also takes good pictures of me.â€ AP tennis: https://apnews.com/hub/tennis

â€‰ Real talk about â€œrelationshipsâ€ in luxury retailâ€¦ I've worked in this game for 20+ years. Started at Nordstrom as a stock boy. Worked my way up to top salesperson. Then came Bally, Chanel, and now I'm at the most luxurious French fashion house on the planet. So yeah, I know a thing or two about sellingâ€”and more importantly, about people. In luxury, everybody loves to throw around the word â€œrelationship.â€ But let's be realâ€¦ most folks don't even know what that means. A real relationship doesn't happen the first time you meet someone. It's not a â€œhi, nice to meet youâ€ and boomâ€”you're bonded for life. Nah. That's not how trust works. There are three things every real relationship needsâ€”sales or not. 1. Know. You gotta actually know who you're dealing with. That means names, stories, families, personalitiesâ€”not just what they want to buy. 2. Like. Do you actually like each other? Because chemistry matters. Don't fake it. Not everyone clicksâ€”and that's okay. But don't be that person who throws others under the bus just because you didn't vibe. That's not maturityâ€”that's projection. 3. Trust. This one? It's everything. Trust means giving grace. It means understanding that sometimes sh*t happens. Packages get delayed. Items sell out. Systems crash. Your salesperson isn't Amazon Primeâ€”and they sure as hell don't control the warehouse. But when there's trust, there's patience. There's understanding. There's teamwork. And let me say this loud and clear. The service industry is full of people trying to make others happy. Not perfect. Not psychic. Not miracle workers. But human beings doing their best in a high-pressure space. If you've got a great relationship with your advisorâ€”nurture it. Make time. Communicate. Be human. And if it's not working anymore, don't be toxicâ€”just move on. Find someone you do connect with....
